title: Knocking on the Doors of Perception: Neuroacoustics in Marketing and Tourism. A Comparative Systematic Literature Review and Bibliometric Analyses
affiliations: Complutense University of Madrid and Universidad Politécnica de Madrid

detail.title: Knocking on the Doors of Perception: Neuroacoustics in Marketing and Tourism. A Comparative Systematic Literature Review and Bibliometric Analyses
detail.abstract: This research is the first comprehensive analysis to thoroughly examine the emerging discipline of neuroacoustics in marketing and tourism marketing. Neuroacoustics combines neuroscience and acoustics to fully understand the effect of these signals on humans' behavior and decision-making processes. Employing two systematic literature reviews and bibliometric analyses, this study provides a comparative examination of the neuroacoustics discipline within the marketing and tourism marketing domains. By bridging the existing gaps, such as the recognition of neuroacoustics as a discipline, tracing its academic evolution, and identifying emerging trends, this research underscores the interdisciplinary nature of neuroacoustics and its relevance in shaping managerial capabilities and strategic decision-making processes.

title: Learning by AI: the Impact of AI Hiring on Chinese Exporters
affiliations: Georgetown University School of Foreign Service in Qatar, Huazhong University of Science and Technology - School of Economics, Peking University - School of Economics and INSE at Peking University

detail.title: Learning by AI: the Impact of AI Hiring on Chinese Exporters
detail.abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is reshaping how firms read the market. Linking China's universe of customs shipments to millions of online job ads, we track AI hiring in sales, marketing, and analytics to build a firm-level proxy for non-production AI and map its exposure across products within firms. To structure our analysis, we introduce a model in which firms confront asymmetric information about heterogeneous consumer preferences and show that AI mitigates these frictions by sharpening firms' ability to learn demand patterns across markets. The model predicts—and the data confirm—that AI-intensive firms fine-tune their product mix and prices with greater precision: they are more likely to export, expand their product lines, and enter new markets.  Crucially, this refinement appears as narrower price dispersion but wider quantity dispersion across destinations—effects strongest for differentiated goods, larger firms, and sales to high-income economies.  Together, the evidence shows that AI eases demand-side information frictions, allowing firms to optimize their global reach strategies.

title: The Role of Exchange Rate Stability in Determining the Success of International Marketing Strategies In SME-Based Export Companies
affiliations: Matana University, Faculty of Economics, Management Study Program

detail.title: The Role of Exchange Rate Stability in Determining the Success of International Marketing Strategies In SME-Based Export Companies
detail.abstract: This study aims to analyze and explain the influence of exchange rate stability and international marketing strategies on the success of international marketing in export companies based on Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs). SMEs play an important role in the Indonesian economy, especially in their contribution to non-oil and gas exports. However, SME export activities are often constrained by volatile fluctuations in foreign exchange rates and suboptimal international marketing strategies implemented. Exchange rate stability is an external factor that greatly affects export performance, as exchange rate changes can significantly impact pricing, profit margins, and product competitiveness in the global market. Meanwhile, international marketing strategy as an internal factor includes product adjustments, pricing strategies, cross-cultural promotions, and the selection of the right distribution channels in the face of global competition. This study uses a quantitative approach with a survey method, where data is collected through the distribution of questionnaires to a number of SMEs who are actively carrying out export activities. The independent variables in this study were exchange rate stability (X1) and international marketing strategy (X2), while the dependent variable was international marketing success (Y). Data analysis was carried out using multiple linear regression with the help of SPSS software, and model testing was carried out through t-test, F test, and determination coefficient (R²) test, accompanied by classical assumption test to ensure model validity. The results of the study show that both partially and simultaneously, exchange rate stability and international marketing strategies have a positive and significant effect on the success of international marketing. A determination coefficient of 0.536 indicates that 53.6% of international marketing success can be explained by these two independent variables, while the rest is influenced by other factors outside of this study model. These findings reinforce the importance of synergy between the management of external factors such as exchange rates and the optimization of marketing strategies so that SMEs can improve their competitiveness and export performance in a sustainable manner. The implication of this study is the need for government support in maintaining macroeconomic stability as well as the provision of training and assistance related to international marketing for SMEs. This research is expected to be a reference for policy makers and business actors in formulating strategies to increase national exports through the empowerment of SMEs.

title: Trust, Risk Perception, and Usage Gaps between University Faculty and Students in Generative AI
affiliations: Doshisha University and Doshisha University

detail.title: Trust, Risk Perception, and Usage Gaps between University Faculty and Students in Generative AI
detail.abstract: This study investigates perception gaps regarding generative AI between university researchers and students (N=337), a crucial issue given the increasing integration of this technology in academia. We used a modified Generative AI Attitude Scale to compare researcher and student attitudes and usage. Results revealed three key discrepancies: a "trust gap" (researchers < students), an "intention to use gap" (researchers > students), and a "perceived originality deficiency risk gap" (researchers < students). These findings suggest that researchers while demonstrating a lack of trust in generative AI, exhibit a strong intention to utilize it and assess the originality deficiency risk as lower than that of students. This research contributes to the discourse on building trust in generative AI and addressing algorithm aversion, offering implications for technology policy in higher education.

title: Beyond Sufficiency: Key Drivers of Shopping Intention Revealed Through Necessary Condition Analysis (Nca)
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Vellore Institute of Technology

detail.title: Beyond Sufficiency: Key Drivers of Shopping Intention Revealed Through Necessary Condition Analysis (Nca)
detail.abstract: Identifying the necessary conditions of key predictors such as reciprocal altruism (RA), perceived risk (PR), social interaction (SI), and trust (ST) for shopping intention among digital consumers is essential for developing effective business strategies for digital marketers. This study investigates the necessary predictors of shopping intention using necessity logic. By using purposive sampling technique, data were collected from 204 digital consumers. Necessary Condition Analysis (NCA) was performed using R software, the results revealed the following effect sizes: RA (0.208), PR (0.167), SI (0.120), and ST (0.125). These values indicate that all four predictors are necessary to achieving shopping intention. The findings offer a methodological contribution to the field of consumer psychology by demonstrating how NCA identifies key conditions for outcome variables within a graphical analysis.Major findingsTo achieve 30% of SSI, minimum 8.3% of RA is necessary.To achieve 50% of SSI, minimum 16.7% of RA and 9.1% of PR are necessary.To achieve 100% of SSI, minimum 50% (RA), 81.8%(PR), 62.5%(SI) and (58.3%) ST are necessary.

title: Comparing Llm-Based Topic Modeling and Sentiment Analysis with Human Evaluation of Consumer Insights
affiliations: Purdue University, Purdue University, Purdue University and Purdue University

detail.title: Comparing Llm-Based Topic Modeling and Sentiment Analysis with Human Evaluation of Consumer Insights
detail.abstract: AI-driven sentiment analysis and topic modeling have become increasingly vital for businesses looking to derive actionable insights from textual data. This study conducted a comprehensive comparative analysis of these techniques, focusing on the performance of four advanced AI systems (Azure, ChatGPT, Claude AI, and BARD ) on customer reviews from two different company datasets. The research methodology encompasses a detailed examination of sentiment analysis and topic modeling approaches, evaluating each AI system’s ability to accurately and consistently interpret sentiments and extract topics. To provide a comprehensive benchmark, AI-generated outcomes were immediately juxtaposed with sentiment evaluations conducted by human specialists, facilitating an evaluation of each AI model’s dependability and accuracy.  The study encompasses a comprehensive literature analysis to contextualize the advancements and constraints of contemporary AI systems in the processing and comprehension of textual data. Results demonstrate notable differences across the AI systems. some tools show strengths in certain areas of sentiment and subject recognition .But others reveal weaknesses in  particularly grasping subtle human interpretations. This comparison study draws attention to certain fields needing further growth and improvement for artificial intelligence technology. The study is valuable because it provides us with data on how these AI systems interpret customer reviews. Ultimately, it gives strategies for future studies that aim to make AI-driven mood and topic modeling tools used in business more accurate and reliable.

title: Encouraging Online Knowledge Contributions: Evidence from a Field Experiment
affiliations: Purdue University

detail.title: Encouraging Online Knowledge Contributions: Evidence from a Field Experiment
detail.abstract: With the prominence of user-generated content platforms, online knowledge platforms have experienced substantial growth. However, it is unclear why individuals voluntarily contribute knowledge, and how platform strategies can facilitate individuals' contributions through non-monetary incentives. I develop a stylized model of individual knowledge contributions where individuals have social motivation to gain reputation and instrumental motivation to obtain functionality privileges on the platform. Based on the model, I design and implement a large-scale field experiment, involving 12,182 individuals on one of the largest online question-and-answer platforms. I sample and manually treat participating platform individuals daily over the course of four and a half months. The treatment gives one anonymous upvote to eligible answers, exogenously shifting individuals' social and instrumental motivations. I then track comprehensive data on individuals' subsequent behavior on the platform daily for four months. I find that the treatment significantly increases an individual's probability of contributing additional answers by around 15% of the baseline, and the difference between the control and treatment groups persists over time. The treatment effect is the most pronounced for individuals with low-to-moderate answering experience or reputation and is slightly stronger for those who are close to obtaining additional privileges after the treatment. The overall quality and effort of future answers remain stable. Using data from the field experiment, I structurally estimate the model of contribution decisions to quantify the relative importance of social and instrumental motivation. Simulation results suggest that social motivation is more important, and platform strategies that boost social motivation are more effective in encouraging contributions.

title: Feature Extraction Based on Sample Length Determination For Network Traffic Classification
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Feature Extraction Based on Sample Length Determination For Network Traffic Classification
detail.abstract: Machine learning technologies will enable more intelligent network operations, such as resource allocation, demand prediction and security protection, in the 5G and 6G eras. Machine learning technologies will analyze network-related information and operate networks to meet service requirements. Network traffic is one of the most significant information that represents temporal changes of user behavior. Traffic consists of packet series captured at collection points, where the packet inter-arrival times are generally unevenly spaced. Machine learning models trained using large amounts of data, such as large language models, tend to achieve high accuracy. However, the large models are not feasible in real networks where billions of users are connected because the amount of raw traffic is more than thousands Gbps. Therefore, a method is required to maintain accuracy even when training a small amount of traffic. This paper proposes a method to extract features representing characteristics of input traffic. The proposed method determines the minimum length of features per sample, which is input to machine learning models, based on the periodicity analysis of unevenly spaced packet series. We also introduce a function to convert unevenly spaced packet series into evenly spaced time series to adopt periodicity analysis. The evaluation results show that the classification accuracy trained using only a part of traffic is comparable to the accuracy trained using the whole traffic. The results also show that the proposed method improves the accuracy when training only a part of traffic by determining the minimum length of features.

title: Solving the Supply Chain Trilemma: A Resilient Multi-Chain Framework for Supply Chain Management with Federated Analytics
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Solving the Supply Chain Trilemma: A Resilient Multi-Chain Framework for Supply Chain Management with Federated Analytics
detail.abstract: Existing blockchain-based supply chain solutions often fail to resolve the "Supply Chain Trilemma”: the challenge of simultaneously achieving scalability, transparency,and interoperability. This paper introduces SynapseSC, a novel multi-chain framework designed to overcome these limitations through a layered, modular architecture. SynapseSC assigns specialized roles (e.g., manufacturing, logistics) to distinct Layer 2 blockchains, interconnected by the LayerZero cross-chain protocol for seamless cross-chain communication. Product authenticity and provenance are ensured through Non-Fungible Tokens (NFTs) linked to metadata on the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS). A key innovation of SynapseSC is the integration of Federated Learning (FL), enabling privacy-preserving data analysis across decentralized data silos to optimize decision-making. Crucially, we validate the resilience of the FL component against adversarial poisoning attacks, demonstrating its robustness in untrusted environments. Experimental evaluations confirm that SynapseSC significantly enhances scalability and security, reduces operational costs, and provides a viable, trustworthy infrastructure for next-generation supply chain systems.

title: Measuring Icloud Private Relay: Desktop and Mobile Performance
affiliations: University of Trieste, University of Trieste, University of Turin, California Polytechnic State University and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Measuring Icloud Private Relay: Desktop and Mobile Performance
detail.abstract: Recent developments in Internet protocols and services aim to provide enhanced security and privacy for users’ traffic. Apple’s iCloud Private Relay is a premier example of this trend, introducing a well-provisioned, multi-hop architecture to protect the privacy of users’ traffic while minimizing the traditional drawbacks of additional network hops (e.g., latency). Announced in 2021, the service offers an easy and inexpensive privacy-enhancing alternative directly integrated into Apple’s operating systems. This seamless integration makes adoption of the technology straightforward, calling for studies on its impact on the Internet. The iCloud Private Relay architecture introduces computational and routing overheads that may hamper performance. In this work, we study the service from a performance perspective across a variety of scenarios and locations. We show that for desktop users, iCloud Private Relay typically reduces speed test and web page performance. However, we find that the overlay routing introduced by the service may improve performance in some cases. Conversely, for mobile users using iPhones on cellular networks, we observe lower speed test throughput while finding negligible changes in web page performance. Our results represent the first detailed study of the effects of large-scale deployment of multi-hop privacy-enhancing architectures. To increase the impact of our work, we contribute our software and measurements to the community.

title: Integration of Predictive Data Mining Models and Knowledge Base System for Tax Fraud Detection: A Case Study of the Tigray Revenue Development Authority
affiliations: Mekelle University, Mekelle University and Mekelle University

detail.title: Integration of Predictive Data Mining Models and Knowledge Base System for Tax Fraud Detection: A Case Study of the Tigray Revenue Development Authority
detail.abstract: Tax fraud poses a persistent challenge to the Tigray Revenue Development Authority (TRDA), significantly undermining tax collection and overall revenue performance. Existing manual detection methods are often inadequate for identifying complex fraud patterns within the growing volume of taxpayer data. This study proposes an integrated framework that combines predictive data mining techniques with a knowledge-based system (KBS) to enhance fraud detection and prevention capabilities within TRDA.The research utilizes historical taxpayer data sourced from TRDA's SIGTAS and TITCOS systems. Data preprocessing was carried out using SQL Management and Visual Studio .Net. Taxpayers were grouped into three clusters using K-means clustering. Classification algorithms—J48, Naive Bayes, and JRip—were applied using WEKA to identify the most effective predictive model. Among these, JRip achieved the highest accuracy (99.964%) and was selected for integration into the KBS.The rules derived from JRip were encoded into a knowledge base using Java (Apache NetBeans), while PROLOG was used to develop the user interface and integration shell, allowing seamless interaction with the fraud detection system. The prototype underwent rigorous testing, including user acceptance and system performance evaluations, achieving 92.0% and 87.5% success rates, respectively.The results affirm the effectiveness of combining machine learning with rule-based reasoning to detect fraudulent tax behavior in real time. This hybrid approach significantly improves detection accuracy and user interaction. The system demonstrates strong potential for operational deployment, offering a scalable, intelligent solution to support TRDA in protecting public revenue from fraudulent activities.

title: Enhancing Student Satisfaction and Loyalty Through Knowledge Management and Statistical Decision Models in Higher Education Institutions: A Case Study

detail.title: Enhancing Student Satisfaction and Loyalty Through Knowledge Management and Statistical Decision Models in Higher Education Institutions: A Case Study
detail.abstract: This study explores the role of Knowledge Management Systems (KMS) and decision support tools, focusing on the use of statistical models and algorithms to enhance student satisfaction and loyalty in Higher Education Institutions (HEIs). In a competitive academic environment, HEIs must not only attract but also retain students. Using a case study from Universidad Bernardo O'Higgins in Chile, based on student satisfaction surveys from 2022 and 2023, advanced statistical modeling techniques—such as machine learning algorithms (e.g., Random Forest)—were applied to extract actionable insights for institutional decision-making. The findings show that student satisfaction and loyalty are primarily shaped by the dimensions of prestige and loyalty, connected to perceptions of institutional progress, willingness to recommend the university, and institutional credibility. The study highlights the importance of aligning institutional discourse, mission, and educational model with actual practices to strengthen satisfaction and loyalty. A noted limitation is the challenge of generalizing findings due to the specificity of the survey instrument used. Despite this, the research emphasizes the relevance of data-driven decision-making through statistical models and algorithms, offering valuable support for educational management. The study contributes to improving educational quality and engagement by integrating knowledge management strategies in the analysis of student experience.

title: Secure and Smart Hospitals: Integrating Ai and Cybersecurity for Resilient Healthcare
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Secure and Smart Hospitals: Integrating Ai and Cybersecurity for Resilient Healthcare
detail.abstract: However, as artificial intelligence (AI) becomes central to diagnostics, treatment planning, and operational efficiency, the risk of cyber threats intensifies. This paper explores the dual advancement of AI and cybersecurity in smart hospitals, proposing a framework for their convergence to build resilient and secure healthcare ecosystems. By examining AI applications in patient care, hospital management, and data analytics alongside the evolving landscape of healthcare cyber risks, we outline strategies for integrated cybersecurity architectures, risk management models, and ethical frameworks. A qualitative-quantitative hybrid research approach was adopted, involving expert interviews, hospital system audits, and AI-driven risk simulations.

title: Real-Cats: A Practical Training Ground for Emerging Research on Cryptocurrency Cybercrime Detection
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Southeast University

detail.title: Real-Cats: A Practical Training Ground for Emerging Research on Cryptocurrency Cybercrime Detection
detail.abstract: Cybercriminals pose a significant threat to blockchain trading security, causing $40.9 billion in losses in 2024. However, the lack of an effective real-world dataset hinders the advancement of AI-based cybercrime detection. The anti-cybercrime efforts of researchers from broader fields, such as statistics and artificial intelligence, are blocked by data scarcity. In this paper, we present Real-CATS, a Real-world dataset of Cryptocurrency Addresses with Transaction profileS, serving as a practical training ground that enables the development, evaluation, and comparison of AI detection methods. Real-CATS comprises 50,943 criminal addresses from real-world reports and 102,178 benign addresses from exchange customers. It satifies the C3R characteristics (Comprehensiveness, Classifiability, Customizability, and Real-world Transferability), which are fundamental for building robust detection systems in realistic scenarios. The dataset provides three main functions: 1) facilitating the evaluation of detection methods, 2) enabling the discovery of novel features, and 3) serving as a foundation to expand other cybercrime measurement studies. In particular, Real-CATS helps lower the entry barrier for cross-disciplinary researchers to explore cryptocurrency-related cybercrime detection using AI-based approaches. We believe it will facilitate practical model development and foster interdisciplinary progress in this emerging field. All datasets are available at https://github.com/sjdseu/Real-CATS.

title: Deepfakes and Data Protection: Evaluating the Effectiveness of African Privacy Laws in the Age of AI
affiliations: University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign and University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign

detail.title: Deepfakes and Data Protection: Evaluating the Effectiveness of African Privacy Laws in the Age of AI
detail.abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) has revolutionized our world with many benefits. Deepfakes are synthetic media that have been convincingly altered or generated using artificial intelligence. While this technology presents some benefits, especially in the realm of arts and entertainment, there are significant harms associated with it, such as misinformation, cyberbullying and privacy violations. Africa’s rising digital footprint, youthful population, socio-economic inequalities, and lack of AI governance laws make the relationship between data protection and deepfakes crucial. Our research examines how 21 existing African data protection laws publicly available in English can address rising deepfakes privacy concerns. We employed qualitative methods of thematic content analyses and structural coding to analyze these 21 data protection laws and then classified the definition into three: (i) expressly stated, (ii) implied, and (iii) narrow. Two independent researchers conducted the thematic coding to ensure reliability and achieved excellent agreement under Cohen’s Kappa agreement score. Our findings indicate that 14 of the 21 laws expressly mentioned deepfake identifiers, images, and voices or either one of them in their definition of personal data. Furthermore, six other countries did not explicitly list images and audio in their laws. Still, their data protection laws are detailed in a way that we can infer by implication that they covered deepfake identifiers. The definition of one Seychelles is so limited that it may not cover the identifiers. We argue that these data protection laws could serve as interim measures to address privacy issues arising from deepfake technologies while advocating for more comprehensive legislation and framework to address legal problems the arising and could arise from deepfake usage.

title: Integrating AI in Education: Educational Technology Practices, Tools, and Accessibility
affiliations: Middle Tennessee State University

detail.title: Integrating AI in Education: Educational Technology Practices, Tools, and Accessibility
detail.abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is increasingly a topic of interest and concern in higher education. Much of the current research focuses on AI policies, how AI is changing education, and the AI use cases that include benefits (e.g., new insights) and concerns (e.g., academic integrity) of AI use. This article focuses on AI integration and builds on an earlier article on AI tools, algorithmic literacies, and educational technology, demonstrating how inclusive design impacts accessibility and the design of AI in education. With this understanding, educators can evaluate existing educational technologies and AI tools as options they may consider adding to their curriculum. The integration ideas presented may help educators plan for educational technology practices, such as scaffolded lessons and assessments for AI literacy (which include digital and AI literacy frameworks and the benefits and challenges of AI). Additionally, these ideas may help educators get started with AI by offering suggestions on technologies to evaluate.

title: The Growing Divide in Scientific Attention: A Tale of Two Scientists
affiliations: University of Texas, Peking University and Peking University

detail.title: The Growing Divide in Scientific Attention: A Tale of Two Scientists
detail.abstract: Imagine a bustling city where a few towering skyscrapers dominate the skyline, while the surrounding neighborhoods—though full of life and potential—remain in the shadows, overlooked. This metaphor captures a troubling trend in modern science: a small group of prominent researchers increasingly dominate scholarly attention, while the majority of scientists—early-career scholars, specialists in niche fields, or those from underrepresented regions—struggle to be heard. A recent study, analyzing millions of academic publications and citations, reveals how this “attention inequality” is reshaping the scientific landscape, with profound implications for innovation, diversity, and the future of knowledge itself.

title: Reframing Information: From "Information as Thing" to "Everything as Document" to the Identity of iSchools—Conversations with Michael Buckland
affiliations: MYRA School of Business

detail.title: Reframing Information: From "Information as Thing" to "Everything as Document" to the Identity of iSchools—Conversations with Michael Buckland
detail.abstract: Michael Buckland, a pivotal figure in information science, has profoundly shaped the field through his scholarship and leadership. In this episode of InfoFire, Buckland engaged with me on foundational concepts, practical applications, and historical perspectives, offering provocative critiques that challenge conventional thinking. He declared “information” a problematic term— “It is a bad word; it is to be abolished”—arguing that its overloaded meanings obscure clarity. Similarly, he labeled bibliometrics a “pseudoscience,” questioning its methodological rigor. These rhetorical provocations underscore his effort to reframe information science around precise, document-centric frameworks.

title: Academic Libraries' Spending Matters for College Student Success
affiliations: University of Oklahoma and Pennsylvania State University, College of Education, Department of Education Policy Studies, Students

detail.title: Academic Libraries' Spending Matters for College Student Success
detail.abstract: Do academic libraries, meaning libraries in colleges and universities, affect students’ graduation rates? Some might think that academic libraries are merely supplemental rather than a critical element for students’ academic success. For the last decade or so, colleges and universities, on average, reduced their total spending for academic libraries while increasing spending in other areas, including student services, research, and institutional support. In this situation, we examined the association between academic library spending and student graduation rates at four-year colleges and universities in the U.S.

title: The Holy API: Ritual, Protocol and Papal Smoke
affiliations: University of Cambridge

detail.title: The Holy API: Ritual, Protocol and Papal Smoke
detail.abstract: Every few decades, a curious thing happens in Vatican City: thousands of people turn their eyes to a chimney. And when the smoke is white, the world knows: Habemus Papam. We have a pope! This centuries-old moment feels ancient, mystical and perhaps even opaque. But let’s look again. What if, instead of dismissing this as quaint Catholic pageantry, we considered it a form of communication? A system. A protocol. In the language of information science and software engineering: an API.

title: World Yuan:A Currency-Free Electronic Exchange System
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: World Yuan:A Currency-Free Electronic Exchange System
detail.abstract: This paper introduces an electronic exchange system called "World Yuan",which enables secure peer-to-peer transactions over network without relying on currencies or centralized authorities. Based on the mathematical principles of commodity exchange, the proposed system establishes a labor-proof mechanism, replacing public ledgers with a peer-to-peer consensus protocol. This innovative approach ensures decentralization and anonymity while addressing the performance and storage limitations of blockchain technology. For the first time, the study defines a standard for measuring value and demonstrates how "World Yuan" functions as a substitute for traditional currency by fulfilling the roles of a measure of value, a medium of exchange, and a store of value. The system not only overcomes the common problems of cryptocurrencies such as high volatility and the dependence on fiat money, offering a scalable and efficient alternative to the blockchain, but also shakes the status of currency as the core of exchange. By elucidating the relationships among labor, value and price and exploring novel mechanisms for social exchange and consensus, this work lays the technical groundwork for a future global financial system free from monetary constraints, offering a fresh paradigm for economic and technological innovation.

title: Unlocking the Secrets of Interdisciplinary Research: How Blending Fields Shapes Scientific Impact
affiliations: University of Texas, Peking University, Nanjing University, Peking University and Peking University

detail.title: Unlocking the Secrets of Interdisciplinary Research: How Blending Fields Shapes Scientific Impact
detail.abstract: Science thrives on innovation, and interdisciplinary research (IDR)—which merges ideas from multiple fields—is often celebrated as a driver of breakthroughs. Nonetheless, a landmark study analyzing over a million journal articles reveals that the benefits of IDR are far from universal. Success hinges on the academic discipline, the effort required to weave ideas together, and how knowledge spreads through the scientific community over time.

title: The Amplification and Perpetuation of AI-Derived Biases Through Automation Dependency: A Framework for Understanding the Long-Term Cognitive and Social Implications of LLM Over-Reliance
affiliations: King’s College London, Dickson Poon School of Law

detail.title: The Amplification and Perpetuation of AI-Derived Biases Through Automation Dependency: A Framework for Understanding the Long-Term Cognitive and Social Implications of LLM Over-Reliance
detail.abstract: This research introduces a framework to elucidate how automation bias in Large Language Models (LLMs) amplifies biases through human over-reliance, leading to critical thinking atrophy and the propagation of biases into human cognition and social systems. Automation bias, defined as the tendency to excessively trust AI outputs while ignoring contradictory evidence or personal judgment, drives a three-phase cycle: (1) initial dependency development, fueled by perceived AI efficiency; (2) critical thinking atrophy via cognitive offloading; and (3) bias internalization and propagation, where AI biases are inherited and reproduced in human decisions, even without AI support (Kosmyna et al., 2025). Drawing on evidence such as the impact of AI on 40% of global jobs (Georgieva, 2024) and cognitive offloading in education (Kosmyna et al., 2025), we challenge the notion that technical fixes alone can mitigate these effects. We propose Wisdom as a Service (WaaS), a preliminary framework that integrates non-European wisdom traditions… This theoretical approach prioritizes epistemic pluralism and community validation as potential pathways to address the long-term societal consequences of AI over-reliance (inspired by Cleverly (2025), integrating non-European wisdom traditions (e.g., Ubuntu, Nyāya) and decolonized AI architectures to disrupt bias amplification). Automation bias is not just a human-AI interaction problem but a sociocognitive epidemic. Without systemic intervention (e.g., WaaS, decolonized AI), AI biases will become permanent fixtures of human reasoning. This framework prioritizes epistemic multiplicity, community validation, and culturally grounded reasoning to address the long-term societal consequences of AI over-reliance.

title: They Published It, But Can You Read It?
affiliations: University of Stirling

detail.title: They Published It, But Can You Read It?
detail.abstract: At a time when global research output is booming, access remains a privilege for the few. This article explores the irony of knowledge locked behind paywalls and argues for a publishing model where research truly reaches the people who need it most. If they published it, why can’t you read it?

title: How Does Scientific Research Influence Policymaking?
affiliations: Wuhan University, Wuhan University, Wuhan University and Nordic Institute for Studies in Innovation, Research and Education (NIFU)

detail.title: How Does Scientific Research Influence Policymaking?
detail.abstract: According to Nathan Caplan, scientists and policymakers belong to two distinct communities: the former prioritize conceptual understanding, while the latter emphasize the practical applicability of knowledge. So, how exactly does science shape policy? By analyzing the pathways through which research articles are cited in policy documents, we may uncover the underlying mechanisms of this complex interaction.

title: How Do You Like Them Agents?
affiliations: University of Washington

detail.title: How Do You Like Them Agents?
detail.abstract: As autonomous agent technologies rapidly permeate our digital landscape, a critical question emerges: what roles should computational agents fulfill to best augment human capabilities? The capabilities of today's agents—from voice-activated personal assistants to code-generation systems—continue to expand dramatically, prompting urgent questions about their optimal design, function, and integration into human activities. Despite significant technical advances, we lack a coherent framework for conceptualizing the different relationships humans might have with agents, hampering both the evaluation of existing technologies and the principled design of future systems.

title: Welsh Healthcare in the AI Era: A Reflection on the Digital Evolution of Welsh Healthcare and Its Future in the Forthcoming AI Era

detail.abstract: This article reflects on past digital transformations of Healthcare in Wales and how they quite often failed to fundamentally improve patient care and operational efficiency, focusing instead on superficial modernisation. Attention is drawn to shortcomings in the application of past digital transformations, which often prioritised adopting new technologies without fundamentally changing the underlying practices of healthcare. The discussion posits that AI now represents more than just a technological advancement; it could provide a groundbreaking organisational shift that will challenge traditional healthcare norms, advocating for a holistic organisational transformation rather than incremental updates to legacy. The author posits that by leveraging AI, there is now an opportunity to redefine roles, enhance collaboration, and improve patient outcomes through integrated workflows. However, the author emphasises the necessity of reimagining existing frameworks and embracing radical innovation whilst also addressing challenges related to data privacy and operational efficiency. The article advocates for a new healthcare model for Wales, leveraging AI's capabilities to enhance care delivery. This would propel the NHS in Wales into a more effective, patient-centred and sustainable model of healthcare delivery, fostering a proactive approach to holistic prevention and wellness.

title: Adaptive Feature Selection Using Swarm Intelligence for Zero-Day Attack Prediction
affiliations: Independent, Independent, Independent, Independent, Independent and Independent

detail.title: Adaptive Feature Selection Using Swarm Intelligence for Zero-Day Attack Prediction
detail.abstract: The increasing sophistication and frequency of zero-day cyberattacks pose a significant threat to modern network infrastructures. Traditional security systems often struggle to detect these novel threats due to the high dimensionality of network traffic data and the inability to adapt to unseen patterns. This study proposes an adaptive feature selection framework using swarm intelligence techniques to enhance the prediction accuracy of zero-day attacks. By integrating metaheuristic algorithms such as Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), and Artificial Bee Colony (ABC), the model dynamically identifies and selects the most relevant features from high-dimensional datasets, reducing computational complexity while preserving critical anomaly indicators. The selected features are subsequently fed into machine learning classifiers to build a robust zero-day attack detection model. Experimental evaluations on benchmark cybersecurity datasets demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly improves detection performance, achieving higher accuracy, lower false positive rates, and faster response times compared to conventional feature selection methods. This research highlights the potential of swarm intelligence as a powerful tool for adaptive, real-time intrusion detection in the face of evolving cyber threats.

detail.abstract: The common use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) systems, specifically Language Model systems into high-stakes domains has precipitated an urgent need for robust governance and assurance mechanisms. The introduction of the European Union's AI Act, the first comprehensive legal framework for AI, establishes a global benchmark for regulation, mandating stringent requirements for systems classified as high-risk. This paper examines the critical role of Technical AI Assurance in navigating this new regulatory landscape. We argue that achieving compliance and fostering public trust requires a paradigm shift from post-hoc explainability to by design decision defensibility. We analyse the requirements of the EU AI Act and map them to the operational framework provided by the ISO/IEC 42001 standard for AI Management Systems. Furthermore, we critique the limitations of current explainable AI (XAI) techniques, such as their approximative nature and inability to provide causal reasoning, which fall short of delivering true enterprise decision defensibility. As a solution, we propose a "glass box" approach, demonstrated by a third generation AI, neuro symbolic platforms like the Tikos Reasoning Platform, which integrate logical reasoning with neural networks to provide end-to-end traceability and generate human-readable, causal explanations. This paper advances that such systems, which bake transparency and auditability into their core architecture, are essential for meeting regulatory demands and building a foundation of verifiable trust in the age of AI.

title: Nerd Harder: A Typology of Techno-Legal Solutionist Logics in Child Online Safety Laws
affiliations: University of North Carolina (UNC) at Chapel Hill - School of Media and Journalism, University of North Carolina (UNC) at Chapel Hill and Appalachian State University

detail.title: Nerd Harder: A Typology of Techno-Legal Solutionist Logics in Child Online Safety Laws
detail.abstract:
As jurisdictions worldwide grapple with regulating social media's effects on youth, U.S. state legislatures have emerged as important laboratories for "techno-legal solutionism"-the belief that complex social problems can be solved through legally-mandated technical fixes. While similar approaches are evident in the EU's Digital Services Act and various national regulations, U.S. states offer particularly revealing cases for understanding how technical mandates get operationalized into specific requirements. Our analysis of recently enacted state-level child online safety laws (COSLs) demonstrates how techno-solutionist logic manifests in three interdependent patterns: (1) the checklist fallacy (reducing safety to discrete technical features), (2) the false promise of age verification (assuming identity verification will prevent harm), and (3) the design determinism myth (overestimating design's power to shape social outcomes). The U.S. offers unique insights through its state-level experimentation, while similar techno-solutionist approaches are emerging worldwide (e.g. UK's Online Safety Bill, EU's Digital Services Act). 

The appeal of techno-legal solutionism transcends borders: from California to Brussels, it offers policymakers seemingly clear solutions to complex problems. However, our analysis shows that this approach fundamentally misunderstands both the social shaping of technology and the complexity of youth wellbeing. Technologies can influence outcomes by offering (or not) certain design features (i.e. affordances); yet these designs do not determine the outcomes. This overconfidence that technology can determine an outcome risks ignoring the more complex and nuanced forces shaping children's online experiences. Moving forward requires abandoning the fallacy that we can simply "nerd harder" our way to youth safety-and instead embracing the more challenging work of developing comprehensive, nuanced approaches that recognize both the limitations and possibilities of technical intervention.

title: Legislative Poison Pills, Information Monopolies, and the False Dawn of State Tech Regulation
affiliations: Center for Democracy & Technology

detail.title: Legislative Poison Pills, Information Monopolies, and the False Dawn of State Tech Regulation
detail.abstract:
State legislatures have responded to mounting concerns over data privacy and algorithmic decision systems (ADSs) with a flurry of new laws since 2021, but these efforts have largely failed to deliver meaningful oversight. This article argues that these failures stem from a combination of (1) pervasive information asymmetries that define the data economy and (2) four categories of legislative "poison pills" (weak definitions, inadequate disclosure obligations, overbroad exemptions, and insufficient enforcement) that allow corporations to leverage their information advantages to avoid accountability.

These legislative poison pills do not arise by accident. Instead, as this article describes, they ultimately stem from bills and amendments drafted by the tech industry and its lobbyists. The true objective of these industry interest groups—to stop states from regulating emerging technologies altogether—was laid bare in the summer of 2025 when technology companies and venture capitalists unsuccessfully pressed Congress to completely ban states from regulating ADSs, AI systems, and AI models.

The combination of information monopolies and legislative poison pills has resulted in a façade of reform that, instead of reining in harmful data economy practices, has allowed them to proliferate. Such toothless legislation is not merely ineffective; it is counterproductive. It enables corporations to further consolidate their information advantages, makes later efforts at regulation more disruptive and difficult, and undermines public confidence in the ability of democratic institutions to serve as effective checks on powerful companies and industries.

The article contends that legislators must purge tech legislation of these poison pills and require disclosures targeting the underlying information asymmetries, which otherwise prevent not only the detection of harm but the ability to determine the risks that data-driven technologies and practices pose to consumers and workers. It further proposes affirmative measures such as whistleblower protections, mandatory reporting, and fiduciary duties to pry open corporate black boxes and address hidden harms from data-driven technologies and practices. Genuine progress will require lawmakers to recognize the scale of corporations' information advantages and reject the poison pills by seeing them for what they are: an effort by the tech industry to obtain by sleight-of-hand the regulatory free pass that it has so far failed to obtain from Congress.

This article solely represents the views of the author, and not those of the Center for Democracy & Technology.

title: Holding the Line: Resilience of High-Tech Firms During the EU's Tariff Crackdown on Chinese NEVs

detail.title: Holding the Line: Resilience of High-Tech Firms During the EU's Tariff Crackdown on Chinese NEVs
detail.abstract: The global competition of high-tech firms has been frequently intervened by conflicts at the border. Regulatory events such as tariffs, import and export limitations, and investment restrictions present major and unexpected shocks to high-tech firms. This study examines (1) the direct effects of tariff shock on targeted foreign high-tech firms’ value, and (2) which firm characteristics shape the resilience of high-tech firms during such shocks. Exploiting the European Union’s investigation on new energy vehicles (NEVs) from China, we find that firms in the NEV sector and export to the European Union experienced a statistically and economically significant negative market reaction of -2.3%. The value loss is more severe for firms with greater exposures to this investigation, i.e., firms with more foreign exports and more government subsidies for NEVs. Moreover, we find that innovation capabilities (R&D investment intensity, non-self patent citations, and number of NEV-related patents), financial viability (bank-firm relationships and working capital efficiency), and supply chain adaptiveness (cost-sharing abilities along the supply chain and geographical diversification) help mitigate the negative price reactions. We further show that the value loss spills over to treated firms’ suppliers and customers. Our results provide direct evidence that tariff shocks create substantial impacts on the targeted high-tech firm and identify key characteristics that enhance high-tech firms’ resilience in the face of global trade frictions, offering valuable insights for firm managers and policymakers.

detail.abstract: As an optional component of peer assessment, backward evaluation serves as a mechanism to monitor and enhance the quality of peer review. To ensure the fairness of backward evaluation, we investigated differences in backward evaluation behaviors among learners of different genders and designed motivational frameworks to mitigate unfair behaviors. In a situational experiment, we analyzed data from 431 undergraduate students. Our findings indicate that females tend to provide higher backward evaluations than males and exhibit less deviations in their evaluations. Drawing on the theory of social value orientation, we proposed interventions through motivational frameworks and confirm that different frameworks exert distinct effects on learners of different genders. Specifically, the competition framework was proved to be more effective in reducing unfair backward evaluation behaviors among females, while the cooperation framework was more effective for males. This study broadens the scope of research on backward evaluation and offers practical strategies to ensure its fairness in applications.

detail.abstract: Background: DeepSeek has the potential to drive the modernisation of higher education in China. As the primary beneficiaries of higher education, university students are transitioning from traditional learning methods to intelligent learning methods. However, current research on artificial intelligence in education has been overly focused on rational dimensions such as knowledge transfer, intelligent assessment, and personalised learning, while severely neglecting the emotional experiences and intrinsic motivations that are crucial to the learning process of university students. Method: We combined the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) with the Stimulus-Organism-Response (SOR) model to analyse the emotional perceptions influencing their use of DeepSeek as a learning tool. This study collected 476 valid responses through an online questionnaire survey. Conclusions: This study reveals the critical role of emotions and motivation in university students' adoption of generative AI learning technologies. The findings indicate that students' perceptions of tool convenience not only enhance evaluations of practicality and usability but also stimulate positive emotional experiences—designs aligned with learning habits enhance a sense of control and pleasure, becoming the core drivers for sustained use. Students with high self-efficacy demonstrate unique advantages, as they can establish an emotional connection between the tool's functions and their personal needs, forming the belief that ‘I can use the technology effectively,’ thereby effectively reducing usage barriers. This helps to understand the key factors influencing university students' sustained adoption of learning technologies and reduces perceived barriers to the adoption of generative AI learning platforms among university students.

detail.abstract: In operating environments increasingly defined by volatility, regulatory complexity, and systemic fragility, traditional governance models built for predictability struggle to sustain effectiveness. Many organizations pursuing agile transformation mistakenly treat governance as overhead, resulting in superficial autonomy, risk accumulation, and accountability deficits. This paper presents agile governance not as a contradiction, but as an essential strategic function necessary for organizations in complex or regulated sectors. Drawing on systems thinking, regulatory case studies, and transformation insights, the paper outlines a framework for fit-for-purpose governance that balances autonomy with accountability. Key concepts include "constraint literacy," governance as an embedded learning mechanism, and designing governance systems that dynamically integrate regulatory requirements without sacrificing adaptiveness. It further discusses governance through measurement, exploring how metrics can both undermine and enhance agile practices. Ultimately, agile governance must evolve beyond trust-based assumptions to deliberate systemic design. This paper provides practical guidelines and illustrative examples demonstrating how governance, when intentionally structured, can enable organizations to operate safely, adaptively, and sustainably within complex constraints.

detail.abstract: The New York City Contract Dispute Resolution Board (CDRB) is an administrative tribunal that serves as the final adjudicator of contract disputes between a City agency and a contractor under the city's administrative procedures. This article is the first to conduct an empirical analysis of the effectiveness of the CDRB since its establishment in September 1990. The CDRB was an independent agency until September 1999, when it was transferred to the New York City Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings (OATH). This article first offers an overview of publicly available CDRB decisions before assessing the effectiveness of the CDRB process. For CDRB decisions after September 1999, claims were (1) denied on their merits or procedurally dismissed in full and (2) granted in full for 85.94% and 4.42% of matters, respectively. Since September 1999, the Department of Design and Construction (DDC), Department of Environmental Protection (DEP), and Department of Transportation (DOT) have been the respondents in 60% of CDRB decisions. Unsuccessful parties appealed 21.2% of OATH-led CDRB decisions to state court as an Article 78 proceeding. Of the Article 78 proceedings that have been decided on their merits, the CDRB's decision was affirmed in 79% of cases. This article finds that the CDRB is an effective and impartial method of adjudicating public contract disputes that could serve as a model for other jurisdictions.

detail.abstract: We consider a supply chain with one downstream retailer and multiple complementary suppliers. Coalitions can be formed among suppliers to jointly develop sustainable production technology and improve the corporate social responsibility (CSR) level of the product. All suppliers in a coalition can enjoy an efficiency improvement as they can share information and knowledge about green production technology. After sourcing from supplier coalitions, the retailer sells the product to  heterogeneous consumers.We develop a game-theoretical model and adopt the notion of Nash stability to study the stablecoalition structures and firms’ optimal decisions in equilibrium under three different profit allocation rules. Our main findings are as follows. (1) Formation of supplier coalitions can be beneficial for all stakeholders including the retailer, the suppliers, and the society and environment, but achieving such a win-win-win outcome depends on two key factors –the market’s consciousness rate (i.e., the percentage of socially conscious consumers in the whole customer group) and the efficiency improvement brought by forming the coalitions. (2) The grand coalition that maximizes the retailer’s profit and product CSR level is not always stable as free-riding phenomena among suppliers are prevalent; for example, the less efficient suppliers in a coalition are more likely to defect from an existing coalition because the defection enables them to save cost of making sustainable innovation effort, while enjoying the benefit of other coalitions’ high innovationefforts (cross-coalition free-riding). (3) From the supply side, adopting the Shapley value allocation rule enhances the within-coalition free-riding effect by assigning an even larger profit share to the the less efficient supplier, while it can mitigate these suppliers’ incentive to defect and thus strengthen the stability of the coalition; in addition, we find that a higher total efficiency and a smaller efficiency gap can further enhance the stability of the grand coalition. (4) From the demand side, we show that the effects of an improvement in the market’s consciousness rate are non-monotonic; hence, the retailer should be cautious, as improperly inducing consumers’ social consciousness could backfire, destabilizing thecoalition and leading to unintended consequences.

title: Account of Profits in Dishonest Assistance, the "Equal Rigour" Principle, and the Retreat from "Status"
affiliations: National University of Singapore (NUS) - Faculty of Law

detail.title: Account of Profits in Dishonest Assistance, the "Equal Rigour" Principle, and the Retreat from "Status"
detail.abstract:
The Court of Appeal in Novoship (UK) Ltd v Nikitin [2014] EWCA Civ 908; [2015] Q.B. 499 held that parties who have dishonestly assisted a fiduciary to breach their duty are liable to account for the profits made from such assistance. However, questions and controversies remain. Should the dishonest assistants be required to account for profits made from that assistance? If so, what principles govern the remedy?

The contemporary analyses concerning an account of profits in dishonest assistance are primarily driven by a “status” centric approach. They centre on the difference, or lack thereof, in status between the dishonest assistant and the errant fiduciary before proceeding to build their respective arguments. Notwithstanding their common focus on “status”, the analyses have yielded three differing outcomes. It will be demonstrated that each of these analyses is flawed.

This article mounts an argument from “facilitative institutions”, and advocates for an “equal rigour” principle to be adopted. The thrust of the analysis is this. Awarding an account of profits against dishonest assistants is justifiable on the ground that it is needed to safeguard the fiduciary relationship, a facilitative institution provided for by the law, from institutional harm. Just as the law protects the fiduciary relationship by ensuring that the fiduciary resists internal temptations, it is equally important that it repels external interferences with the relationship. By the same token, the remedial principles governing breaches of fiduciary duty should apply in equal force to dishonest assistance claims.

title: Modeling Uncertainty Awareness under Strategic Decision Making in Game Theory beyond Nash

detail.title: Modeling Uncertainty Awareness under Strategic Decision Making in Game Theory beyond Nash
detail.abstract: Game theory provides a powerful framework for analyzing strategic interactions among rational agents, yet its foundational reliance on perfect information or common knowledge often falls short in capturing the complexities of real-world decision-making. This paper introduces a novel extension to classical game theory by incorporating "uncertainty awareness"-a mechanism that models how players account for their lack of complete information or their opponent's uncertainty. We formalize this concept mathematically using a stateupdate mechanism, demonstrating how awareness influences strategic behavior. The core of our contribution is the "Shadow Auction" game-a modified auction format where players submit an initial bid based on partial information and a shadow bid after seeing the opponent's move. By analyzing this game, we show that uncertainty awareness can lead to novel phenomena not captured by traditional Nash equilibria. This work expands game theory toward a more realistic model of bounded decision-making, incorporating adaptive learning and risk adjustment.

title: The Preparedness Ladder: A Neurobiologically-Informed Coaching Model for Overcoming Hopeful Inaction

detail.title: The Preparedness Ladder: A Neurobiologically-Informed Coaching Model for Overcoming Hopeful Inaction
detail.abstract: This paper introduces the Preparedness Ladder, a theoretical coaching framework grounded in neurobiological principles, designed to help clients transition from passive, action-less hope to purposeful engagement. Drawing from the Parallel Pathways model-which conceptualizes hope and fear as neurobiologically linked by their relationship to action-this framework addresses a common but overlooked phenomenon in coaching: hopeful paralysis. The Preparedness Ladder offers a structured, four-stage process that supports coaches in identifying cognitive or emotional stalling, mentally priming action pathways, and establishing micro-commitments and pre-freeze protocols to bypass default freeze responses. Each stage is informed by distinct neural mechanisms, particularly the shift from ventrolateral to dorsolateral periaqueductal gray (vlPAG to dlPAG) dominance. An accompanying Neural State Shifting protocol deepens the model's utility by enabling targeted interventions based on the client's neurochemical and behavioral state. While conceptual in scope, this framework provides a practical and ethically bounded tool for coaches working with action-resistant clients, and offers clear implications for future empirical study and potential application across organizational, educational, and health behavior domains.

detail.title: Comparing Post-Keynesianism and Modern Monetary Theory: The Importance of Ontology and Sociology
detail.abstract: This paper utilises Marc Lavoie's 2024 critique of Modern Monetary Theory (MMT) to contrast the ontological foundations, methodologies, and policy implications of MMT with those of Post-Keynesian (PK) economics. We argue that disagreements between these schools reflect fundamental ontological divergences rather than technical nuances. Post-Keynesian economics models the economy as a private-sector-led system where the state intervenes reactively, while MMT positions the state as the constitutive architect of monetary systems, designing market operations through taxation, currency issuance, and fiscal policy. Key areas examined include treasury-central bank operations, external sector dynamics, unemployment, and interest rate policy. The paper also addresses MMT's intellectual origins in financial practice rather than heterodox theory and analyses sociological factors shaping its contentious reception within economics. We conclude that constructive MMT-PK dialogue requires acknowledging these ontological roots to reconcile divergent policy prescriptions.

detail.title: Complementors' Dual-Level Knowledge and Its Role in Platform Ecosystem Innovation
detail.abstract: This study examines how complementors' knowledge shapes innovation in platform ecosystems, focusing on architectural and component-level knowledge in relation to platform boundary resources (PBRs). While PBRs support third-party development, their effectiveness depends on complementors' capabilities. Using data from 1,311 user-generated modifications (mods) from the Dark Souls game series, we find that architectural knowledge is positively associated with innovation performance. Furthermore, component-level knowledge enhances innovation outcomes only when complementors also possess architectural knowledge, particularly when the latter is modeled as a binary variable. These results highlight the importance of combining structural understanding with prior development experience to produce high-performing complementary products. Platform owners should not only provide accessible PBRs but also support complementors in acquiring architectural knowledge through training and documentation to foster sustainable innovation.

title: An Integrated Value Based Framework to Understand the Nature of Consciousness: Distinguishing Human and Machine Experience

detail.title: An Integrated Value Based Framework to Understand the Nature of Consciousness: Distinguishing Human and Machine Experience
detail.abstract: This paper explores the core insight that sets human consciousness apart from machine processing: the emotionallydriven pursuit of value and satisfaction. It critiques traditional cognitive models (notably Kahneman's), integrates recent theories on emotion and value, and draws a clear distinction between human and machine consciousness. The argument is made that understanding cognition requires centering emotion and value as foundational, not peripheral, elements. Within this theoretical framework, "Value" represents: Definition of the term "Value": Represents an individual's dynamically constructed and contextually-dependent perception of worth, significance, or desirability-fundamentally shaped by their unique history, experiences, and evolutionary predispositions. It is not a static calculation or objective measure but rather an iterative process of cognitive appraisal and emotional response, resulting in a personalized valuation system that actively guides behavior toward perceived satisfaction and promotes individual growth. This system mirrors the broader dynamics of naturewhere non-human living beings, including plants and animals, operate through a similar process of value perception to drive growth, survival, and evolution. Just as a tree seeks sunlight or an animal pursues food, value guides behavior toward desired outcomes and promotes individual growth. This inherent drive to seek "value"-whether it's a resource, connection, or experience-is rooted in the very nature of consciousness and life itself, extending beyond humanspecific interpretations. This process is not solely driven by conscious intention, but also by ingrained instincts and physiological needs.

detail.title: Beyond Wall Street: Technological Innovation and the Rise of Individual Investors
detail.abstract: The rise of individual investors marks a structural shift in financial markets, driven by advances in digital platforms, AI-driven tools, and global connectivity. Traditionally viewed as passive recipients of institutional innovation, individual investors now actively shape market dynamics through strategic behavior, platform engagement, and capital allocation into non-traditional domains. This paper introduces the concept of Circular Innovation Streams, a self-reinforcing model in which empowered individuals not only adopt emerging technologies but also drive their evolution. Unlike traditional linear models of innovation diffusion, Circular Innovation Streams emphasize recursive feedback: investor behavior generates innovation pressure, which reshapes platform features, further enhancing investor autonomy and influence. To formalize this dynamic, a recursive mathematical model is developed that links investor empowerment (Et), investor behavior (Bt), innovation outcomes (It), and platform evolution (Pt) over time. A stylized algorithm illustrates the core feedback mechanism, providing a foundation for future agent-based simulations and empirical validation. This formalization captures how digitally empowered investors fuel a continuous cycle of technological and financial innovation.

detail.abstract: The UK and EU have become acutely aware of the strategic vulnerabilities posed by capital market globalisation particularly the loss of high-potential firms and domestic investment capital. With harmonised global standards in retreat, the strategic use of regulation as a retention tool has moved to the heart of their regulating for growth agenda. While the UK and the EU have similar worries about outward flows, especially to the U.S. markets, fundamental differences in their capital market ecosystems result in divergence in their regulatory responses. The paper highlights similarities and differences in key UK and EU initiatives aimed at improving capital market access for domestic growth companies and large privately-owned companies. The persistent difficulty of closing funding gaps for growth companies and providing exits for investors in privately-owned companies, coupled with the growing importance of private capital markets, has elevated this policy area to one of strategic importance. The paper explores the challenges faced by public growth markets and. considers how their competitive position may be impacted by the introduction, led by the UK, of a new ‘private plus’ type of stock exchange for privately-owned companies. Stimulated by the scholarship of Roberta Romano, this paper examines the UK and EU retention efforts through the lens of defensive regulatory competition. Key findings relate to (i) diversity in legal transplants; (ii) the limits of regulatory solutions in addressing market ecosystem problems; and (iii) the (mis)alignment between market friendly solutions and socially optimal outcomes.

detail.title: Streamflow Prediction in the Jhelum River Basin Using Ensemble Machine Learning Models and Long-Term Hydro-Meteorological Data
detail.abstract: This study pertains to streamflow prediction in the Jhelum River, a complex and snow-fed river basin in the Himalaya, Jammu and Kashmir, India. The Jhelum River originates from Verinag Spring in the Pir Panjal Mountain range. It is susceptible to extreme flooding events, including the recent devastating 2014 Kashmir flood, with continued flooding threatening lives and property in the region. Therefore, good hydrological prediction models are needed to forecast water levels, especially floods. In this study, we used 56 years (i.e. 1969–2024) of historical data for the study area, which included discharge (m3/s), rainfall (mm), temperature (°C), humidity (%), and wind speed (km/h) from five gauging stations and four meteorological stations. The study used four machine learning models: Random Forest, LightGBM, XGBoost and CatBoost to predict streamflow at Padshahi Bagh gauging station in Srinagar. We used an 80:20 train-test split to evaluate the performance of the models based on the training and testing errors. For the models analysed, XGBoost achieved the highest generalisation performance (i.e. R2 = 0.7736), while CatBoost had the best training accuracy (i.e. R2 = 0.9976), which indicates overfitting. The study demonstrates that ensemble learning models can be utilised for forecasting in a complex snow-fed basin such as the Jhelum River, with parameters from an actual basin observed for 56 years, where XGBoost provided a more robust and deployable solution for predicting streamflow of the Jhelum River. This research demonstrates the rationale to expand machine learning in hydrological modelling, while improving flood forecasting, water resource planning, and climate resilience through the prediction of streamflow in the Himalayan area.

title: Towards Efficient Building Energy Management: Deep Learning and Iot Strategies for Predictive Analytics and Optimization

detail.abstract: The rapid growth in global population necessitates efficient energy management solutions for sustainable living. Smart Building Energy Management Systems (SBEMS) play a crucial role in achieving this goal by leveraging automation and advanced analytics. This study proposes a novel Deep Learning and IoT-based SBEMS approach to predict energy consumption, classify buildings into energy-demand clusters, and optimize the monitoring and operation of electrical equipment. While traditional statistical methods have been widely used for load forecasting, recent advancements in deep learning provide robust alternatives to address the inherent complexity of nonlinear energy consumption patterns. This research employs regression analysis and state-of-the-art neural network architectures, including Single-Step and Multi-Step Dense Models, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, to enhance prediction accuracy. Additionally, K-means clustering is introduced to segment buildings into distinct energy-demand categories, ensuring optimal energy utilization. Unlike prior studies that often lack a comprehensive approach, this work integrates all critical features under a unified framework. By applying these advanced methodologies to a unique dataset, the proposed system demonstrates improved accuracy in energy load forecasting and clustering, providing a significant contribution to the field of smart building energy management.

detail.abstract:
This article examines New York's 1814 Act to Encourage Privateering Associations, the second general incorporation statute in U.S. history and a unique example of early industrial policy designed to facilitate private maritime warfare. The article situates the 1814 Act within the broader context of the War of 1812, examining the costs, risks, and organizational challenges that made both the privateering business and incorporation of that business attractive to potential investors. This early experiment in using incorporation to advance public policy objectives through private initiative offers valuable insights into both the historical development of American corporate law and the relationship between legal innovation and economic development in the early Republic.


Through detailed analysis of the Act's provisions and historical context, this study advances three principal arguments. First, it demonstrates that early general incorporation statutes functioned as deliberate instruments of industrial policy rather than neutral procedural mechanisms, with the 1814 Act representing a novel state effort to harness private capital for national defense. Second, it provides insight into the contested evolution of essential corporate attributes by analyzing which features of the modern corporation the Act provided and which it omitted, contributing to ongoing scholarly debates about the truly indispensable characteristics of the corporate form. The statute's design reveals contemporary understanding of how corporate privileges could encourage high-risk entrepreneurial ventures by providing limited liability, centralized management, and rudimentary asset partitioning. Third, it offers a case study of how economic necessity can drive the functional development of corporate features—particularly asset partitioning and limited liability—even when formal legal architecture remains incomplete.

title: Efficiency of Attracting Financing in the Public Debt Market of Ukraine and Poland

detail.title: Efficiency of Attracting Financing in the Public Debt Market of Ukraine and Poland
detail.abstract: The study of the issue of assessing the effectiveness of attracting financing in the public debt market is still relevant. This is due to the constant increase in public debt in all countries without exception: the least developed and the most developed. A large amount of public debt does not mean the presence of problems with the economy. The problems stem from inefficient management of such debts. Methods and tools that can be used to assess the effectiveness of attracting financing in the public debt market are quite broad. However, the more factors are taken into account in such an assessment, the better and more reliable the assessment will be. The effectiveness of attracting financing in the country's public debt market should take into account the conditions that characterize the state of the country's economy. The best option is to take into account the macroeconomic parameters of economic development, such as: the volume of GDP in actual prices, state budget revenues, the size of international reserves, inflation index. After all, it is the macroeconomic situation in the country that determines the opportunities and the need to attract financing in the external and domestic markets of public debt. The effectiveness of attracting financing in the public debt market can be carried out using both qualitative and quantitative instruments. The calculation of the efficiency ratio refers to quantitative statistical evaluation methods. In this case, this ratio can be modified by adding a number of new factors that are defined as either positive or negative factors. The assessment of debt financing is carried out in terms of external and domestic debt of two countries – Ukraine and Poland, which are at different levels of economic development. This allowed to interpret the results of calculations as objectively as possible and to take into account the conditions of debt financing of the needs of the economy of Ukraine and Poland. Expanding the tools for assessing the effectiveness of attracting financing in the public debt market is of practical importance and allows you to use different variations of the indicator by adding factors. This is the basis of further research.

title: Robust Discharge Prediction of Seasonal Snow-Influenced Karst Systems Through Hybridization of Process-Based and Data-Driven Models
