detail.title: Robust Discharge Prediction of Seasonal Snow-Influenced Karst Systems Through Hybridization of Process-Based and Data-Driven Models
detail.abstract: Hydrological modeling of karst systems is difficult due to their unique recharge, drainage, and discharge behavior, which is often highly dynamic and nonlinear. It becomes even more challenging for elevated karst catchments, where the recharge process is additionally influenced by snow accumulation and melting. In this study, we developed an innovative modeling approach of hybridizing a process-based model and a data-driven model for the karst systems influenced by seasonal snow cover, and tested its application to a large, complex karst system in the Unica River catchment in Slovenia. For this purpose, the process-based model Génie Rural à 6 paramètres Journalier including the CemaNeige snow routine (CemaNeige GR6J) was hybridized with the Stacked Autoencoder Deep Neural Networks (SAE-DNN). A 60-year period of catchment discharge observations from 1962 to 2021 was used for model development, testing and evaluation. The performance of the stand-alone models CemaNeige GR6J as well as SAE-DNN, and the hybrid model CemaNeige GR6J-SAE-DNN was systematically compared. The results show that the hybrid model clearly outperforms the stand-alone process-based model and the data-driven model, especially during the extreme flow conditions. To better understand the hybrid model behavior, the Shapley Additive exPlanation (SHAP) was used and showed that the slow and fast flow components contributed significantly to the overall performance of the hybrid model. Overall, the proposed hybrid modeling approach provides an innovative way to robustly predict the daily discharge behavior of karst systems influenced by seasonal snow cover, especially during extreme flow conditions, and can be easily applied to other karst systems with similar characteristics to support robust decision making in karst water resource management.

detail.abstract: Given the variety of debt relations scenarios across different countries, debt security issues are becoming increasingly relevant. Modern debt management concepts are developing in two contrasting directions. The first criticizes the increase in public debt, focusing solely on its negative consequences. The second is based on the theory of effective public debt management, which recognizes the potential positive effects of rising public debt. This second theory is supported by the successful operation of countries with significant debt burdens.In this context, the uniqueness of the conditions for debt financing of state budget deficits in different economies has been demonstrated. Particular attention is given to the exogenous environment influencing Ukraine’s state debt formation, based on which thirteen factors causing the uncontrolled growth of Ukraine’s public debt were identified and substantiated.Using a hierarchization of threats, six levels of factors influencing the level of public debt were identified. Among the most significant threats leading to the growth of public debt are factors closely related to the budget deficit. In contrast, Ukraine’s dependence on energy imports, cyclical economic fluctuations, the influence of political business cycles, and the technical backwardness of a significant part of Ukraine’s national economy were found to be the least influential.These factors have the highest impact on all sectors of the economy and, therefore, exhibit the widest range of interconnections. The simulation results confirm that the existence of debt and its potential transition to an uncontrolled state of growth are different situations, each of which requires specific effective management.

detail.abstract: We analyze the effects of start-up grants for young firms and their founders. We match records from a program funding thousands of new firms in Romania to linked employer-employee tax data. We use a regression discontinuity design to compare firms just above the score for obtaining funding with those just below. Funded and unfunded firms show a divergence in trends 6-months post-approval. After 3 years, funded firms are about four times more likely to survive, have more employees, and earn higher income. However, only a handful of firms hire above the requirements for getting funding. We find no evidence of increases in labor productivity or patenting. We find no effects on founder taxpaying status or founder total income. Comparing funded subindustries with similar ones not treated, as well as counties more and less treated, we find no equilibrium effects on economic activity (income, number of employees, employee income), despite higher numbers of new firms. The evidence is consistent with a trade-off when designing grant programs: simple, broad programs, with bureaucratic hurdles ensuring prudent usage of public funds can inadvertently dampen the emergence of high-growth, high-productivity, innovative start-ups.

detail.abstract: This study evaluates the performance of local, global and hybrid forecasting approaches for short-term household electricity consumption. Using real data from the GoiEner energy cooperative, different models were developed and compared, including basic statistical techniques, machine learning models, and ensemble methods. Special attention is given to FFORMA, a meta-learning approach that assigns dynamic weights to base models based on their expected error. The results show that local models demonstrated superior performance, most likely because no set of features was found that could reliably explain the prediction error across series, limiting the ability of hybrid methods to learn meaningful combinations. Even so, hybrid and global models show potential in contexts with more diverse users. These findings are particularly relevant for selecting forecasting algorithms in Home Energy Management Systems (HEMS), where accurate short-term demand prediction is essential for optimizing energy usage and integration of renewables.

title: Code Biology and Abduction in the Creative Process
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Code Biology and Abduction in the Creative Process
detail.abstract: In this paper, we investigate how abduction represents one of the fundamental stages within the broader process of creativity. We begin by revisiting the various definitions of abduction, starting with the one proposed by Peirce, who conceptualized it as a form of logical inference enabling a “jump to a conclusion” from given facts. Post-Peircean semiotics retains the central idea that abduction is a logical inference that allows for “best guessing” and, as such, can lead to both fallacious reasoning and highly innovative insights. Particularly relevant is Umberto Eco’s classification of abduction into three types: overcoded, undercoded, and creative. Expanding the notion into an ecosystemic framework, we examine two significant definitions of abduction, namely those of Gregory Bateson and Victoria Alexander. Bateson argues that abduction is a fundamental process underpinning most of our perceptions and knowledge of the world, enhancing our capacity for abstraction. Alexander, on the other hand, introduces a concept closely related to abduction: stochastic resonance. We argue that the theoretical framework which best integrates and enriches these perspectives is found in the field of Code Biology, where abduction is conceived as a vital process that enables human beings to interpret their environment, where three processes are necessary for interpretation: coding, decoding and abduction. Finally, we present several theories of abduction developed within one of the most application-oriented domains of creativity studies: design.

title: Transitioning to the Circular Textile and Fashion Industry: Drivers and Barriers from Stakeholder's Perspectives

detail.title: Transitioning to the Circular Textile and Fashion Industry: Drivers and Barriers from Stakeholder's Perspectives
detail.abstract: This article explores the perspectives of multiple stakeholders within the circular ecosystem of Thailand’s textile and fashion industry (TFI), aiming to investigate the drivers and barriers to the industry's transition toward a circular economy (CE). A qualitative methodology is adopted, comprising in-depth interviews with 42 stakeholders across various sectors involved in the industry’s circular ecosystem. The data were analyzed using qualitative content analysis supported by the STEEP framework, which includes Social, Technological, Economic, Environmental, and Political dimensions, to categorize and interpret the key influencing factors. The study identifies seven stakeholder groups that play essential roles in facilitating or hindering the CE transition. Findings reveal that the most influential drivers are environmental factors, particularly global regulations and certification schemes, which push the industry to adopt circular practices. In contrast, the most significant barriers are political, including the lack of coherent government support and insufficient incentive programs targeted at the textile sector. Technological and economic constraints, such as inadequate recycling infrastructure and high production costs, also present notable challenges. By focusing on stakeholder perspectives, the study highlights the external dimensions shaping CE adoption and provides practical implications across the five STEEP dimensions. The insights contribute to a better understanding of how stakeholder dynamics influence systemic transformation and offer a framework for identifying roles, challenges, and opportunities within the circular ecosystem of Thailand’s TFI.

title: Drone-Enhanced Last-Mile Medical Delivery in Rural Areas: A Weather-Aware Optimization Approach

detail.title: Drone-Enhanced Last-Mile Medical Delivery in Rural Areas: A Weather-Aware Optimization Approach
detail.abstract: Rural communities face persistent challenges in accessing timely and reliable medical supply delivery due to infrastructure limitations and dispersed populations. This study presents a weather-aware, multi-modal optimization framework that integrates drones and ground vehicles to enhance last-mile healthcare logistics. The model accounts for vehicle routing, depot and facility siting, time-sensitive delivery, transshipment, and recharging decisions under operational and environmental constraints. Drone energy consumption is estimated using a dynamic model that incorporates local weather conditions and temporal variations. We develop multiple case study instances based on real-world data from rural Southern Illinois and evaluate the model’s performance across various delivery configurations, including ground-only, drone-only, and hybrid networks. Results show that drone-only configurations reduce costs by up to 47% in low-volume, dispersed settings. In high-volume cases—defined by dense demand clusters and larger total order weights—hybrid solutions significantly improve delivery efficiency, cutting average delivery time by more than 50% while preserving operational feasibility. Compared to simplified range-based models commonly used in the literature, the proposed approach more accurately captures energy demands and enables better-informed routing decisions—offering a robust platform for navigating trade-offs between cost, timeliness, and network complexity in rural healthcare logistics.

title: An Imitation Learning Framework Through Adaptive Learning Process for On-Demand Mobility Services

detail.title: An Imitation Learning Framework Through Adaptive Learning Process for On-Demand Mobility Services
detail.abstract: Travelers primarily request on-demand mobility services via platforms, introducing a distinct utilization procedure compared to traditional transportation. They go through a dynamic decision-making process: requesting service, waiting for matching, and deciding on boarding service. In addition, they lack precise trip information since services are not scheduled in advance and vary flexibly. To cope with uncertainty, users decide whether to utilize on-demand mobility services based on travel information and experience, adjusting their decision-making rules based on experience. Although these characteristics are crucial for service demand, the dynamic behaviors underlying on-demand mobility service usage have not been thoroughly explored. This study aims to develop an imitation learning framework for modeling dynamic decision-making process of on-demand mobility services. A Markov decision process is employed to represent the sequential decision-making process of on-demand mobility service users. The reward function is formulated as a linear combination of travel context attributes, aligning with a utility function. Interaction terms are introduced to capture the sensitivity varying with experience. Reinforcement learning, where agents update their decision rules based on rewards from their choices, represents travelers’ behavior. Then, inverse reinforcement learning is applied to infer reward parameters. To implement this approach, we conducted empirical research on the I-MOD service, a demand-responsive service transit operated in Yeongjong-do, Incheon, South Korea. Empirical findings revealed positive feedback on on-demand mobility services in that travelers with more experience are likely to utilize them more frequently. Moreover, rewards varying with experience can improve predictive accuracy in forecasting on-demand mobility service ridership trends.

title: Do Guns Increase Workplace Misconduct? The Impact of Guns-at-Work Laws on Federal Labor Law Violations

detail.title: Do Guns Increase Workplace Misconduct? The Impact of Guns-at-Work Laws on Federal Labor Law Violations
detail.abstract: This paper investigates the influence of workplace gun rights on workplace misconduct. Workplace gun rights legislation allows employees to bring firearms onto their employer’s premises, which has serious legal implications. Leveraging the staggered adoption of state-level Guns-at-Work (GAW) laws across U.S. states, we find that workplace gun rights legislation increases penalties by 38.67% and number of labor law violations by 4.29%. Cross-sectional tests reveal that the increase in workplace misconduct is more pronounced among firms with weaker labor union coverage, lower innovation capacity, weaker reputational incentives, poor internal governance, and limited reliance on skilled labor. Furthermore, we identify heightened workplace tension, reduction in workplace safety-related investment, and increased workload as potential mechanisms through which workplace gun rights influence workplace misconduct. Overall, the findings underscore the critical role of workplace gun legislation in exacerbating workplace misconduct.

detail.title: Sustainable Logistics, Innovation, Governance: Quantile Analysis of Economic Growth and Transport Emissions
detail.abstract: Technological innovation and human capital drive logistics performance, yet their environmental impacts remain underexplored. This study examines relationships among logistics performance, economic growth, and transport-related environmental outcomes across 65 logistics economies from 2007 to 2023. Using a macro-level panel dataset of 1,105 observations, panel unit root and cointegration tests ensure stationarity and long-run relationships. A robust econometric framework—combining Two-Step System GMM, Quantile Regression, and Two-Way Fixed Effects—addresses endogeneity, heterogeneity, and distributional asymmetries. Results show technological innovation, governance quality, urbanization, and human development significantly enhance logistics performance across quantiles, while employment and gross fixed capital formation show diminishing or adverse effects beyond thresholds. Human capital strongly drives economic growth, yet logistics performance is negatively linked to economic expansion but positively correlated with transport-related CO₂ emissions, reflecting carbon-intensive supply chains. Findings highlight the urgent need for low-carbon technologies, green infrastructure, and sustainable logistics strategies to align efficiency with environmental goals.

title: Bounded Fuzzy Logic Control for Optimal Scheduling of Green Hydrogen Production Andrevenue Maximisation
affiliations: Independent researcher

detail.title: Bounded Fuzzy Logic Control for Optimal Scheduling of Green Hydrogen Production Andrevenue Maximisation
detail.abstract: Hydrogen Purchase Agreements (HPAs) guarantee revenue streams that mitigate the financial risks inherent in the long-term production of green hydrogen from renewable energy sources. However, the intermittency of renewable electricity and the availability of parallel revenue opportunities in both the electricity and hydrogen markets complicate the scheduling of green hydrogen production. The scheduling should maximise the total revenue from short-term sales of electricity and hydrogen against the long-term HPA delivery obligations. This challenge is addressed by developing a Bounded Fuzzy Logic Control (BFLC) which determines the daily HPA delivery target based on day-ahead forecasts of electricity and hydrogen prices, as well as wind capacity factors. Subsequently, the daily target is imposed as a constraint in dispatch optimisation which allocates energy and hydrogen flows for each hour of the day. Revenue comparisons over several years demonstrate that the BFLC achieves total annual revenues within 9% of optimal revenues that are based on perfect foresight. The BFLC revenues consistently exceed those of steady control, with the largest differences observed under conditions of elevated price levels and variability. The BFLC provides an effective long-term scheduling of green hydrogen production, enabling realistic revenue quantification that mitigates economic risks without overlooking economically viable projects.

title: Dual Layer Collaborative Optimization Configuration of Adn Considering Vehicle-to-Grid and Electric Vehicle
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Tianjin University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Dual Layer Collaborative Optimization Configuration of Adn Considering Vehicle-to-Grid and Electric Vehicle
detail.abstract: Advances in vehicle-to-grid (V2G) technology have enabled electric vehicles (EVs) to contribute to both distributed power consumption and new opportunities for active distribution network (ADN) optimization. However, the large-scale integration of EVs currently poses a threat to grid stability and complicates load balancing. Therefore, it is crucial to strategically plan EV charging stations and achieve a coordinated configuration with distributed power devices. This paper proposes a two-layer optimization model for ADN that incorporates V2G and EV considerations. The upper layer of the model determines the optimal siting and capacity planning for each device through the collaborative planning of EV charging stations and other devices, while the lower layer accounts for the temporal and spatial scheduling characteristics of EVs in V2G and schedules the flexible resources within the ADN. The model's validity is demonstrated through an example, indicating a potential reduction in investment costs by 2.8%, a decrease in total operating costs of the ADN by 10.5%, and a reduction in the wind curtailment rate by 1.2% and the solar power curtailment rate by 2.8%.

title: Adaptive Energy Management Strategy for Fuel Cell Electric Vehicles Trained Separately Based on Different Driving States
affiliations: Shanghai University of Electric Power, Shanghai University of Electric Power, Shanghai University of Electric Power and Shanghai University of Electric Power

detail.title: Adaptive Energy Management Strategy for Fuel Cell Electric Vehicles Trained Separately Based on Different Driving States
detail.abstract: This study proposes an adaptive energy management strategy (EMS) based on deep reinforcement learning for multi-objective optimization problems in energy management of fuel cell hybrid electric vehicles (FCHEVs). This strategy aims to reduce hydrogen consumption, stabilize the state of charge (SOC) of the battery, and delay the degradation of fuel cell performance. A multi-objective reward function integrating three performance indicators is constructed, and the Deep Q-Network (DQN) algorithm is improved based on this. The EDQN5 algorithm is constructed by integrating mechanisms such as priority experience replay, dueling network, multi-step learning, target network, and noise network. To enhance the generalization ability of the strategy under variable operating conditions, a driving condition partitioning method based on SMk-means is further proposed. Based on the partitioning results, reinforcement learning agents are trained for each condition to form corresponding sub strategies. At the same time, a driving pattern recognizer integrating the dung beetle optimization algorithm (DBO) and backpropagation neural network (BPNN) is constructed, and a sliding window mechanism is introduced to enhance the robustness and real-time performance of online recognition. The verification results indicate that the "driving condition hierarchical training plus strategy adaptive switching" control framework, which dynamically switches sub strategies based on online recognition results, has been finally implemented, effectively improving the energy management performance of FCHEV in complex driving environments, and showing significant advantages in both economy and stability.

title: Moving from Description to Explanation - Explaining Consumers’ Preference for Bio-Based Plastics Like Pef by Extending the Theory of Planned Behavior
affiliations: Otto-von-Guericke University

detail.title: Moving from Description to Explanation - Explaining Consumers’ Preference for Bio-Based Plastics Like Pef by Extending the Theory of Planned Behavior
detail.abstract: Global plastic production relies heavily on fossil feedstocks, contributing significantly to CO₂ emissions. Bio-based plastics like PEF offer a promising alternative that could help reduce this environmental impact. For bio-based plastics to achieve widespread adoption, they must be accepted and purchased (i.e., preferred) by consumers. Although several conceptual frameworks have been proposed to explain consumers’ preferences for bioplastics – drawing on a substantial body of prior research from marketing/ economic and environmental psychology – it is important to note that earlier empirical findings have been integrated primarily in a descriptive manner. As a result, the assumed relationships of the determinants within these frameworks have not yet been empirically tested – neither in terms of their structural composition nor with regard to quantifying their influence on consumers’ preferences for bioplastics. The present study aimed to take a first step toward developing a comprehensive psychological model to explain consumers’ preferences for bio-based PEF. In March 2025, an online survey was conducted with a sample of the German consumers (N = 566). Drawing on insights from previous research in the bioplastics domain and well-established environmental psychological theories, we investigated how participants’ PEF-related beliefs and their attitude towards PEF as well as their personal and subjective norms, perceived behavioral control, and habits for sustainable consumption influenced participants’ (hypothetical) PEF purchase decisions. Taken together, the findings of this study offer a broad range of implications for both practical interventions and future research aimed at further understanding the determinants of consumer preferences for bio-based plastics.

title: Shaping Evolution of Structural Holes: From the View of Both Broker and Alters' Experience
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Shaping Evolution of Structural Holes: From the View of Both Broker and Alters' Experience
detail.abstract: While structural holes have demonstrated significant value across multiple levels and domains, their fragility has sparked dynamic research into their formation, stability, and closure. Although existing research has highlighted the importance of experience in broker's ability to extract brokerage benefits, how experience influences the evolution of structural holes remains unclear, particularly in contexts where structural holes terminate through closure or disintermediation. Drawing on organizational learning theory and social network theory, we categorize experience into cognitive and non-cognitive dimensions to examine how individual experiences of both broker and alters, along with their interactions, shape structural hole evolution.We tested our hypotheses in the context of joint patent applications among 41 major Chinese research organizations between 1996 and 2020, encompassing 36,338 patent applications. Our findings reveal that while individual cognitive experiences of both broker and alters contribute to structural hole closure or inhibit disintermediation, their interaction paradoxically facilitates structural hole evolution toward disintermediation. Conversely, non-cognitive experiences, both independently and interactively, consistently inhibit disintermediation. Furthermore, our examination of disintermediation's impact on both parties' outputs reveals that disintermediation suppresses broker's innovative output while enhancing alters'. These results illuminate the distinctly different operational mechanisms of cognitive versus non-cognitive experiences in structural hole evolution, as well as the differential outcomes of disintermediation on both parties' innovative outputs.This study advances our understanding of network dynamics in organizational innovation and offers significant implications for R&D management strategy.

title: Environmental, Economic, and Social Implications of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles for Last-Mile Delivery
affiliations: Zhejiang University, Zhejiang University, Zhejiang University and Zhejiang University

detail.title: Environmental, Economic, and Social Implications of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles for Last-Mile Delivery
detail.abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are technically appealing for last-mile parcel delivery, but its sustainability remains underexamined. Here we assess the life cycle environmental, economic and social performance of three last-mile parcel delivery modes, namely BAU (parcels are delivered by an electric vehicle and a courier), UAV (parcels are delivered by UAVs), and CO (parcels are delivered by UAVs and electric vehicle), based on Monte Carlo simulations using real-world settings from a representative community. The results indicate that CO is the least favorable mode from the environmental perspective but is the best from the economic and social aspects. Our factorial analysis demonstrates that polymer lithium batteries reduce carbon emissions by 24.71% compared to lithium-ion batteries but cost 7.6 times more. We also observe that UAV generates lower carbon emissions in detached houses or for small parcels (0.10-1.99 kg and 0.0002-0.0199 m3) deliveries. Furthermore, we offer implications to guide research and practices.

title: The Role of Monitoring and Evaluation in the Performance of Community Development Projects: A Study of the Fadama Initiative
affiliations: Institute of Management and Technology (IMT), Enugu, UNN Business School, Central Bank of Nigeria, UNN Business School and Central Bank of Nigeria

detail.title: The Role of Monitoring and Evaluation in the Performance of Community Development Projects: A Study of the Fadama Initiative

declarations.declarationOfInterest: No personal or financial relationship
declarations.ethicsApproval: Ethical guidelines were closely followed during the whole data gathering procedure for this investigation. Institutional gatekeepers and pertinent authorities gave their approval for the research to be carried out in Enugu State under the Fadama project framework. Before any data was gathered, participants were made aware of the study's objectives, parameters, and voluntary nature. All respondents gave their informed permission after being informed of their ability to withdraw at any time without incurring penalties. To ensure confidentiality, all data were anonymized, and responses were used solely for academic purposes. Sensitive information was handled with care, and no identifying details were disclosed in the final report. The study also complied with standard ethical research guidelines, including the principles of respect for persons, beneficence, and justice.
declarations.funderStatement: Self

detail.abstract: This study examined the role of monitoring and evaluation (M&E) in the performance of community development projects, using the Fadama initiative in Enugu State, Nigeria, as a case study. The objectives were to assess the alignment of current M&E practices with global best practices, determine the influence of M&E on project outcomes, particularly food security, and identify strategies to improve M&E systems for enhanced project performance. A survey research design was adopted, and data were collected from a sample of 225 respondents drawn from a population of 1,085 Fadama projects using purposive and stratified random sampling techniques. Primary data were gathered through structured questionnaires, analyzed using descriptive statistics, and tested with regression analysis via SPSS version 25. Findings revealed that while existing M&E practices are consistent with global standards, their effectiveness is limited by financial, technical, and logistical constraints. Furthermore, M&E practices significantly impact key project outcomes, such as agricultural productivity, income generation, and food security. The study also identified strategic approaches for strengthening M&E systems, including improved funding, capacity development, stakeholder engagement, and the adoption of modern data management tools. The research concludes that M&E plays a vital role in the success of Fadama Community Development Projects. However, the study's geographic focus on Enugu State limits the generalizability of the findings. It recommends that Fadama project coordinators institutionalize global best practices, invest in M&E capacity building, prioritize outcome-based assessments, and enhance transparency to ensure more effective and sustainable development interventions.

title: A Stability-Driven Framework for Long-Term Hourly Electricity Demand Forecasting
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) - Center for Energy and Environmental Policy Research (CEEPR) and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: A Stability-Driven Framework for Long-Term Hourly Electricity Demand Forecasting
detail.abstract: Long-term electricity demand forecasting is necessary for grid and operations planning, as well as for the analysis and planning of energy transition strategies. However, accurate long-term load forecasting with high temporal resolution remains a challenge as most existing approaches focus on aggregated forecasts, which require accurate prediction of many other variables as bottom-up sectoral forecasts are developed and aggregated. In this study, we propose a parsimonious methodology that uses t-tests to verify load stability and the correlation of load with gross domestic product (GDP) to arrive at a long-term hourly load forecast. Applying this method to Singapore's electricity demand, analysis of multi-year historical data (2004-2022) reveals that its relative hourly load has remained statistically stable, with an overall percentage deviation of 4.24% across seasonality indices. Utilizing these stability findings, five-year-ahead total yearly forecasts were generated using gross domestic product (GDP) as a predictor, and the hourly loads were then forecasted using hourly seasonality index fractions. The maximum Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) across multiple experiments of six years ahead forecasts was only 6.87%. We then further apply the methodology to Belgium (an OECD country) and Bulgaria (a non-OECD country), to arrive at MAPE values of 6.81% and 5.64%, respectively. Additionally, stability results were incorporated into a short-term forecasting model based on exponential smoothing, demonstrating comparable or improved accuracy relative to existing machine learning-based methods. The findings show that parsimonious approaches can be effective in arriving at long-term, high resolution forecasts.

title: Identification of Key Links in China's Electric Vehicle Industrial Chain Under External Risks:A Multi-Layer Network Synchronization Approach
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Identification of Key Links in China's Electric Vehicle Industrial Chain Under External Risks:A Multi-Layer Network Synchronization Approach
detail.abstract: This paper considers the external impacts on industrial chains caused by risk factors, taking an analytical framework that integrates structural and behavioral characteristics, key links for promoting industrial chain operations and shock resistance are identified based on the theory of multi-layer time-delay network synchronization. The industrial chain is deconstructed from the perspectives of production linkage and R&D linkage, and a multi-layer network structure model of the industrial chain is constructed by complex network theory. The impacts of external risks on production activities, R&D activities, and collaborative activities are abstracted as intra-layer time delays (across industries within a layer) and inter-layer time delays (within industries across layers) in the multi-layer network of the industrial chain. Based on this, a multi-layer time-delay network dynamics model of the industrial chain is developed by integrating structural and behavioral characteristics. Taking the auxiliary system method, the synchronization criteria for the multi-layer time-delay network of the industrial chain are analyzed to explore the time-delay thresholds under the conditions of intra-layer and inter-layer time delays. By integrating the control strategy with heuristic search algorithms, the problem of identifying key links is transformed into a pinning node search problem. Taking China’s new energy vehicle industrial chain as a case study, key links in its multi-layer time-delay network under different external risk scenarios are identified.

title: Kyndryl Technologies: A Textbook Example of Stock Selection Using the Potential Payback Period (PPP) Methodology
affiliations: International Management School Geneva (IMSG)

detail.title: Kyndryl Technologies: A Textbook Example of Stock Selection Using the Potential Payback Period (PPP) Methodology
detail.abstract: This article applies the Potential Payback Period (PPP) valuation methodology and its derived metrics-Stock Internal Rate of Return (SIRR), Stock Price Appreciation Rate of Return (SPARR), Stock Internal Rate of Return Including Price Appreciation (SIRRIPA), and Stock Risk Premium (SRP)-to assess the long-term attractiveness of Kyndryl Technologies. This company displays a compelling profile of future profitability and price appreciation relative to its valuation and risk. In contrast, the S&P 500 index appears fairly valued with a risk premium close to zero. The study highlights how the PPP framework can offer a comprehensive, time-based, and risk-adjusted tool for stock selection that extends and corrects the traditional P/E ratio.

title: Exploring the Demand for External Technologies: The Roles of Appropriability and Absorptive Capacity
affiliations: University of Pennsylvania - Management Department and Cornell University

detail.title: Exploring the Demand for External Technologies: The Roles of Appropriability and Absorptive Capacity
detail.abstract: Prior research on markets for technology has largely focused on the supply side (technology originators). In contrast, we examine the demand side by evaluating firm-technology variants of two established theories: (1) an appropriation-based view, where firms license to capture value from innovation, and (2) an absorptive capacity (AC)-based view, where firms license to recognize and commercialize external knowledge. We assemble a novel dataset of patent licenses disclosed by public firms, and all firms that cited the patents are at risk of licensing. We find that firms with both high general AC and technology-specific AC are more likely to license, even though high technology-specific AC alone predicts lower licensing. This suggests a contingent complementarity view of AC, which helps reconcile conflicting perspectives in the literature.

title: Artificial Intelligence and Inventory Performance: An Exploratory Investigation
affiliations: University of Tennessee, Knoxville - Haslam College of Business, University of Tennessee, Knoxville - Haslam College of Business, University of Tennessee, Knoxville - Haslam College of Business and University of Tennessee, Knoxville - Haslam College of Business

detail.title: Artificial Intelligence and Inventory Performance: An Exploratory Investigation
detail.abstract: Problem definition: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has transformed many facets of modern business. At its core, machine learning promises more accurate demand forecasting under uncertainty. However, it remains unclear whether AI actually leads to better inventory performance in practice. In this paper, we explore the impact of AI from an operations management perspective: Does AI really improve inventory performance? Methodology/Results: We adopt a data-driven approach by integrating firm-level AI job posting data with Compustat. We develop a novel human-capital-based metric that quantifies AI investment in supply chain specifically and examine the impact of AI investment on inventory performance in U.S. retail and wholesale sectors. Our regression results with fixed effects and Difference-in Differences show a significant negative relationship between recruitment of supply chain human capital equipped with AI skills and relative inventory levels, with effects intensifying over time. Interestingly, we observe heterogeneous effects: pure online players benefit less from AI investment than traditional and multichannel retailers and wholesalers. In addition, firms with higher operational complexity experience larger decreases in inventory levels. Conversely, high labor intensity hinders the effectiveness of AI investment and adversely impacts inventory performance. Managerial Implications: We provide empirical evidence that AI investment improves inventory performance, especially when combined with supply chain expertise. Managers should consider: prioritize "algorithm bilinguals"-professionals blending AI skills with domain knowledge-over overall AI human capital, account for a payoff lag, tailor AI investment to their specific operational contexts to optimize AI-driven reductions in inventory levels.

title: Qcraft Autoscheduler: A Library for Maximizing Qubit Utilization on Qpus Through Quantum Circuit Multiprogramming
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Extremadura, University of Extremadura and University of Extremadura

detail.title: Qcraft Autoscheduler: A Library for Maximizing Qubit Utilization on Qpus Through Quantum Circuit Multiprogramming
detail.abstract: Quantum computing is emerging as a technology with the potential to solve complex problems in areas such as optimization, cryptography, and simulation beyond the capabilities of classical computers. Cloud-based quantum platforms have made quantum hardware accessible to researchers and developers worldwide. However, current usage models still face important limitations. Despite growing demand, quantum computers often remain under-utilized, as tasks are executed sequentially, blocking all available qubits regardless of their actual usage. This leads to long queue times, high execution costs, and inefficient resource utilization. To address these problems, the following paper presents QCRAFT AutoScheduler, a Python-based programming library that optimizes the use of Quantum Processing Units (QPUs). The proposed library automatically multiprograms a quantum circuit with multiple copies of itself until it reaches or approaches the maximum capacity of the processor. By multiprogramming circuits, the approach reduces idle qubits, reducing execution costs, and reducing the number of required shots. To demonstrate these advantages, QCRAFT AutoScheduler has been validated on different real quantum computers provided by IBM Quantum and Amazon Braket. The obtained results showcase demonstrate the effectiveness of this tool to improve resource utilization in quantum computing, obtaining an average shot reduction of 85% and 96% in AWS and IBM executions respectively.

title: Hybrid Telecentric Laser Vision Measurement for Multi-Scale Geometric Error Evaluation of Aircraft Engine Shaft
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Hybrid Telecentric Laser Vision Measurement for Multi-Scale Geometric Error Evaluation of Aircraft Engine Shaft
detail.abstract: The increasingly stringent operational requirements for aero-engine rotary shafts demand ever-higher geometric accuracy. Traditional contact metrology methods, such as coordinate measuring machines, face limitations in throughput and measurement fidelity due to prolonged inspection cycles and probe-induced deformations. Existing optical techniques further struggle to reconcile multi-scale measurement conflicts spanning submicron-scale surface roughness to meter-level axial dimensions. This study presents a vertical shaft digital measurement system integrating telecentric imaging, laser micrometrology, and adaptive machine vision algorithms. The system employs a multi-sensor fusion architecture to achieve synchronized quantification of over 10 categories encompassing more than 200 geometric parameters through single clamping. Key innovations include a telecentric imaging module with affine transformation-based image stitching for distortion-free axial measurements across 1,300 mm, laser micrometry enabling dynamic radial error detection at high sampling rates, and a hybrid edge detection algorithm robust to partial feature occlusion. Experimental validation demonstrated a 15-minute measurement cycle with 0.8 μm radial repeatability and ±1.5 μm axial accuracy. Compared to the German Schneider WMM 1000 shaft measurement system, the presented system achieves similar accuracy while significantly reducing the measurement cycle time.

title: Biodiversity Risk Management: Role of Digital Transformation

detail.title: Biodiversity Risk Management: Role of Digital Transformation

detail.abstract: This study examines the impact of corporate digital transformation on biodiversity risk using data from 4,932 listed Chinese firms between 2007 and 2023. Empirical results show that digital transformation significantly reduces biodiversity risk through mechanisms such as enhanced total factor productivity and dynamic capabilities. Heterogeneity analysis reveals stronger effects in high-pollution industries, low-carbon pilot cities, mature or regenerative resource-dependent cities, and the regions of the Yangtze River Economic Belt. Financial implications indicate that digital transformation improves the financial stability of firms with high biodiversity risk, although this effect diminishes over time. These results provide important insights for governments and firms on how to manage biodiversity risk effectively.

title: Behind the Silver Screen: Leveraging Large Language Models for Pre-Release Forecasting and Release Scheduling
affiliations: The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen - School of Management and Economics, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen and The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen - School of Management and Economics

detail.title: Behind the Silver Screen: Leveraging Large Language Models for Pre-Release Forecasting and Release Scheduling
detail.abstract: Problem definition: Accurate pre-release forecasting of box-office performance is essential for strategic decision-making in movie industry, as it can offer significant implications for release scheduling and marketing investment. While traditional machine learning models can offer predictive tools, they often struggle to process unstructured textual metadata, such as plot, cast, and genre. Moreover, these models rarely account for the competitive dynamics that affect film performance at launch. To address these limitations, we propose a novel prediction framework powered by large language models (LLMs), specifically GPT-4o, which enables context-aware predictions using only pre-release information. Methodology/results: We develop an LLM-based prediction framework that directly processes textual metadata through advanced prompt engineering techniques-Chain-of-Thought and Tree-of-Thoughtto structure the model's reasoning process. The prompts guide the model to consider both intrinsic film attributes and the competitive landscape at the time of release. Using a dataset of 1,585 films released in China between 2012 and 2019, we show that the LLM-based framework consistently outperforms machine learning benchmarks in predictive accuracy. We also perform robustness checks to evaluate the framework on 2024 releases, which fall outside GPT-4o's pretraining window, and to conduct repeated trials with different prompting strategies. All results showcase the framework's generalizability and reproducibility. Furthermore, we leverage the framework to simulate alternative release timings for a subset of underperformed films in a counterfactual analysis. We find that the strategic scheduling identified by the framework could increase box-office revenue for individual film as well as the whole market. Managerial implications: Our results highlight the potential of LLMs as both predictive tools and decision support systems in movie industry, especially for smaller studios seeking to avoid direct competition with blockbusters. The proposed framework offers a practical, low-barrier solution for producers, distributors, and marketers to evaluate release strategies and forecast performance, without requiring technical expertise. By simulating alternative release scenarios, practitioners can identify strategic release timing that substantially enhance box-office performance.

title: Frozen Accidents and Emergent Orders: A Complexity Journey through the Foundations of Mathematics
affiliations: Lyciar

detail.title: Frozen Accidents and Emergent Orders: A Complexity Journey through the Foundations of Mathematics
detail.abstract: This essay reexamines the foundations of mathematics through the lens of complexity science, proposing that many of our most fundamental constructs-such as zero, one, orthogonality, and the binary-are not eternal truths but frozen accidents: historically contingent choices that became entrenched through utility, not necessity. Tracing a conceptual timeline from ancient arithmetic and Euclidean geometry through Cartesian frames, calculus, and modern logic, the essay demonstrates how each mathematical epoch was shaped by philosophical, political, and technological conditions. It culminates in the emergence of quantum logic and the qubit, where contradiction is no longer avoided but embraced. Throughout, the essay argues for a shift in perspective: from viewing foundations as fixed to recognising them as emergent, adaptive, and contextdependent. By integrating historical insight with the dynamics of complex systems, the essay opens a path towards a mathematics that is more reflective of the entangled, evolving world it seeks to describe.

title: Identity, Friction, and Professional Codes of Conduct
affiliations: James Cook University - College of Business, Law and Governance,

detail.title: Identity, Friction, and Professional Codes of Conduct
detail.abstract: Codes of Conduct remain the primary tool through which professional associations regulate member behaviour and signal ethical standards. Yet many still operate from a compliance-era mindset that treats culturally or politically sensitive speech as inherently risky, particularly when expressed by individuals in visible roles. This article reconceptualises such speech as a form of governance friction, a diagnostic signal that personal identity, role expectations, and institutional values may be misaligned. Rather than defaulting to censorship or sanction, it argues that these moments offer an opportunity to enhance legitimacy through structured reflection and pluralist inclusion. Grounded in the theories of Goffman, Sen, and Breda, and supported by a two-axis governance typology, the article proposes a friction-sensitive approach to Code of Conduct reform. Four Australian frameworks are examined: the Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency's "reflection loop" model and the Law Society of New South Wales' reliance on broad reputational clauses offer contrasting regulatory logics; the National Code of Conduct for Health Care Workers exemplifies the limitations of prescriptive, compliance-based norms; and the AIATSIS Code of Ethics demonstrates best-practice design in culturally grounded governance. From these, the article derives a practical framework comprising (1) a diagnostic typology for assessing identity expression, (2) a procedural pathway prioritising deliberation over discipline, and (3) friction-sensitive drafting techniques to support legitimacy without silencing lawful expression. The resulting model equips professional associations to uphold standards, navigate cultural complexity, and build public trust in a pluralist society.

title: Research on Supply Chain Optimization Under Different Government Subsidy Strategies in the Remanufacturing-Insurance Integration System
affiliations: Hefei University of Technology, Hefei University of Technology, Hefei University of Technology, Hefei University of Technology, Hefei University of Technology and Hefei University of Technology

detail.title: Research on Supply Chain Optimization Under Different Government Subsidy Strategies in the Remanufacturing-Insurance Integration System
detail.abstract: Remanufacturing, a sustainable production mode, faces development constraints due to low market awareness and weak policy support. To boost its market, a novel model integrating insurance and remanufacturing has emerged. This paper constructs a supply chain system consisting of an Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM), a Third-Party Remanufacturer (TPR), an insurance institution, and consumers. Dynamic game models are established under three different government subsidy strategies. The analysis reveals the impacts on stakeholders’ decisions, demands, and profits, guiding subsidy policy-making. Research indicates that subsidizing the TPR and subsidizing consumers post-claim have similar effects. Subsidizing all consumers who purchase the remanufactured-part-claim insurance is more effective in expanding the market share of remanufactured parts. When both the claims ratio and consumer acceptance of remanufactured products are high, this model can bring a win-win for the government and supply chain members.

title: The Role of Grantmakers and Accounting Information in the Private Foundation Grantmaking Process
affiliations: Mississippi State University - School of Accountancy, University of Alabama - Culverhouse School of Accountancy and University of Montana

detail.title: The Role of Grantmakers and Accounting Information in the Private Foundation Grantmaking Process

declarations.ethicsApproval: IRB approval for this study was obtained from each of the authors’ institutions.

detail.abstract: U.S. private foundations distribute over $100 billion annually, but their grantmaking process has been described as a “black box” (Diaz 1999; Jung 2016). We interview grantmakers from 20 large private foundations to understand how they use accounting and other information in their evaluation of nonprofits’ grant applications and usage. Using a utility function of nonprofit workers’ behavior, we uncover the tension grantmakers feel between best serving the interests of their foundation’s board and their nonprofit grantees. We find that grantmakers often use nonprofits’ readily available accounting information in sophisticated ways for their grant decision-making, rather than requiring burdensome reports, such as audits, as a condition for grant funding. Our findings have implications for nonprofits seeking funding and foundations wishing to develop best practices for grantmaking. Further, our finding that foundation grantmakers use different information in their decision-making than individual donors has implications for nonprofit researchers, managers, and regulators.

title: Analysing Coronial Inquests into Mining: A Systems Thinking Approach
affiliations: Queensland University of Technology, School of Psychology and Counseling and Queensland University of Technology

detail.title: Analysing Coronial Inquests into Mining: A Systems Thinking Approach
detail.abstract: The mining sector consistently ranks among the industries with the highest fatality rates globally, largely due to the frequent exposure of workers to high-risk environments as part of their job. The current body of research into mining fatalities has heavily focused on the direct cause of the incident causing death, with recommendations focusing on controlling human error and updating technology. This perspective fails to consider the indirect risk factors that may contribute to the fatality from different levels of the mining system. This study proposes the application of systems thinking models and methods to gain a deeper understanding of the complex safety dynamics within the mining industry. The study adopts a systems thinking framework to (1) map the contributory factors identified in publicly available coronial inquests that are associated with the levels of the mining system and (2) identify the relationships between contributory factors to inform recommendations addressing systemic issues. A qualitative template analysis was conducted on 17 coronial inquests from a state in Australia. A systems thinking incident review taxonomy was applied to categorise contributory factors, resulting in the identification of 89 distinct factors and 173 relationships across the system. As predicted, the majority of contributory factors were identified at the level of frontline staff and other operational personnel. This study recommends guidance for employers on interpreting the standards and guidelines that govern the industry, with the goal of protecting both contracted and non-contracted staff.

title: The Humanitarian Relief Supply Chain: Analysis of the 2004 South East Asia Earthquake and Tsunami
affiliations: Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) - Center for Transportation & Logistics

detail.title: The Humanitarian Relief Supply Chain: Analysis of the 2004 South East Asia Earthquake and Tsunami
detail.abstract: Humanitarian relief supply chains are not well documented. This thesis describes humanitarian relief supply chains in general and those specifically utilized in the 2004 South East Asia Earthquake and Tsunami relief effort. A survey, created in collaboration with the Fritz Institute and KPMG, informed the analysis and establishes baseline data for a sector with little formal measurement. It was found that relief organizations share common problems regardless of size, focus, or structure. While the survey determined that relief delivery was effective, the findings illuminated deficiencies in the following areas: initial assessment, collaboration, trained logistics experts, and supply chain analysis. Finally, the thesis suggests plans to address these issues and future research.

title: School Strategies in Stimulating Student Motivation to Participate in Competitions at SD Negeri Larangan Tokol 1 Pamekasan
affiliations: Islamic University of Madura (UIM) and Islamic University of Madura (UIM)

detail.title: School Strategies in Stimulating Student Motivation to Participate in Competitions at SD Negeri Larangan Tokol 1 Pamekasan
detail.abstract: Student motivation in academic competitions remains a critical challenge in elementary education, particularly in rural Indonesian schools where limited resources create complex educational dynamics. This research examines strategic approaches implemented by SD Negeri Larangan Tokol 1 Pamekasan to enhance student motivation for participating in academic competitions. The study employed a qualitative descriptive approach, utilizing in-depth interviews with educators and administrators, systematic classroom observations, and comprehensive document analysis to gather empirical data. Data collection involved structured interviews with teachers and principals, direct observation of motivational activities, and analysis of school policies and competition records. The findings reveal that the school implements a multi-faceted strategy encompassing personalized approaches by homeroom teachers, systematic talent mapping and identification, provision of adequate supporting facilities, implementation of recognition and reward systems, and intensive mentoring programs tailored to individual student needs. The effectiveness of these strategies is enhanced through collaborative efforts among educators, regular evaluation mechanisms, and adaptive program modifications. Key influencing factors include institutional policies supporting competition participation, individual student interests and abilities, parental support and engagement, and community involvement in educational activities. The research demonstrates that these comprehensive strategies have successfully increased student participation rates in various competitions by 40% and improved overall academic performance, with students showing enhanced confidence and stronger motivation for lifelong learning. The study concludes that integrated motivational strategies when implemented systematically with stakeholder collaboration, create sustainable improvements in student engagement and academic achievement.

title: On the Existence of Pairwise Stable Networks for Games Without Ordered Preferences
affiliations: Shanxi Normal University and Shanxi Normal University

detail.title: On the Existence of Pairwise Stable Networks for Games Without Ordered Preferences
detail.abstract: Network formation games involve noncooperative behaviors among all agents and cooperative behaviors between any two agents. The widely used pairwise stable network was introduced by Jackson and Wolinsky. In this study, we introduce a general network formation game without ordered preferences. By giving preferences to integrate noncooperative and cooperative behaviors, the existence of pairwise stable networks for the game is proven by employing equilibrium problems, which can deduce an existence result with pseudocontinuous utilities. Furthermore, under this general game framework, the existence of a strong (proper, unweighted) pairwise stable network is also established.

title: The Debt Ceiling's Disruptive Impact: Evidence from Many Markets
affiliations: Washington University in St. Louis and Olin Business School, Washington University in St. Louis

detail.title: The Debt Ceiling's Disruptive Impact: Evidence from Many Markets

publicationDetails.journalName: Chicago Booth: Fama-Miller Working Paper Series

detail.abstract: We show that the debt ceiling significantly impacts the duration of government liabilities through an unintended interaction between Treasury issuance rules and the debt ceiling constraint. During debt ceiling episodes, the Treasury allows more bills to mature than it issues. In recent years, this force has induced fluctuations in bill supply greater than one percent of GDP. We exploit this to construct an instrument for bill supply and show that the debt ceiling distorts convenience premia and the pricing of investment-grade corporate credit. We attribute the Treasury’s implicit decision to lengthen the duration of its liabilities to an intermediation constraint.

title: The Impact of Regional Identity on Hiring Chances: An Experiment Examining Employer Bias
affiliations: Ghent University, Ghent University, Ghent University and Ghent University

detail.title: The Impact of Regional Identity on Hiring Chances: An Experiment Examining Employer Bias
detail.abstract: Regional mobility is crucial for addressing labour shortages, as jobseekers from one region may fill vacancies in another region with few local candidates. However, this requires a willingness amongst employers to consider candidates from across regional borders. This study examines the influence of regional identity on hiring decisions in the Belgian labour market, focusing on perceptions of Flemish recruiters towards Flemish and Walloon candidates. Through a state-of-the-art vignette experiment, genuine Flemish recruiters evaluated fictitious resumes of school leavers that signalled regional identity through their name, place of birth, residential address, secondary school location, and/or language proficiency. Walloon candidates consistently score lower on key hiring metrics. Structural equation modelling reveals that Flemish employers hold negative perceptions of Walloon candidates, particularly regarding availability, interpersonal competency, attitude, and willingness of employers, employees, and clients to cooperate with them. These findings highlight the persistent role of regional identity stereotypes in reinforcing labour market inequalities and impeding mobility as a strategy to mitigate labour market tightness.

title: Words Matter: Central Bank Communication and Household Expectations in a Global Panel
affiliations: Vienna School of International Studies and Stanford University

detail.title: Words Matter: Central Bank Communication and Household Expectations in a Global Panel
detail.abstract: This paper studies how the linguistic features of central bank communication affect household economic sentiment. Linking central bank speeches from 29 countries to individual-level data from the Gallup World Poll (2006-2023), we examine whether speech complexity-captured through sentiment, tone, length, and readability-is associated with public perceptions of the economy and labor market. We find that longer and more syntactically complex speeches are consistently linked to lower economic confidence and less favorable views of the job climate. Positive sentiment in modal (i.e., policy-relevant) sentences is associated with more optimistic household outlooks. These effects are stronger among younger and college-educated respondents, suggesting differential processing of complex information. These findings underscore the importance of clarity and tone in central bank messaging and support the view that communication is a key behavioral channel of monetary policy transmission.

title: Strategies for Harmonizing Fragmented AI Ethics Frameworks, Standards, and Regulations
affiliations: Purdue University

detail.title: Strategies for Harmonizing Fragmented AI Ethics Frameworks, Standards, and Regulations

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no conflicts of interest.

detail.abstract: AI governance is increasingly shaped by a patchwork of ethical frameworks, standards, and regulations, with overlapping demands from technical standards bodies, industry consortia, and governments. A key piece of this puzzle is standardization: as regulators increasingly delegate governance to standards development organizations (SDOs) in response to rapid AI innovation, hundreds of potentially overlapping standards proliferate, creating redundancy, organizational confusion, and superficial compliance, while audits and certifications struggle to meaningfully assess adherence. Drawing on an analysis of over 500 AI standards across multiple domains and issuing bodies, this chapter diagnoses five interrelated challenges complicating AI governance: the persistent difficulty of translating contested sociotechnical concepts like fairness, well-being, and transparency into actionable standards; the proliferation of voluntary frameworks with limited enforceability and vague operational guidance; decision paralysis as organizations confront competing and overlapping standards; standards development cycles that lag behind fastmoving AI innovation; and geopolitical competition that fragments international coordination. To address these challenges, the chapter offers a detailed set of institutional design strategies, grounded in current governance practice, for both harmonizing-and humanizing-AI governance. These include fostering deeper coordination among SDOs, supporting satisficing and layered framework adoption tailored to organizational capacity, establishing living standards and rapid-response taskforces to enable adaptive updates, strengthening auditing ecosystems through independent accreditation, transparency, and public reporting, and embedding stakeholder participation directly into governance workflows and organizational implementation processes. Crucially, AI governance must itself be human-centered, designed to be legible, adaptable, and actionable for the real humans responsible for implementing, auditing, and overseeing AI systems.

title: A Dynamic Strategic Plan for the Transition to a Clean Bus Fleet Using Multi-Stage Stochastic Programming
affiliations: Sabanci University, Sabanci University and Sabanci University

detail.title: A Dynamic Strategic Plan for the Transition to a Clean Bus Fleet Using Multi-Stage Stochastic Programming
detail.abstract: In recent years, the transition to clean bus fleets has accelerated. Although this transition might bring environmental and economic benefits, it requires a long-term strategic plan due to the large investment costs involved. This paper proposes a multi-stage stochastic program to optimize strategic plans for the clean bus fleet transition that explicitly considers the uncertainty scenarios in the cost and efficiency improvements of clean buses. Our optimization model minimizes the total expected cost subject to emission targets, budget restrictions and several other operational considerations. We propose a new forecasting approach that captures the correlation between these improvements to obtain realistic future pathways for Battery Electric Buses (BEBs) and Hydrogen Fuel Cell Buses (HFCBs), which are then given to the multi-stage stochastic program as scenarios. We also utilize a physics-based model for BEBs to accurately capture their energy consumption and recharging needs. As a case study, we focus on the complex public bus network of Istanbul, which aims to transition to a clean bus fleet by 2050. Utilizing real datasets, we solve a five-stage stochastic program spanning a 25-year planning horizon that involves 256 scenarios to obtain dynamic strategic plans that can be used by the policy makers. Our results suggest that BEBs are more advantageous than HFCBs, even in slow BEB but fast HFCB development scenarios. We also conduct several sensitivity analyses to understand the effects of the intermediate emission targets, budget limitations and energy prices.

title: Scalable Prediction  Of Crop Bbch Stages Using Sentinel-2 Plant Phenology Index and Machine Learning
affiliations: TU Wien, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Scalable Prediction  Of Crop Bbch Stages Using Sentinel-2 Plant Phenology Index and Machine Learning
detail.abstract: Accurately predicting the phenology of crops in a timely  manner is essential to estimate the effects of management practices, climate and environmental variability on agricultural  systems. This paper presents a lightweight, low-data consuming method to predict growth stages of crops, using Sentinel-2 satellite data and machine learning.  By addressing nine BBCH  stages (from  germination,  BBCH  0 to harvest, BBCH100), we predict phenological events at the base of the Plant Phenology Index (PPI)  and recorded crop type data without  direct measurement of meteorological and high-resolution auxiliary  data.We trained two regression models, LightGBM and Random Forest, on a total  of over 450 ground-truth observations from the PEP725 phenology network in Lower Austria.  With  lightGBM, we attained R2  scores over 0.994 and the mean absolute errors (MAE) between 2.09 and 2.99 days, RMSEs between 3.41 and4.91 days.  Random Forest models outperformed, with  R2   consistently above 0.999 and MAEs  as low as0.20–0.38 days. The prediction performance remained robust even with a 50% data reduction, underscoring the model’s scalability and generalizability.Our results show that  a minimal,  globally available input  set allows for accurate, nearly real-time phe- nology prediction.  In particular  in data-sparse or resource-limited settings, this method enables new oppor- tunities for operational crop monitoring,  yield forecasting, and phenological modeling.

title: Algeria, Africa's Gateway: A Strategic Infrastructure Vision for Continental Integration (Enhanced with Econometric Modeling, Hydrological Simulations & Comparative Benchmarking)
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Algeria, Africa's Gateway: A Strategic Infrastructure Vision for Continental Integration (Enhanced with Econometric Modeling, Hydrological Simulations & Comparative Benchmarking)
detail.abstract: This study explores Algeria's transformative potential to become a strategic hub for continental integration between North Africa and the Sub-Saharan region. It proposes a multi-sectoral infrastructure vision, anchored by a deep-water port in Djen Djen, a trans-Saharan corridor integrating railways, highways, and a water transfer canal, supported by extensive investments in agriculture, energy, and air transport. Through a detailed cost-benefit analysis, spatial economic assessment, and a comprehensive risk evaluation, the paper investigates how this ambitious mega-project can generate regional economic synergies, enhance logistical connectivity, and serve as a catalyst for African unity and sustainable development. The project is estimated to create over 3.5 million direct jobs during the construction phase, and approximately 150,000 direct permanent jobs, along with 600,000 to 750,000 indirect and induced jobs after construction and full operation. The study also addresses its technical feasibility, proposed governance framework, and overarching socioeconomic impacts, including significant benefits for neighboring African nations.

title: Labor Market Penalty for Single Mothers
affiliations: The University of Manchester - Institute for Development Policy and Management, Indian Institute of Management Calcutta and Indian Institute of Management Calcutta

detail.title: Labor Market Penalty for Single Mothers
detail.abstract: Single mothers, a growing global demographic, face unique labor market challenges, yet their outcomes remain understudied compared to the well-documented motherhood penalty. On the one hand, fewer opportunities for household specialization might facilitate their labor force participation. Conversely, they face the same constraints with respect to childcare as married mothers. While aggregate data suggests that single mothers' labor market participation rates are usually higher than those of unmarried women, we argue that this realized labor market equilibrium masks potential demand-side discrimination. To study this, we conduct a correspondence study experiment that involves applying for real jobs using fictitious resumes. We show that equally qualified single mothers are much less likely to receive interview callbacks than unmarried women without children, married without children, and married mothers. For every interview callback, a single mother has to apply to about 30 jobs, whereas an unmarried woman receives more than two callbacks for as many job applications. The callback probability for single mothers is 0.034 p.p. lower in low-DEI (diversity, equity, and inclusion) firms and 0.048 p.p. lower in high-DEI firms. A key mechanism, the relocation cost channel, where callback differentials are more pronounced for jobs farther from applicants’ home locations, suggests statistical discrimination, which is further corroborated by a vignette study.
