title: A Dynamic Perspective on Biosimilar Competition
affiliations: European University Institute - Department of Law (LAW)

detail.title: A Dynamic Perspective on Biosimilar Competition

publicationDetails.detailsText: IIC - International Review of Intellectual Property and Competition Law (forthcoming)

detail.abstract: The upcoming biopharmaceutical patent cliff is expected to set the stage for a largescale market entry with biosimilars over the next decade. Unlike generic producers, their developers may be incentivized to compete on more than just price. The technological and commercial peculiarities of biosimilars suggest that they can be a source of innovation, stemming from advances in drug delivery and manufacturing processes. Although these advances fit the definition of incremental innovation, they may produce disruptive effects in niche market segments, thus blurring the line between incremental and disruptive innovation. In addition, the freedom to operate in biosimilar R&D is a key condition enabling manufacturers of biosimilars to potentially expand their business models into the originator segment of the industry and puts originator producers under pressure to innovate preemptively. These innovation-related benefits highlight the importance of identifying a workable antitrust framework for assessing the effects of business strategies that may interfere with pipeline biosimilars. To that end, the article proposes applying the concept of potential competition in existing markets-previously applied to small-molecule markets-to the biopharmaceutical segment. It then discusses several open questions on this adaptation. These include, in particular, the extent to which small market size and regulatory exclusivities may rule out a competitive relationship between incumbents and biosimilar developers; the timeframe for assessing potential biosimilar competition; the features at company level that indicate the capability for a successful biosimilar entry; and the relevant market in which an innovative biosimilar would compete upon commercialization.

title: A Resolution to the Post-Split Volatility Puzzle
affiliations: Rice University - Jesse H. Jones Graduate School of Business, Rice University - Jesse H. Jones Graduate School of Business and CUNY Lehman College

detail.title: A Resolution to the Post-Split Volatility Puzzle
detail.abstract: The abnormal change in volatility following stock splits remains one of the most puzzling anomalies in the asset pricing literature. This paper provides a resolution to this phenomenon by demonstrating that, when volatility is measured using returns that are less susceptible to trading frictions, there is no evidence of abnormal post-split volatility changes over the 1926-2023 period. We validate these results by showing that when volatility is estimated from returns that are sensitive to market microstructure factors, the abnormal changes in volatility become economically small and noisy after controlling for such factors. Overall, our evidence indicates that the post-split volatility effect stems from trading frictions rather than from behavioral biases.

title: Rise of the Titans: How Israel and India are Reshaping the World Order
affiliations: O P Jindal Global University

detail.title: Rise of the Titans: How Israel and India are Reshaping the World Order
detail.abstract:
Rise of the Titans: How Israel and India Are Reshaping the World Order examines the evolving roles of Israel and India as assertive middle powers within a multipolar global system. Through a comparative foreign policy analysis, the book explores how these states utilize strategic alliances, technological innovation, and economic diplomacy to enhance their global influence and autonomy.

Employing the theoretical lenses of realism, liberalism, and constructivism, the study analyzes Israel’s defense-driven strategy and regional normalization—particularly through the Abraham Accords—and India’s multilateral engagement in forums such as the G20 and QUAD. It also highlights the growing strategic partnership between the two countries in fields like defense, agriculture, and high technology.

This work offers a conceptual framework for understanding how middle powers operate within complex geopolitical structures and influence global governance. It provides original insights into the agency of non-Western powers in reshaping the post-unipolar order toward greater balance and multipolarity.

title: Murder in the Marketplace
affiliations: University of Liverpool, Old Dominion University - Economics and Bocconi University

detail.title: Murder in the Marketplace
detail.abstract: Violence is often viewed as an intrinsic feature of illicit markets, driven by competition, disputes, and predation. We argue that the connection between violence and markets is not exclusive to illicit markets and that in the absence of strong institutions these factors exist ubiquitously. Using an estimator of spatial concentration, we document the empirical relationship between violence and markets in the 14th century. We then employ a large language model to analyze the coroner’s accounts of the era’s homicides, finding that many of these incidents were driven by avoidable escalations of business-related disputes. Employing a novel difference-in-differences estimator for spatial concentration, we proceed to causally identify the impacts of the introduction of London’s first professional police force in the 19th century on this concentration. We find that the police force’s introduction led to a 54% reduction in the degree of concentration of violence around marketplaces. Our findings suggest that it is not the nature of the commodities being sold in illicit markets that drives violence, but is rather the absence of formal institutions of enforcement and dispute resolution.

title: On the Relevance of the Purchasing Power Hypothesis as a Determinant of Exchange Rate Equilibrium in the Post WWI French Franc Floating Exchange Rate Period
affiliations: DISEI University of Florence and University of Rome Tor Vergata

detail.title: On the Relevance of the Purchasing Power Hypothesis as a Determinant of Exchange Rate Equilibrium in the Post WWI French Franc Floating Exchange Rate Period
detail.abstract: The French franc variability of the 1920-1926-time interval is often attributed to irrational speculation. A common view is that French investors, disregarding fundamentals, were prone to export their funds in response to adverse financial/political news, destabilizing in this way the exchange rate. Our analysis, based on a new dataset, qualifies these results. The estimates of a Markov-switching Heterogeneous Agents Model strongly support the hypothesis that informed speculators relied on the relative purchasing power parity paradigm and drove the short run exchange rate dynamics, bandwagon effects being but short lived. In line with previous analyses the impact of additional explanatory variables, real and financial, turns out to be rather limited.

title: When Workers Don't Know Their Contract: Evidence from French Working Time Regulations
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: When Workers Don't Know Their Contract: Evidence from French Working Time Regulations
detail.abstract: This paper examines workers’ awareness of their contractual working time arrangements and its consequences for labor market outcomes. Combining administrative and survey data at the individual level, we construct a new and unique data set which shows that 20% of the workforce mistakenly think that they work under day contracts, with no monitoring of hours, while they are actually paid through a standard hours contract. This reveals that many workers with various profiles do not know the legal environment governing something as fundamental as their working time. We show that these “ignorant” workers differ from classic workers in terms of working conditions: they perform more unpaid overtime hours but have a higher wage rate per contractual hour, so that their total compensation is similar. Complementary results on job satisfaction also suggest that firms do not take advantage of their workers’ ignorance of labor contracts to extract rents. Rather, “ignorant” workers appear to benefit from an intermediate status between standard hours contracts and day contracts with more flexibility. Leveraging the panel dimension of our data, we further show that these workers are more likely to sign actual day contracts over time, but with smaller effects on their earnings’ trajectories.

title: Government Onchain Open Data (GOOD) Project Report
affiliations: University of San Francisco - School of Law and University of San Francisco - School of Law

detail.title: Government Onchain Open Data (GOOD) Project Report
detail.abstract:
Government agencies spend millions annually on fragmented, expensive cloud storage while struggling to provide transparent, accessible public data. Current solutions create vendor lock-in and require technical expertise that most civic organizations don't possess.

The Government Onchain Open Data (GOOD) Project proposes to create the first user-friendly platform enabling any civic technologist or government employee to upload public datasets to Filecoin's decentralized network with simple dragand-drop functionality—no blockchain expertise required.

GOOD provides a living repository where data updates automatically while preserving immutable historical versions, supporting both real-time government operations and permanent public accountability.

Our technical evaluation of Filecoin storage solutions demonstrates that decentralized storage can reduce government storage costs while eliminating vendor dependencies. However, adoption requires accessible tools—the critical gap our platform addresses. A platform must enable, for example, a city clerk to preserve budget documents without understanding blockchain mechanics.

title: The Forgotten Women : Gendered Violence and Legal Impunity in India's Conflict Zones
affiliations: University of Calcutta

detail.title: The Forgotten Women : Gendered Violence and Legal Impunity in India's Conflict Zones
detail.abstract: This article explores the gendered impact of conflict in India's militarized regions, with a focus on Kashmir. It highlights how protracted violence, enforced disappearances, and armed presence disproportionately affect women-particularly those known as "halfwidows," whose husbands are missing but not legally declared dead. These women face compounded legal, social, and economic hardships due to the lack of formal recognition and support. Despite religious rulings permitting remarriage, stigma and legal ambiguity persist. It critically examines state inaction, the absence of a structured legal framework, and the discovery of mass graves as markers of systemic failure. It argues that current mechanisms fall short of addressing the needs of women in conflict, and calls for gender-sensitive legal reforms, psychological support, and institutional accountability. The study urges the integration of women's voices and rights into conflict resolution, ensuring dignity, recognition, and justice in both legal and humanitarian terms.

detail.abstract: Exchange rate volatility is influenced by both domestic and foreign asymmetric shocks in addition to conventional macroeconomic fundamentals. This study examines the disparate impacts on the INR-USD currency rate in the post-COVID era (2020-2024) of the volatility of the world oil price, interest rate decisions made by the US Federal Reserve, and India-specific economic indicators (such as inflation and trade deficit). The study, which uses a Threshold Vector Auto Regression (TVAR) model, finds that the Indian Rupee responds more strongly to abrupt increases in US interest rates and negative shocks to the oil price than it does to comparable positive occurrences. The results highlight the necessity of scenario-based, flexible monetary solutions for currency risk management.

title: A General Approach to Multistability Analysis for Fuzzy Multidimensional-Valued Nns with Memristor
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, China University of Mining & Technology, Zhengzhou University of Light Industry and University of Technology Sydney (UTS) - University of technology sydney

detail.title: A General Approach to Multistability Analysis for Fuzzy Multidimensional-Valued Nns with Memristor
detail.abstract: This article addresses a general approach to the multistability analysis for fuzzy multidimensional-valued memristive neural networks(FMVMNNs) with unbounded time-varying delays. By integrating fuzzy logic with memristive dynamics, establishing a generalized analytical approach encompassing real, complex, and quaternion systems. Through general analysis, via statespace decomposition based on the Brouwer fixed point theorem, several sufficient criteria are obtained to ensure the existence of QJM,K=R,IQni=1(2S iM + 1) equilibrium points(EPs), among which QJM,K=R,IQni=1(S iM + 1) are shown to be locally asymptotically stable, where S iM are nonnegative integers and the set M depends on the number field. These criteria are less restrictive and easier to verify. This paper further estimate the basins of attraction corresponding to stable equilibria. Finally, the theoretical results are supported by two simulated numerical examples.

title: Quantifying and Valorizing Unavoidable Food Waste: A Global Assessment Across Food Groups and Regional Pathways
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Leiden University

detail.title: Quantifying and Valorizing Unavoidable Food Waste: A Global Assessment Across Food Groups and Regional Pathways
detail.abstract: Unavoidable food waste (UFW) represents inedible by-products such as husks, peels, bones, and shells. It embodies a significant flow with varying degree of utilization across the global food system. Leveraging the FOWCUS mass balance database and global food production and trade data, this study presents a high-resolution global quantification of UFW generated from post-harvest to consumption stages in 2022, offering one of the most detailed accounts to date. We found that 5.7 Gtons of UFW was generated across 199 countries. By estimating its release upstream and at consumption stage and modelling current waste management practices across regions and food groups, we find that 90% of UFW is released before it reaches consumers, and that almost half of UFW is not valorized, representing a significant loss of potential resources. We identify key regional differences in UFW availability and its current treatment. We highlight these untapped opportunities for more advanced valorization across regions, including bioethanol, biochemicals, and bio-adsorbents, aligned with feedstock availability. The findings support more nuanced, regionally adapted approaches to waste management and bioresource policy, emphasizing UFW as a stable feedstock for circular bioeconomy strategies.

title: Strategic Disclosure to Combat Copycats
affiliations: University of International Business and Economics (UIBE), Renmin University of China and Renmin University of China - School of Finance

detail.title: Strategic Disclosure to Combat Copycats
detail.abstract: We hypothesize that mutual funds strategically report their holdings to combat copycats. Using the unique hybrid disclosure setting in China, we find that the average past returns of top-10 holdings are significantly lower than those of non-top-10 holdings. This suggests that mutual funds may hide the real money-making holdings underneath and move slightly under performing stocks to the top before disclosure, then reverse engineer. This effect is stronger for funds with better past performance, lower turnover rate and weaker tendency of window dressing. Furthermore, these funds are associated with lower copycat probability and superior performance in the future.

title: China’s e-CNY and the Future of Money: A Rewiring Global Finance, Technology, Policy, and Geopolitics
affiliations: Sri Lanka Institute of Information Technology

detail.title: China’s e-CNY and the Future of Money: A Rewiring Global Finance, Technology, Policy, and Geopolitics
detail.abstract: This paper provides a comprehensive overview of China's central bank digital currency (CBDC), the e-CNY, highlighting its development trajectory, technical architecture, and strategic objectives. Initiated by the People's Bank of China (PBoC) in 2014, the e-CNY integrates centralized control with distributed ledger technologies to create a secure, efficient, and inclusive digital currency system. The study examines the legal and regulatory frameworks underpinning the e-CNY, its implications for monetary policy and financial stability, and its potential role in advancing the internationalization of the renminbi within a multi-polar global currency system. Additionally, the paper discusses critical challenges facing the e-CNY's implementation, including legal ambiguities, public adoption barriers, financial system risks, data privacy concerns, and cross-border regulatory complexities. The findings underscore that while the e-CNY represents a significant innovation in digital finance, its successful large-scale deployment depends on addressing multifaceted operational, legal, and geopolitical issues.

title: Valuation of Mangrove Forest Management in Ghana: Using Discrete Choice Experiments
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Cape Coast and Nha Trang University

detail.title: Valuation of Mangrove Forest Management in Ghana: Using Discrete Choice Experiments
detail.abstract: The degradation of mangrove forests threatens the critical ecosystem services vital to human well-being and coastal ecosystems. This study used the discrete choice experiment to elicit marginal willingness-to-pay (MWTP) and marginal willingness-to-work (MWTW) of coastal communities for mangrove forest management in Ghana. The attributes assessed include fish stock, biodiversity, shoreline erosion protection, and the size of the mangrove area restored. We employed the random parameter logit (RPL) model because it addresses the problem of independence of irrelevant alternatives (IIA), no random taste variation, and no correlation in unobserved factors and uses the results to estimate the MWTP and MWTW. The findings showed a positive and significant MWTP and MWTW of the attributes associated with mangrove forest management. Households preferred a high level of fish stock and shoreline erosion protection to a moderate level. They also prefer the size of the mangrove area restored and biodiversity at a moderate level. We argue that these non-market values and preferences of households should be incorporated into the decision-making process to ensure effective mangrove forest restoration and conservation in Ghana.

detail.title: Using did multiplegt dyn in Stata to Estimate Event-Study Effects in Complex Designs: Four Examples Based on Real Datasets
detail.abstract: This document provides examples where the Stata command did multiplegt dyn, which computes the estimators proposed in De Chaisemartin and d’Haultfoeuille (2024), is used on real datasets to estimate event-study effects in complex designs. The first example has a binary treatment that can turn on an off. The second example has a continuous absorbing treatment. The third example has a discrete multivalued treatment that can increase or decrease multiple times over time. The fourth example has two, binary and absorbing treatments, where the second treatment always happens after the first.

title: How Varian Wiped out Half of Economics: Supply
affiliations: Chienkuo Technology University - Department of International Business

detail.title: How Varian Wiped out Half of Economics: Supply
detail.abstract: Varian defined supply as the negative of demand, or the remainder of capacity (or endowment) from demand. For example, labor supply is the negative of leisure demand. If his theory were correct, economists would no longer need to study any supply theory, and half of the Economics syllabus could be removed. This paper proves that Varian's supply is nothing but the mirrored image of a demand.

title: Education of Children with Disabilities (CWD) in Nepal: An Overlooked Issue
affiliations: Kathmandu University

detail.title: Education of Children with Disabilities (CWD) in Nepal: An Overlooked Issue
detail.abstract: This work is an effort to explore the actual situation of children with disabilities in the education system through empirical data. The paper also tries to uncover the perceptions of various stakeholders towards children with disability. Especially the views and narratives of the children, parents and teachers are analyzed to come up with recommendations to improve the conditions of inclusion and access to school education for children with disabilities. The findings of the study are depicted in three sections; the Institutional Arrangements and Policies section deals with the discussion about policies and institutions working in the field of inclusion and welfare of CWD. Similarly, the Perceptions section presents the views of various stakeholders, especially parents, teachers and students with the help of secondary sources like previous research reports. Finally, the Demography section presents the empirical data and synthesis of evidence from various sources like the Census 2021 and Flash I report 2021. The percentage of children with disability in school education was below 1% which indicates the limited access of CWD to education and thus other opportunities. Flash I Report of 2021 issued by CEHRD (2022) presents the number of CWD to be 0.24% of total enrolments in schools, which is 17,219 children with disabilities out of 70,95,435 total children enrolled. The facts derived from Census data and the Flash I report of 2021 clearly show the disparity. Only around 15% of total children with disabilities were enrolled in schools in 2021.

title: Analytic Optimal Income Taxation
affiliations: University at Albany, SUNY - Department of Economics

detail.title: Analytic Optimal Income Taxation
detail.abstract: The paper uses the Euler Lagrange Equation to determine analytic optimal income tax functions for a utilitarian social welfare function with quasi-linear utility functions. The tax attains optimality by balancing income and substitution effects so that individual labor supply is the same for all individuals who work. Individuals can avoid taxation by choosing not to participate in the labor market when their utility would be greater by not working. With this option, the analytic optimal tax incorporates the conditions of the least productive individuals through determination of the extensive margin. Numerical solutions depend on two parameters determined by tax revenue and labor participation constraints. The solutions, with marginal tax rate beginning below zero and monotonically increasing, provide counterexamples to generalizations of published results on optimal income taxation based on alternative assumptions.

title: Notes on Stochastic Dominance
affiliations: The University of Texas and University of Texas at Austin - Department of Information, Risk and Operations Management

detail.title: Notes on Stochastic Dominance
detail.abstract: This paper explores the concept of stochastic dominance, a critical tool in decision-making under uncertainty, particularly in economics and finance. Building on foundational work by Friedman and Savage (1948), and subsequent formalizations by Hadar and Russell (1969), the study delves into first-order (FSD), second-order (SSD), and third-order stochastic dominance (TSD). Using integration by parts, the paper provides simple proofs for these dominance theorems, connecting them to utility and distribution functions. Practical examples from financial markets illustrate the relevance of stochastic dominance in portfolio selection and risk assessment. The analysis highlights the progression from risk aversion in SSD to prudence and sensitivity to skewness in TSD, offering insights into the preferences of decision-makers under varying conditions of uncertainty.

title: The Governance Configurations of High Firm Environmental Performance Under External Audit and Political Green Pressures
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and RMIT University Vietnam

detail.title: The Governance Configurations of High Firm Environmental Performance Under External Audit and Political Green Pressures
detail.abstract: We address the lack of research on the interdependent relationships among governance mechanisms and their associations with firm environmental performance. We argue that internal and external governance mechanisms interact complexly such that they cluster together as configurations associated with high environmental performance. To examine these governance configurations, we perform fuzzy-set qualitative comparative analysis (fsQCA) with a sample of 3,215 firm-year observations of S&P500 firms over a 20-year period (2003-2022). Our research highlights that firms employ either stringent or flexible internal governance, characterizing two distinct ways that agency and resource-based mechanisms come together to result in environmental performance. In line with institutional theory, we also find that external mechanisms including external sustainability audit and political context (i.e., Republican- or Democratic-learning states) influence the firm’s choices of internal governance configurations. When firms are not monitored by external audit nor experiencing pressures from the political context, we identify that high environmentally performing firms are those that employ stringent governance. Our work implies external audit and political context as key contextual conditions specifying when agency and resource dependence theory become salient in informing the linkage between governance and environmental performance. We also discuss the implications of our study to governance practices.

title: Can Fiscal Transfers Achieve Both Equity and Efficiency：Evidence from Chinese Counties
affiliations: Guangzhou Medical University and Guangzhou Medical University

detail.title: Can Fiscal Transfers Achieve Both Equity and Efficiency：Evidence from Chinese Counties
detail.abstract: Whether fiscal transfers can simultaneously achieve the dual goals of equity and growth has been a key topic of public finance research. This paper examines China's fiscal decentralization system and its intergovernmental transfer practices, proposing two conditions under which equity-oriented transfer systems may promote economic growth: The effectively motivate local officials' enthusiasm for economic development and the receiving regions' high marginal capital returns. We employ unique fiscal data from China's county-level economies for the period 2016-2021 to conduct regression analyses. The results show that provinces with more equitable distribution of transfer payments exhibit better economic growth at the county level. However, at the provincial level, there is a non-significant but noteworthy economic loss. This is attributed to the reverse incentives created by the equalization of fiscal transfers, which encourage growth in smaller counties but hinder growth in larger ones. The main mechanisms driving these reverse incentives include insufficient growth potential, distorted fiscal spending preferences, and an over-reliance on transfer payments. Our study demonstrates that, even within China’s unique fiscal system and local development incentives, the allocation of fiscal transfer funds still faces a trade-off between equity and growth. This deepens our understanding of the effectiveness of fiscal transfer systems and the logic of local fiscal operations under a multi-level fiscal governance framework.

title: Fintech and Banking Profitability: The Mediating Role of Insolvency Risk at Islamic and Conventional Banks
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, affiliation not provided to SSRN and King Abdulaziz University

detail.title: Fintech and Banking Profitability: The Mediating Role of Insolvency Risk at Islamic and Conventional Banks
detail.abstract: Emphasizing the mediating function of insolvency risk, this research analyzes the impact of Financial Technology (FinTech) on bank profitability by comparing Islamic and conventional banks. We investigate how FinTech influences Return on Assets (ROA) and Net Interest Margin (NIM) using a dynamic panel generalized method of moments (GMM) approach, employing a three-stage mediation framework with data from the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) nations. FinTech lowers short-term profitability due to high investment costs, but it improves risk management, thereby somewhat compensating for this impact and increasing long-term stability. FinTech presents additional major hurdles for Islamic banks, which reduces their return on assets (ROA). For Islamic banks, nevertheless, focused IT expenditures improve NIM and ROA. Our results highlight the complex interplay between FinTech, risk, and profitability, underscoring the need for strategic IT investments, particularly for Islamic banks.

title: An Argument For Housing Reparations
affiliations: Columbia University - Department of Sociology

detail.title: An Argument For Housing Reparations

publicationDetails.detailsText: Maine Law Review, Volume 77, No. 2 (2025), Pp. 243-297

detail.abstract: This Article explores recent applications and framing of municipal reparatory housing policies and assesses equal protection challenges, including specific discussion of an emerging case in Evanston, Illinois. Because of recent changes to the Supreme Court's approach to applying strict scrutiny in equal protection challenges of race-conscious policies as reflected in Students for Fair Admissions v. Harvard, race-based applications of reparations have been criticized as dead on arrival. However, this Article finds that housing-related reparatory policies are dissimilar from affirmative action admissions policies in several ways relevant to the Court's application of strict scrutiny. Housing reparations policies are more in line with historical reparations policies that have withstood strict scrutiny, and they thus represent one comparatively promising avenue through which reparations may yet be achieved. Finally, this Article anchors these findings in possible applications of reparatory policy orientations in housing, connecting existing failures and challenges in housing policy with the myriad possibilities of a reparatory policy orientation.

title: An Adaptive Subinterval Univariate Dimension Reduction Method for Uncertain Problems with Large Interval Parameters
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: An Adaptive Subinterval Univariate Dimension Reduction Method for Uncertain Problems with Large Interval Parameters
detail.abstract: An adaptive subinterval univariate dimension reduction method is proposed to solve uncertain problems with large interval parameters. The subintervals are obtained by the adaptive iterative algorithm and sensitivity analysis. The univariate dimension reduction method is used to predict the upper and lower response bounds in each subinterval, which can improve both the accuracy of the response bounds and the convergence speed of subinterval iterations. Three examples are used to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in terms of computational cost and error.

title: Banking on Renewables: How Finance Powers the Green Energy Boom
affiliations: Columbia University and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Banking on Renewables: How Finance Powers the Green Energy Boom
detail.abstract: This paper examines the role of private bank financing in driving the expansion of non-conventional renewable energy, with a focus on solar and wind power. Using granular banking data of an emerging market, we find that bank credit has a greater impact on energy production for green energy firms, especially smaller ones, compared to conventional producers. This implies a higher return per dollar of credit for clean energy. While green energy firms face higher initial financing costs, these converge with conventional producers over time. Lower default rates among green energy firms suggest that banks improve credit assessments over time. We also find positive spillovers to other sectors: after a green plant is installed in a county, non-energy firms located in that county experience reduced financing costs and default rates.

title: Empowering Women in the UK: Exploring the Role of Financial Access and Digital Literacy in Driving Business Growth
affiliations: Robert Gordon University, Robert Gordon University and Intellinavix Limited,

detail.title: Empowering Women in the UK: Exploring the Role of Financial Access and Digital Literacy in Driving Business Growth
detail.abstract: This study examines the impact of financial access and digital literacy on the growth of womenled businesses in the United Kingdom, employing a qualitative content analysis of secondary sources. Despite increased participation in entrepreneurship, women continue to face significant barriers to accessing capital and leveraging digital tools. Findings reveal that financial access is critical for business start-ups and scale-up, yet persistent gender disparities remain. In 2024, women-founded businesses secured only 5.8% of total investments, with female entrepreneurs receiving just 1.8% (£145 million) of the £8 billion in equity investment, while male-led ventures obtained 86% (£6.92 billion). Additionally, the average loan for women-led businesses was £174,000, significantly lower than the £507,000 allocated to maleled enterprises. Barriers to financial access include restrictive institutional financing, gender bias in investment decisions, and inadequate financial inclusion policies. Similarly, digital literacy challenges stem from limited education, lack of mentorship programs, and structural barriers to adopting digital business models. The study integrates Resource-Based Theory, Pecking Order Theory, and Network Affiliation Theory to analyse these challenges and proposes solutions. The study recommendations include institutional financing reforms, enhanced female participation in financial decision-making, and increased involvement of women in developing digital financial tools to foster a more inclusive and sustainable entrepreneurial ecosystem.

title: Leveraging Intellectual Property Rights for Entrepreneurial Success: A Case Study of NutriHer under the EIPR Framework
affiliations: Rashtreeya Vidyalaya College of Engineering (RVCE), Rashtreeya Vidyalaya College of Engineering (RVCE) and Rashtreeya Vidyalaya College of Engineering (RVCE)

detail.title: Leveraging Intellectual Property Rights for Entrepreneurial Success: A Case Study of NutriHer under the EIPR Framework

declarations.declarationOfInterest: None
declarations.funderStatement: None

detail.abstract: In today's knowledge-driven economy, entrepreneurship is increasingly shaped by the ability to innovate and protect those innovations. Intellectual Property Rights (IPR) serve as critical tools for safeguarding ideas, promoting innovation, and enhancing competitive advantage. This paper investigates the strategic role of IPR in startup growth through the lens of the Entrepreneurship and Intellectual Property Rights (EIPR) framework, using NutriHer, a healthtech startup specializing in personalized herbal nutrition, as a case study. The research maps IPR tools to different stages of the entrepreneurial lifecycle, examines common challenges faced by startups in adopting IPR, and proposes policy interventions. The study finds that startups like NutriHer gain significant leverage when intellectual property is integrated early into business planning. Findings also highlight key gaps in awareness, access, and enforcement that hinder broader IPR adoption among entrepreneurs. The paper concludes by underscoring the strategic value of IPR in the entrepreneurial ecosystem and advocating for targeted educational and policy initiatives to support innovation-led ventures.

title: Financial Development, Competition, and Productivity
affiliations: The University of Sydney

detail.title: Financial Development, Competition, and Productivity

declarations.funderStatement: N/A

detail.abstract: I study how financial development promotes competition. I extend the model of Atkeson and Burstein (2008) to include dynamic capital accumulation and financial frictions. Capital market imperfections interact with endogenous misallocation from market power and variable markups. Calibrating the model with data from Chilean manufacturing firms, I show that improved access to external finance reduces industry concentration and both the level and dispersion of markups. These effects explain over half of the total productivity gains from financial development and are especially pronounced in financially underdeveloped economies. Models that ignore markup variation thus underestimate the benefits of improving capital markets.

title: Electricity Market Predictability: Virtues of Machine Learning and Links to the Macroeconomy
affiliations: UNSW Business School, Nanyang Technological University (NTU) and Nanyang Technical University

detail.title: Electricity Market Predictability: Virtues of Machine Learning and Links to the Macroeconomy
detail.abstract: With stakeholder-level in-market data, we conduct a comparative analysis of machine learning (ML) for forecasting electricity prices in Singapore, spanning 15 individual models and 4 ensemble approaches. Our empirical findings justify the three virtues of ML models: (1) the virtue of capturing non-linearity, (2) the complexity (Kelly et al., 2024) and (3) the l2-norm and bagging techniques in a weak factor environment (Shen and Xiu, 2024). Simulation also supports the first virtue. Penalizing prediction correlation improves ensemble performance when individual models are highly correlated. The predictability can be translated into sizable economic gains under the mean-variance framework. We also reveal significant patterns of time-series heterogeneous predictability across macro regimes: predictability is clustered in expansion, volatile market and extreme geopolitical risk periods. Our feature importance results agree with the complex dynamics of Singapore's electricity market after deregulation , yet highlight its relatively supply-driven nature with the continued presence of strong regulatory influences.

title: Equilibrium Failure Rates in Tests of Endogenous Competence
affiliations: University of Turin - Department of Economics

detail.title: Equilibrium Failure Rates in Tests of Endogenous Competence
detail.abstract: Rational individuals who obtain a premium by passing an imprecise test change their choice of costly competence when the pass threshold varies. At given premium that reaction prevents variation of the failure rate completely if the marginal cost of competence is constant, only partially if it is increasing. The offsetting effect of endogenous competence is stronger when the pass premium varies in the same direction as the threshold, as it plausibly does when in equilibrium it depends on the expected competence differential between otherwise unobservably heterogeneous individuals who pass and fail. Failure rates remain very similar as different thresholds elicit different endogenous competence and depend much more strongly on the test's precision: the outcome of a frequently failed test must be very random from the point of view of those who take it.

title: Curriculum and Instructional Assessment of the Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education Major in Home Economics Program
affiliations: Cebu Technological University

detail.title: Curriculum and Instructional Assessment of the Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education Major in Home Economics Program

keywords: Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education

detail.abstract: The Bachelor of Technology and Livelihood Education (BTLE) Major in Home Economics Program is an essential academic program that provides aspiring educators with thorough knowledge and practical skills to teach home economics effectively. This overview emphasizes the vital components of the curriculum and instructional assessment that have been rigorously created to satisfy the different demands of current Home Economics learners. The research begins by illuminating the underlying ideas that support the BTLE Major in Home Economics Program, highlighting its conformity with contemporary educational standards and societal expectations. The study used purposive sampling to develop research questions, ensuring relevant and representative respondents. The questionnaire assessed program content, methods, faculty competence, and facility adequacy. The curriculum framework integrates theoretical knowledge with practical experiences, preparing future educators for Home Economics, covering nutrition, textiles, family dynamics, interior design, and consumer economics. The instructional assessment within the program is characterized by a blend of formative and summative evaluation methods, allowing instructors to continuously gauge students' progress and adapt their teaching methodologies accordingly. Incorporating modern educational technologies facilitates enhanced learning experiences and promotes creative and critical thinking among students. Moreover, utilizing real-world scenarios and practical application of concepts fosters a deeper understanding of Home Economics principles and prepares students for their roles as future educators. BTLE Major in Home Economics Program promotes inclusivity and practical knowledge transmission through pedagogical methodologies, collaborative learning, and community engagement. Evaluating the program's effectiveness reveals positive student learning outcomes and overall program satisfaction. Continuous feedback and assessment mechanisms allow timely adjustments to enhance the program's quality and relevance. The study showed that the program meets CHED standards and industry needs but requires improved technology integration and practical experiences. Students satisfied, recommend hands-on experiences.

title: Sequential Large Language Model-Based Hyper-Parameter Optimization
affiliations: Middle East Technical University and Middle East Technical University

detail.title: Sequential Large Language Model-Based Hyper-Parameter Optimization
detail.abstract: This study introduces SLLMBO, an innovative framework leveraging large language models (LLMs) for hyperparameter optimization (HPO), incorporating dynamic search space adaptability, enhanced parameter space exploitation, and a novel LLM-tree-structured parzen estimator (LLM-TPE) sampler. By addressing limitations in recent fully LLM-based methods and traditional bayesian optimization (BO), SLLMBO achieves more robust optimization. This comprehensive benchmarking evaluates multiple LLMs—including GPT-3.5-Turbo, GPT-4o, Claude-Sonnet-3.5, and Gemini-1.5-Flash, extending prior work and establishing SLLMBO as the first framework to benchmark a diverse set of LLMs for HPO. By integrating LLMs’ established strengths in parameter initialization with the exploitation abilities demonstrated in this study, alongside TPE’s exploration capabilities, the LLM-TPE sampler achieves a balanced exploration-exploitation trade-off, reduces API costs, and mitigates premature early stoppings for more effective parameter searches. Across 14 tabular tasks in classification and regression, the LLM-TPE sampler outperformed fully LLM-based methods and achieved superior results over BO methods in 9 tasks. Testing early stopping in budget-constrained scenarios demonstrated competitive performance, indicating that LLM-based methods generally benefit from extended iterations for optimal results. Furthermore, by automating hyperparameter tuning with LLM-driven initialization and adaptive search space refinement, SLLMBO aligns with broader AutoML objectives. Its integration into AutoML pipelines can enhance search efficiency, reduce human intervention, and improve hyperparameter selection strategies in real-world applications. This work lays the foundation for future research exploring open-source LLMs, reproducibility of LLM results in HPO, and benchmarking SLLMBO on complex datasets, such as image classification, segmentation, and machine translation.

title: Decision Mamba Architectures for Offline Rl
affiliations: Universidade da Beira Interior and Universidade da Beira Interior

detail.title: Decision Mamba Architectures for Offline Rl
detail.abstract: Recent advancements in imitation learning have been largely fueled by the integration of sequence models, which provide a structured flow of information to effectively mimic task behaviours. Currently, Decision Transformer (DT) and subsequently, the Hierarchical Decision Transformer (HDT), presented Transformer-based approaches to learn task policies. Recently, the Mamba architecture has shown to outperform Transformers across various task domains. In this work, we introduce two novel methods, Decision Mamba (DM) and Hierarchical Decision Mamba (HDM), aimed at enhancing the performance of the Transformer models. Through extensive experimentation across diverse environments such as OpenAI Gym and D4RL, leveraging varying demonstration data sets, we demonstrate the superiority of Mamba models over their Transformer counterparts in a majority of tasks. Results show that DM outperforms other methods in most settings.

title: Data-Driven Sequential Search
affiliations: Duke University - Decision Sciences and Duke University - Decision Sciences

detail.title: Data-Driven Sequential Search
detail.abstract: How can one search effectively with limited prior knowledge on the distribution of alternative values? This paper addresses this question in the context of sequential search. In our data-driven setting, traditional methods that rely on a known value distribution no longer apply and feasible search policies are based solely on the history of explored alternative values. We seek to identify a policy that maximizes the worst-case ratio of expected reward compared to an oracle (referred to as Pandora) with full knowledge of the value distribution. We first consider a general setting where alternative values may follow any arbitrary distribution. We design simple policies that statically commit to a prespecified number of explorations. We show that these static policies guarantee a competitive ratio of at least 1/e ≈ 37% of the Pandora benchmark for any arbitrary value distribution. Our approach involves studying nature's problem to select a distribution to counter a policy and identifying worst-case distributions. Moreover, we study how the structure of the unknown value distribution influences achievable performance guarantees by considering a setting where feasible distributions belong to the class of monotone hazard rate distributions. In this case, we improve our guarantee to (e/(e+1))^2 ≈ 53% of the Pandora benchmark. In both settings, we derive performance limits for feasible policies to complement our performance guarantee results. We illustrate the efficacy of our policies through numerical examples based on price search. Our results provide insights to the decision makers with no prior knowledge of value distributions across many search applications.

title: The COVID Pandemic and Its Aftermath: Missed Opportunities for Avoiding a Future of Authoritarian Neoliberalism
affiliations: New School for Social Research

detail.title: The COVID Pandemic and Its Aftermath: Missed Opportunities for Avoiding a Future of Authoritarian Neoliberalism
detail.abstract: Neoliberalism can be characterized as an exhausted but entrenched growth regime that requires fundamental institutional transformation to create the conditions for inclusive and sustainable growth. But will existing political leadership rise to the challenge of implementing this transition? Experience during and immediately after the COVID-19 pandemic does not give cause for optimism. First, the pandemic itself could have served as a timely reminder of the need for socialized responses to shared sources of uncertainty. Second, the post-pandemic 'inflation' could have served as a timely reminder of the importance of distributive justice as a component of macroeconomic performance. The argument advanced is that both of these opportunities were missed, demonstrating a paucity of vision and leadership among center-left parties at a critical juncture for liberal democracy.

title: Fair to Fare Well: How Algorithmic Fairness Benefits Firms on a Platform?
affiliations: Tianjin University, University of Illinois, Tianjin University and University of Texas at Dallas - Naveen Jindal School of Management

detail.title: Fair to Fare Well: How Algorithmic Fairness Benefits Firms on a Platform?
detail.abstract: In this paper, we examine the impact of algorithmic fairness-through unawareness (e.g., equal treatment) or awareness (e.g., equal opportunity)-on firms that rely on platform algorithms for decision-making. Specifically, in industries such as lending and hiring, lenders and employers use platform algorithms to predict candidates' qualifications. We develop a game-theoretic model involving a platform and a firm, the platform can invest in learning to improve algorithm accuracy for better prediction of candidates' qualifications and the firm can decide which candidates to accept by setting score thresholds, whereas the candidates belong to either a regular group or a protected group that is biased against by platform algorithms. Counterintuitively, we show that algorithmic fairness, while seemingly detrimental to firms' profitability due to the constraints it imposes, can actually benefit firms. Interestingly, we find that algorithmic fairness can hurt the protected group or benefit the regular group. Our study also shows that whether equal opportunity or equal treatment outperforms in maximizing firms' profits depends on the benefit-loss ratio. When this ratio is sufficiently high, the firm has higher profits under equal opportunity; otherwise, the firm has higher profits under equal treatment. This study also provides implications for policymakers on when to allow or prohibit the use of sensitive attributes in platform algorithms.

title: From Collapse to Clean Energy How the Enron Scandal and the 2008 Financial Crisis Paved the Way for Solar Growth
affiliations: Jefferson-Lewis-Hamilton-Herkimer-Oneida BOCES

detail.title: From Collapse to Clean Energy How the Enron Scandal and the 2008 Financial Crisis Paved the Way for Solar Growth

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no financial or non-financial conflicts of interest related to this manuscript.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This article does not involve human participants, personal data collection, or animal research, and therefore does not require institutional ethics approval.
declarations.funderStatement: This research was conducted independently and received no external funding.

detail.abstract: This white paper examines how the collapse of Enron in 2001 and the 2008 financial crisis indirectly accelerated the growth of the U.S. clean energy market, with a particular focus on solar energy. Both events exposed systemic failures in corporate governance, financial transparency, and regulatory oversight. In response, reforms such as the Sarbanes-Oxley Act and post-crisis stimulus programs created a financial environment more favorable to sustainable investments. The paper explores how these shifts led to new market opportunities, with solar companies like First Solar, SolarCity, and Tesla pioneering innovative business models and financial instruments. Tools such as Yieldcos, Green Bonds, and Solar Asset-Backed Securities made solar energy an investable asset class for mainstream capital markets. The paper also draws parallels between Enron's off-balance-sheet accounting tactics and the mortgage-backed securities that fueled the 2008 crisis, highlighting the risks of unchecked financialization. Additionally, the study discusses the role of the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA) in stabilizing the clean energy sector during the Great Recession. A forward-looking analysis addresses emerging risks in ESG investing, cryptocurrency markets, and AIdriven financial systems, underscoring the need for continued vigilance. The paper concludes that financial innovation, when paired with ethical oversight and transparent regulation, can transform systemic failure into long-term sustainability gains. An appendix provides teaching and discussion materials for educators and trainers seeking to use this case study in academic or professional settings.

title: Impact of Voluntary Sustainability Standards on Decent Rural Employment: Evidence from Smallholder Coffee Farms and Cooperatives
affiliations: Addis Ababa University and Addis Ababa University

detail.title: Impact of Voluntary Sustainability Standards on Decent Rural Employment: Evidence from Smallholder Coffee Farms and Cooperatives
detail.abstract: Voluntary Sustainability Standards (VSS) are increasingly recognized and promoted as effective governance tools to advance global sustainability and resilience within agricultural value chains and food systems, in alignment with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). This study evaluates the impact of Fairtrade and Organic certification on decent rural employment in Ethiopia's smallholder coffee sector, focusing on indicators such as wages, contracts, working conditions, training, and job satisfaction. Analyzing data from 560 wage workers across six districts, we utilized Ordinary Least Squares (OLS), Two-Stage Least Squares (2SLS), and IV Probit models. Results indicate that certification improves job contracts for all workers and increases wages primarily for those in cooperatives, who also gain better access to training on gender equality and child labor prevention. In contrast, household/farm-based workers see minimal benefits due to structural barriers. While working conditions generally improve, job satisfaction rises only moderately among cooperatives, with no significant gains in social integration. A composite decent work index confirms substantial improvements for cooperative workers only, highlighting that VSS effectiveness is heavily influenced by existing organizational capacity. The findings stress the need for context-specific certification frameworks with localized enforcement and targeted training to extend decent work opportunities to marginalized agricultural laborers in developing economies.

title: Design and Implementation of an AI-based Digital Media Literacy Training Platform for English Teaching
affiliations: Lincoln University College, Students and INTI International University

detail.title: Design and Implementation of an AI-based Digital Media Literacy Training Platform for English Teaching
detail.abstract: This study presents an Artificial Intelligence (AI)-driven platform designed to enhance digital media literacy in English language education. By integrating natural language processing (NLP), deep learning, and reinforcement learning algorithms, the platform dynamically assesses users' competencies in information retrieval, critical analysis, and information integration. It employs multimodal data analysis to generate personalized training tasks and real-time feedback. Experimental results demonstrate robust performance under high concurrency, with significant improvements in users' critical thinking and information synthesis skills.

title: Task-Aware Dynamic Routing Network for Cross-Domain Few-Shot Learning
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Wuhan Institute of Technology, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Huazhong University of Science and Technology

detail.title: Task-Aware Dynamic Routing Network for Cross-Domain Few-Shot Learning
detail.abstract: Cross-domain few-shot classification (CD-FSC) aims to learn classifiers for unseen classes and domains using a small number of labeled samples, which is an extremely challenging task, and this paper conducts in-depth research around this topic. Existing methods solve this problem by incorporating learnable task-specific parameters. However, this fixed-parameter paradigm often results in suboptimal transfer performance when adapting models from source to diverse target tasks. Our research is inspired by the observation that task-specific parameter configurations exhibit strong correlations with the characteristics of target tasks. We posit that the optimal configuration of task-specific parameters is inherently task-dependent, as an excessive number of such parameters may induce model overfitting, whereas insufficient parameters can impede the model's adaptability to novel tasks. To exploit the findings, we propose a novel model termed Task-Aware dynamiC rOuting Network (TACO)for cross-domain few-shot learning. During the training phase, TACO employs reinforcement learning to dynamically adjusts the network architecture by considering the discrepancies between the target and source domains. In this way, TACO evaluates the configuration and optimizes an appropriate network configuration for a given task. Furthermore, through the integration of self-attention and knowledge distillation, the feature extraction capability is enhanced, allowing the model to represent more sophisticated visual elements. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm, we conducted experiments on eight cross-domain few-shot classification (FSC) datasets. The experimental results demonstrate that TACO outperforms existing methods in terms of average accuracy and generalization ability. Additionally, compared to state-of-the-art results on individual datasets, our approach achieves a performance improvement up to 3.03\%.

title: The African Worldview: A Principled and Civilized Vision in Contrast to the Western Aggressive Ethos
affiliations: Afrindependent Institute

detail.title: The African Worldview: A Principled and Civilized Vision in Contrast to the Western Aggressive Ethos
detail.abstract: This paper examines the foundational ethical, philosophical, and civilizational differences between the African worldview and the dominant Western worldview. Drawing on the insights of social philosopher and economist Manuel Tacanho in his paper Africonomics: A School of African Philosophical and Economic Thought, it affirms that the African worldview is intrinsically theist, principled, nonrivalrous, and nonaggressive, while the Western worldview remains shaped by materialism, racialism, rivalry, and systemic violence. This contrast—the distinctly human and principled nature of the African worldview—makes it morally and civilizationally superior to the animalistic Western worldview. The paper critiques the Western paradigm’s grounding in Darwinian evolutionary theory, Social Darwinism, and racism, highlighting the destructive impact of these ideologies on worldwide human relations within and among nations. It concludes that the African worldview, as articulated in Africonomics, offers an ethical, constructive, and civilized framework for structurally just socioeconomic order and human flourishing—one aligned with reality and grounded in the natural-moral law principles of truth, justice, and nonaggression.

title: Governing of Labor Supply in Bulgarian Farms -Modes, Factors, Post-transition Evolution
affiliations: Institute of Agricultural Economics

detail.title: Governing of Labor Supply in Bulgarian Farms -Modes, Factors, Post-transition Evolution
detail.abstract:
The goal of this article is to identify contemporary modes and factors of labor supply in Bulgarian farms. Interdisciplinary New Institutional Economics methodology is incorporated, and analysis made of new representative micro data collected from the managers of farms of different types and locations. There has been enormous development in labor supply governance in Bulgarian farms during the last two decades. Permanent employment is a major form of labor supply in farms, followed by seasonal and part-time employment. Owners and family members account for the largest share of the total workforce. Different forms are used (high recurrence of contracts with the same person, output-based compensation, use of service supply or input contracts, etc.) to reduce transaction costs of labor and overall governance of farms. The reasons for using employment contracts and the importance of different labor supply and governance modes, intensity of transactions, types of partners, and kinds of remuneration vary considerably depending on juridical type, size, specialization, and locations of holdings. The most important problems in hiring labor are the lack of labor in the labor market, the high price of hired labor, requirement to pay social payments, pay-holidays, etc., big turnover of workers, high costs for adapting official labor standards, high costs for controlling of hired labor (cheating, stealing, etc.), high costs for negotiating conditions of employment, high costs to find good workers, low qualification of hired labor, advance age of hired labor, requirement for signing a written contract, and insufficient initiatives of workers. For a significant number of Bulgarian farms, the costs of finding and managing hired labor are factors strongly restricting the development of their enterprise. The latter is particularly important for a good proportion of major commercial farms like cooperatives, physical persons, and corporations, to a lesser extent to sole traders.  Other critical factors strongly restricting development of Bulgarian farms at present stage of development are: legislation and regulation environment in the country and sector, the amount of costs for finding needed lands and natural resources, amount of costs for finding needed short-term and long-term assets, amount of costs for finding needed finance for the farms, amount of costs for finding needed innovations, amount of costs for marketing of output, amount of costs for  registration, certification, etc., existence of informal and gray sector in agriculture, and socio-economic situation in the region and in the country.

It has to be periodically used in economic analysis to support public decision making and farm management. However, the wider application of this new framework requires collection of new type of (micro) economic data and significant changes in the official (agro) statistical system in the country and EU.

title: Bridging the Gap between Education and Employability: The Role of Transformative Curriculum for Secondary Schools in South-West Nigeria and Beyond
affiliations: Bowen University, Bowen University and Bowen University

detail.title: Bridging the Gap between Education and Employability: The Role of Transformative Curriculum for Secondary Schools in South-West Nigeria and Beyond
detail.abstract: Many African secondary school graduates struggle to find paid or self-employment due to mismatch between education and labour market needs. This study explores the design of a practical, skills-based entrepreneurship curriculum to better prepare secondary school students for the realities of today’s economy. Using a mixed-methods approach, the research assesses existing entrepreneurship education through surveys, interviews, and curriculum analysis. Educators, industry experts, policymakers, and secondary school students provided insights to shape a curriculum that aligns with real-world demands. The study emphasises experiential learning, skills acquisition, digital tools, and local relevance in EE curriculum to enhance student engagement and adaptability, in order to reduce youth unemployment, encourage innovation, and position secondary schools as incubators for future business leaders. Findings highlight gaps in current programs and propose a dynamic, market-driven curriculum that fosters problem-solving, creativity, and self-reliance. The results offer actionable recommendations for policymakers and educators, towards a transformative shift in African secondary education.

title: M&A and the Rise in Industry Concentration
affiliations: Boston College, Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: M&A and the Rise in Industry Concentration
detail.abstract: This paper provides the first quantification of the contribution of mergers and acquisitions (M&A) to rising industry concentration. Using comprehensive firm-level microdata from the U.S. Economic Census, we show that M&A account for 44% of the increase in aggregate concentration. An empirical decomposition of changes in concentration that further accounts for firm entry and exit shows similar results. Classifying M&A using the numerical criteria in the merger guidelines, we show that presumed anticompetitive M&A account for 12% of the increase in aggregate concentration.

title: A Roadmap for Emissions, Cost, and Capital Renewal in Primary Steel Decarbonization
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: A Roadmap for Emissions, Cost, and Capital Renewal in Primary Steel Decarbonization
detail.abstract: This paper evaluates key decarbonization pathways for Brazil’s steel industry through 2050, focusing on the strategic roles of natural gas and biomass. Cumulative emissions over the 2025–2050 period may differ by more than 600 MtCO2 depending on the pathway chosen. Using a novel suite of integrated models, we generate consistent estimates of emissions, costs, and abatement potential for various production routes (BF-BOF, scrap-EAF, DRI-EAF) in many fuel configurations. Proper system boundary definition is shown to be crucial for a holistic assessment of the total environmental impact of steel production. Our findings show that switching to natural gas-based Direct Reduced Iron (NG-DRI) can cut emissions by approximately 50% compared to the conventional coal-based route, while also enabling stepwise asset renewal and future uptake of biomethane and green hydrogen. Charcoal also offers significant emission reduction opportunities, either in dedicated plants or substituting pulverized coal injection. However, all alternatives face considerable economic, technical, and scalability barriers, necessitating robust policy frameworks to drive the transition. We conclude that NG-DRI represents the most pragmatic bridge to a potential hydrogen-based future, highlighting the value of incremental yet scalable decarbonization strategies.

detail.title: The Development of International Law: The Case for Revisiting Compensation

publicationDetails.detailsText: Faculty of Laws University College London Law Research Paper No. 08/2025

detail.abstract: How can the development of public international law work in a decentralised and pluralist international society, where actors and institutions increasingly and deeply disagree on key questions? The paper identifies two concepts for discussing the viability of such developments: clarity, about the current law and the claim for change, and coherence of that claim with the existing law, both substantively and in relation to relevant procedures and institutions. After explaining how these concepts operate in international law more generally, the paper considers their application to the case study of compensation within the particular institutional setting of the United Nations International Law Commission.

title: Legal Analysis of RBI Circulars/Notifications on the Banking Sector and its Interpretation by Supreme Court of India
affiliations: O. P. Jindal Global University, Jindal Global Law School (JGLS) and Independent

detail.title: Legal Analysis of RBI Circulars/Notifications on the Banking Sector and its Interpretation by Supreme Court of India

keywords: Dharani Sugars and Chemicals Ltd. v. Union of India
State Bank of India v. Rajesh Agarwal
High Court of Madhya Pradesh v. Reserve Bank of India

detail.abstract:
RBI circulars, notifications, and master directions are the backbone policies of the bank’s regulatory structure. Their importance stems from multifaceted gaps that stem from fulfilled targets ranging from implementation of monetary policy and management reminders including non-performing assets (NPAs). These circulars facilitated bank mergers and acquisitions, eased foreign investment restrictions, lifted barriers on new entrants into various sectors, as well as interest rate controls.  The aims of these policies are quite broad. First and foremost, they focus on maintaining stability in the banking sector during times of market turbulence. The other objective is to improve synchronization of the Indian Banking industry with global competition standards which widens strategic expansion opportunities for both Indian Banks and their foreign journeyers.

The system is not immune to devising ineffective measures however – there exists numerous cases where issuances of circulars went unaddressed or notifications received zero attention outside their intended circles. There have been several notable instances where the Supreme Court has intervened to interpret or challenge RBI circulars, leading to significant legal and regulatory developments. One of the notable cases in this area is “State Bank of India v. Rajesh Agarwal”. This case dealt with natural justice concepts such as the ‘right to be heard’. Another important example is the case of “Dharani Sugars and Chemicals Ltd v Union of India”, where the Supreme Court voided an RBI circular instructing banks to compulsorily commence insolvency proceedings against debtors marked as one-day defaulted loans. As noted by the court, this circular resulted in overstepping predetermined limits by the Reserve Bank of India on its regulating jurisdiction and was deemed as ultra vires. “High Court of Madhya Pradesh v. RBI” is another relevant case. This case pertains to directives concerning merchant trade issued by Reserve Bank of India which were sued upon allegations of being vague as well as excessive scope for could be termed as unregulated expansion drawn over jurisdiction lacking certain borders.

The legal framework empowering the RBI to issue circulars and notifications is primarily derived from the Banking Regulation Act, 1949, and other related statutes. However, the scope and limitations of this authority are subject to judicial interpretation, as evidenced by the cases. This regulatory framework promotes trust in government procedures since it guarantees accountability and fairness. Responding to emerging realities is critical to a healthy evolutionary process, although action without thought can lead to chaos. These actions are usually influenced by social constructs which help maintain order and fairness; however, within a system devoid of borders these influences lose functionality. Without a well-structured system that preserves safety and precision these tools would transform into systems devoid of responsibility and regulation.

title: Multi-Unit Search: An Experimental Approach
affiliations: University of Queensland - School of Economics, University of Queensland - School of Economics and Universidad Adolfo Ibanez

detail.title: Multi-Unit Search: An Experimental Approach

declarations.ethicsApproval: The experiment discussed in this paper received ethical approval from UQ’s BEL LNR review panel (project number2023/HE002373).
declarations.funderStatement: Jose A. Carrasco thanks and acknowledges financial support from FONDECYT #1221816 and FONDECYT #1251698.

detail.abstract: We experimentally explore sellers' dynamic pricing strategies in a multi-unit search environment with stochastic buyer arrivals. Building on Carrasco and Smith (2017), our laboratory design examines how reservation prices adapt to inventory levels and demand distributions, as well as to deadlines. Despite theoretical predictions suggesting that higher inventory levels and imminent deadlines reduce reservation prices, our findings reveal negligible effects of both factors on pricing behavior. Our experimental results reveal unexplored dynamics in multi-unit search environments, underscoring the need for further empirical research to bridge the gap between theory and observed seller behavior.

title: Market Concentration, Capital Misallocation, and Asset Pricing
affiliations: University of Amsterdam - Amsterdam Business School

detail.title: Market Concentration, Capital Misallocation, and Asset Pricing

declarations.funderStatement: Amsterdam University Fund

detail.abstract: Superstar firms, which dominate stock markets through their large size and high markups, can distort efficient capital allocation. This paper empirically studies the asset pricing implications of superstar firms through the channel of capital misallocation, measured by the cross-sectional dispersion in the marginal product of capital (MPK). I decompose this measure into misallocation (1) among superstar firms, (2) among other firms, and (3) between these two groups. I find that only changes in the third component, termed the "MPK spread", are negatively priced in the cross-section of stock returns. Stocks with negative exposure to these changes outperform stocks with positive exposure by 4.8% per year. In the long run, a higher MPK spread predicts lower economic growth and aggregate stock returns, while in the short run, it predicts lower innovation growth. Consistent with the ICAPM framework, capital misallocation between superstar and non-superstar firms is a key state variable, and its changes capture a macroeconomic risk factor.

title: Effects of Credit and Labor Constraints on Microenterprises and the Unintended Impact of Changes in Household Endowments: Use of Threshold Estimation to detect Heterogeneity
