title: Default and Restructuring as Possible Scenarios for Settlement of Debt Problems
affiliations: State Scientific Research Institute for Informatization and Economic Modeling

detail.title: Default and Restructuring as Possible Scenarios for Settlement of Debt Problems

publicationDetails.detailsText: MODELING THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE ECONOMIC SYSTEMS, issue 1, 2023[10.31891/mdes/2023-7-3]

detail.abstract:
The spread of debt problems in Ukraine and in the world necessitates the study of possible scenarios of actions of the borrower countries. In case of loss of solvency, countries can choose two ways: the first is based on a complete rejection of their own obligations, the second consists in reaching agreements with creditors. That is why the article examines default and restructuring as two possible scenarios available to states in a difficult debt situation. The purpose of the article is to substantiate the approaches to the selection of scenarios for settling the debt problems of the debtor countries. In order to achieve the goal, it is necessary to solve the following tasks: to deepen the theoretical approaches to determining the essence, types and scenarios of default and restructuring; to investigate the experience of restructuring in Ukraine; compare the scenario of default and restructuring as possible scenarios for settling debt problems.

Available scenarios of the borrower's behavior in the market when solving debt problems should not be chosen in isolation, but should take into account a number of factors and threats to the growth of the public debt. Examples of default and restructuring that took place in the world are described. The high level of sensitivity to default, defined in the article, led to the study of the experience of the restructuring of the state debt of Ukraine in 2015. The types of default were considered and compared with restructuring in terms of the advantages and disadvantages of each according to the following criteria: change of loan status, reduction of the amount of debt, reduction of interest on the debt, change of the debt repayment term, reduction of the rating of the borrowing country, support for reforms aimed at restoring the financial stability, debt isolation of the borrowing country. The article is dominated by the idea of settling debt problems while maintaining access to the capital market and reaching agreements with creditors.

title: Women Leaders in the Strategic Positions of Pharmaceutical Companies: Overcoming Barriers and Systemic Biases
affiliations: Tshwane University of Technology

detail.title: Women Leaders in the Strategic Positions of Pharmaceutical Companies: Overcoming Barriers and Systemic Biases

declarations.declarationOfInterest: No conflict to declare.
declarations.ethicsApproval: Not applicable as this was a desktop review.
declarations.funderStatement: There is no funding for this research.

detail.abstract: The United Nations Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 5 aims to achieve gender equality and empower all women and girls, emphasising the importance of ensuring full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public. The representation of women in leadership positions serves as a measure of gender equality. Empowering women in leadership facilitates inclusive economic growth and allows organisations to have a diversified talent pool. Women continue to be significantly underrepresented in strategic leadership roles within manufacturing pharmaceutical companies (MPCs) operating in South Africa, despite ongoing efforts to promote gender equity. This study aimed to assess the presence of women in board and executive leadership positions and propose strategies to promote gender-inclusive leadership. A systematic desktop review was conducted to analyse the websites and annual reports of 49 publicly listed MPCs that were selected from the South African Pharmacy Council (SAPC) 2021 register. The data were collected on company characteristics, leadership composition, gender distribution and professional qualifications of leaders within each company. The results revealed that women comprised only 29.48% of board members and 27.36% of executive leaders, with female pharmacists representing just 28.1% of leadership positions. Statistical analysis, including Chi-square tests, confirmed a gender disparity, with men significantly more likely to occupy strategic roles. The findings highlighted barriers such as unconscious bias, exclusion from influential networks, limited mentorship and sponsorship opportunities and challenges related to work-life balance. The study concludes that addressing these disparities requires a comprehensive approach, including structured sponsorship programs, gender-inclusive leadership policies, targeted talent development initiatives and corporate accountability measures. By implementing these strategies, pharmaceutical companies can create a more equitable leadership environment for women to enhance decision-making, innovation and long-term sustainability of the pharmaceutical industry.

title: Healthcare Workers' Pay Transparency and Patient Satisfaction
affiliations: Hong Kong Polytechnic University - School of Accounting and Finance, Hong Kong Polytechnic University - School of Accounting and Finance, The University of Hong Kong - Faculty of Business and Economics and Hong Kong Polytechnic University - School of Accounting and Finance

detail.title: Healthcare Workers' Pay Transparency and Patient Satisfaction
detail.abstract: Pay transparency reduces wage information asymmetry between coworkers. By utilizing the staggered, state-level implementation of pay transparency laws in the U.S., we find that patient satisfaction is higher for hospitals in states that enact a pay transparency law than it is in states with no such legislation, consistent with the fair wage-effort theory. Within the healthcare context, this theory predicts that fairer wages for healthcare workers will incentivize them, resulting in higher-quality patient care. The positive effect of pay transparency on patient satisfaction is more significant for hospitals in Democratic states and in states where the hospital industry has a larger gender-based pay gap. The positive effect is also more evident in less profit-driven hospitals and in those that exhibit a higher labor intensity. Overall, we offer novel evidence that workers' pay transparency has a positive transmission effect on customer satisfaction.

title: Environmental-Friendly Flotation Separation of Copper and Arsenic Sulfide Minerals by Using the Combined Depressant of Polyaspartic Acid and Sodium Sulfide
affiliations: Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming University of Science and Technology, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming University of Science and Technology and Kunming University of Science and Technology

detail.title: Environmental-Friendly Flotation Separation of Copper and Arsenic Sulfide Minerals by Using the Combined Depressant of Polyaspartic Acid and Sodium Sulfide
detail.abstract: Flotation separation of chalcopyrite from copper ion-activated arsenopyrite presents significant challenges due to their surface similarity induced by copper ions adsorption. In this study, a combined depressant system comprising polyaspartic acid (PASP) and sodium sulfide (Na2S) was systematically investigated to achieve efficient separation. Micro-flotation tests, contact angle experiments, atomic force microscopy (AFM), surface adsorption analysis, Zeta potential characterization, and local electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (LEIS) were carried out to elucidate the selective inhibition mechanism. Results of the flotation tests showed that recovery of the chalcopyrite remained 94.25%, but recovery of the arsenopyrite distinctly decreased to 19.80% after the addition of depressants. Testing results of the contact angle and AFM indicated that the depressant can selectively adsorbed on the surface of arsenopyrite and increased the hydrophilicity. The results of surface adsorption amount tests and Zeta potential measurement illustrated that the depressant could greatly hinder collector adsorb on the arsenopyrite surface, but have little effect on the chalcopyrite. The results of LEIS tests presented that the component of Na2S mainly hindered the adsorption of collector and the PASP further interacted with the arsenopyrite surface, finally resulting in an improvement of hydrophilicity. A mechanistic schematic was proposed to illustrate the synergistic roles of PASP-copper ions chelation and site competition of Na2S with collector. These findings advance the fundamental theory for environmentally sustainable separation of copper-arsenic sulfide minerals.

title: Taking a Leaf Out of Their Book: Peer Influence and Corporate Risk-Taking
affiliations: City University of Hong Kong (CityU) - Department of Economics and Finance, City University of Hong Kong (CityU) - Department of Economics & Finance and Department of Finance at School of Economics (SOE),  and Wang Yanan Institute for Studies in Economics (WISE), Xiamen University

detail.title: Taking a Leaf Out of Their Book: Peer Influence and Corporate Risk-Taking
detail.abstract: This paper documents that corporate risk-taking is influenced by peer behaviors through the product-market network. Firms tend to take more risks if they observe higher risk-taking among peer companies. We further extend theoretical identification conditions of peer effects to a network model incorporating an interaction term, which is pivotal for uncovering the mechanisms of peer influence. Leveraging these advanced tools, we find that firms with less talented CEOs and poor performance are more inclined to learn from their peers. Firms with better governance also show a greater propensity to emulate their peers. Moreover, firms facing severe financial constraints are particularly vulnerable to predatory peer behaviors, increasing their likelihood of imitation. Our findings remain robust across alternative network identification strategies, including endogenous selection of peers and traditional instrumental variable analysis utilizing the adoption of Universal Demand (UD) laws as an exogenous source of variation to identify the causal peer effect.

title: Attitude Towards Voting Behaviour: An Analysis of Ajmer City
affiliations: University of Aberdeen

detail.title: Attitude Towards Voting Behaviour: An Analysis of Ajmer City

contentType.other: Submitted in partial fulfilment of a Master's Degree in Political Science

detail.abstract: This study aims to identify the attitude towards voting behaviour in the Ajmer District through the factors affecting the same. The first part of this study divides these factors into the following major heads: the influence of the party and the influence of the candidate. The influence of parties was studied through factors like familial party identification, ideology, the national/regional status of a party and religious preferences. Economic voting and anti-incumbency voting were also taken into account. Influence of the candidates was studied through factors like charisma, dynastic politics, past record, religion and cast of the candidate. Other factors affecting the undecided voters were benefits and social media. The impact of these factors can be so strong that one might put up a question: Do election results truly mirror public opinion? The second part of this study analyses the factors impacting voter turnout. These factors are anti-incumbency voting, costs concerning time and money, lost votes, the introduction of NOTA, the increase in voting awareness campaigns, weather conditions and possession or non-possession of a voter-ID.

title: The Impact of Central Bank Swap Lines on International Currency Competition: Evidence and Theory from Trade Finance
affiliations: Beijing University of Chemical Technology - School of Economics & Management, Central University of Finance and Economics (CUFE) - School of International Trade and Economics, PBCSF, Tsinghua University, Renmin University of China and Renmin University of China

detail.title: The Impact of Central Bank Swap Lines on International Currency Competition: Evidence and Theory from Trade Finance
detail.abstract: International currency competition between the incumbent currency (the US dollar) and the rising currency (China's RMB) has reshaped the global financial system. This paper empirically and theoretically examines how China's central bank RMB bilateral swap lines (BSL) with 40 countries (regions) influence currency competition in trade finance. Using unique data with global coverage, we find: (1) BSLs increase the RMB's share in trade finance by 6% without significantly reducing the dollar's share; (2) categorizing BSLs by publicly stated objectives and activation clauses shows Type I BSL (trade-focused) has no impact on the dollar, whereas Type II BSL (trade and financial stability-focused) reduces the dollar's share by 3%; (3) Type II BSLs drive RMB adoption by improving offshore RMB accessibility and lowering RMB funding costs, enabling it to compete directly with US dollar. These patterns follow naturally from a model of currency competition in trade finance.

title: An Adaptive, Resilient, Regenerative Life-Based Economy? Using Structure-Mapping Theory to Enhance the Conceptual Clarity of Bio-Inspired Economic Models
affiliations: Suffolk University

detail.title: An Adaptive, Resilient, Regenerative Life-Based Economy? Using Structure-Mapping Theory to Enhance the Conceptual Clarity of Bio-Inspired Economic Models
detail.abstract: Disagreement and conceptual vagueness continue to characterize the use biological metaphors in economics, including its bio-inspired, sustainability-oriented subfields. This paper suggests that these challenges may be addressed by asking whether and how the structure, function and dynamics of complex organisms are analogous to those of economies. Aligning with educational and scientific standards in biology, we explore this question by comparing the structure, function, and dynamics of economies against an established standard by which scientists distinguish living from non-living systems: the eight, well-established characteristics of complex organisms: Hierarchical Organization (HO), Metabolism, Homeostasis, Response to Environmental Stimuli, Growth and Development, Reproduction, Evolutionary Adaptation, and Order. To identify deep, structural-functional parallels – rather than flexibly-interpreted metaphorical similarities – we apply the formal criteria of structure-mapping theory which underlie the cognitive alignment process that drives scientific model-building. This analysis suggests that economies are not just metaphorically similar to organisms, but that the properties, principles or laws underlying the structure and abilities of complex organisms apply to economies. More simply, although economies may not resemble complex organisms in appearance, they are organized and function as if they are. This supports shifting from the mechanistic to a biological paradigm. Importantly, shared characteristics – particularly with respect to HO – may enhance the conceptual clarity of vague ecological metaphors, offering potentially a novel, scientifically grounded framework for understanding economies in terms of the structure, function, and dynamics complex organisms. The paper concludes with limitations and directions for future research.

title: Keeping the Agents in the Dark: Competing Mechanisms, Private Disclosures, and the Revelation Principle
affiliations: University of Toulouse Capitole - Toulouse School of Economics, University of Rome Tor Vergata - Dept. of Economics and Finance, Universite de Toulouse 1 Capitole and Northwestern University

detail.title: Keeping the Agents in the Dark: Competing Mechanisms, Private Disclosures, and the Revelation Principle
detail.abstract: We study the design of market information in competing-mechanism games. We identify a new dimension, private disclosures, whereby the principals asymmetrically inform the agents of how their mechanisms operate. We show that private disclosures have two important effects. First, they can raise a principal’s payoff guarantee against her competitors’ threats. Second, they can support equilibrium outcomes and payoffs that cannot be supported with standard mechanisms. These results call for a novel approach to competing mechanisms, which we develop to identify a canonical game and a canonical class of equilibria, thereby establishing a new revelation principle for this class of environments.

title: Short-circuiting Price-default Spirals in Housing Markets
affiliations: San Diego State University, West Virginia University and UNC Charlotte

detail.title: Short-circuiting Price-default Spirals in Housing Markets
detail.abstract: This paper examines whether liquidating distressed houses via short sales instead of real estate owned (REO) transactions can reduce the number of nearby homeowners who subsequently default, thereby curtailing price-default spirals in surrounding housing markets. Using the mortgage securitization of the liquidated house as an instrument for the liquidation channel, we find that each house liquidated via an REO instead of a short sale results in an additional 0.12 to 0.41 homeowner defaults within a 0.10-mile radius. These results suggest that policies that incentivize short sale liquidations can help mitigate price-default spirals in housing markets.

title:
Building a New Form of Socialist Economy in the Digital
Era through "Commodity Anchoring" and "Intelligent
Governance" ——Commodity-Currency Collaborative Governance and New
Paradigm of Socialist Economic Governance under Digital
Technology Empowerment
affiliations: Meizhu Research Laboratory and Soochow University

detail.title:
Building a New Form of Socialist Economy in the Digital
Era through "Commodity Anchoring" and "Intelligent
Governance" ——Commodity-Currency Collaborative Governance and New
Paradigm of Socialist Economic Governance under Digital
Technology Empowerment
detail.abstract:
Global economic governance is trapped in a threefold predicament: "credit decoupling from real economy and shifting to virtual economy, market regulation failure, and imbalance in governance power". Traditional theories and governance tools struggle to address systemic risks. Guided by Xi Jinping Thought on Economics, and based on China's comprehensive industrial chain advantages and the enabling conditions of digital technologies, this paper proposes the theory of "dynamic anchoring of a basket of core commodities" and the collaborative system of "Advanced Planned Economy". This theory selects 1,000 core commodities covering over 90% of the national economic output value, anchors currency issuance to their total value, and dynamically adjusts weights relying on the three-dimensional model of "commodity scarcity-demand elasticity-industrial correlation", forming a logical closed-loop of "physical value anchoring - dynamic quantitative regulation - upgrading of governance efficiency". The technical support system includes a core commodity database (full-chain data penetration), a dynamic weight algorithm (supercomputing-driven real-time iteration), and a digital currency layer (targeted regulation tool), realizing the governance balance of "macro-level orientation without overstepping, micro-level vitality without disorder". Practice shows that this system narrowed the deviation between the growth rates of money supply and physical wealth from 3.2 percentage points to 1.5 percentage points during 2018-2023, with the CPI volatility decreasing by 40%. It also provides a Chinese solution for breaking the US dollar hegemony and building a global pluralistic governance order. This innovation develops the digital expression of the labor theory of value in Marxist political economy, breaks through the dual opposition between planning and market, and contributes a new paradigm to the economic theory of scientific socialism in the digital era.
Definition of Core Concepts
1.Advanced Planned Economy: Refers to an economic governance form enabled by digital technologies, which achieves "controllable macro proportions + autonomous micro decisions" through dynamic monitoring of core commodities and algorithm-based collaborative regulation. Its core feature is relying on full-domain monitoring of the Internet of Things (coverage rate 98.7%) and supercomputing power support, converting national regulatory goals into dynamic weight signals rather than mandatory interventions. It is distinct from the administrative quota model of traditional planned economy, and essentially represents a collaborative paradigm of "effective market + proactive government" in the digital era.[ Referencing Ostrom, E. (2015) "Polycentric Governance" theory, which emphasizes that multiple subjects achieve collaborative governance through information sharing, this paper further transforms "decentralized knowledge" into "centralized wisdom" through digital technologies.]
2.Physical Credit Community: A currency cooperation mechanism based on mutual recognition of regional core commodity reserves and data sharing. Its credit foundation is "total commodity volume + technical endorsement". By building cross-regional commodity pools (e.g., RCEP palm oil and rubber reserves) and cross-border data platforms, it realizes the rigid binding of currency settlement and physical value, freeing from dependence on the sovereign credit of a single country, and providing a technical path to solve the "trilemma of reserve currency".[ Drawing on Triffin, R. (1960) "Triffin Dilemma" which critiques the flaws of sovereign currencies, this paper replaces sovereign credit with physical credit to build a decentralized cross-border cooperation network.]

title: Recent Developments in the Taxation of Cross-Border Services: LATAM Position(s) on the UN Terms of Reference (ToR)
affiliations: University of Sao Paulo (USP), Faculty of Law (FD), Department of Economic, Financial, and Tax Law, Students

detail.title: Recent Developments in the Taxation of Cross-Border Services: LATAM Position(s) on the UN Terms of Reference (ToR)

keywords: UN Framework Convention on International Tax Cooperation
UN Model Tax Convention Between Developed and Developing Countries

detail.abstract: This paper aims to analyse the recent developments on the expansion of source taxing rights concerning technical and/or digital cross-border services. For this purpose, the idea is to analyse what are the legal strategies being formed for the taxation (or not) of cross-border services in the United Nations (UN), especially in the scope of the UN Framework Convention on International Tax Cooperation (Framework Convention) and how these strategies connect with the current geopolitical environment. Our analysis focuses on the Latin American prior experience on the taxation of technical services and/or technical assistance, and how these rules have evolved after the digitalisation of the economy.

title: The Role of Regulator as Minority Shareholders in Shaping Firms’ ESG Performance: Evidence from a Quasi-Natural Experiment in China
affiliations: Northwestern Polytechnic University (NPU), Northwestern Polytechnic University (NPU) and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: The Role of Regulator as Minority Shareholders in Shaping Firms’ ESG Performance: Evidence from a Quasi-Natural Experiment in China
detail.abstract: This study explores the effect of the China Securities Investor Services Center (CSISC), a regulatory mechanism designed to protect minority shareholders and supported by the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC), on firms’ environmental, social, and governance (ESG) performance. The findings, based on a difference-in-differences (DID) method using data from Chinese listed firms between 2013 and 2017, reveal that CSISC shareholding significantly improves ESG performance. These results remain consistent across various robustness tests. Mechanism analysis reveals that CSISC shareholding improves ESG performance by enhancing information transparency and mitigating agency problems. Cross-sectional tests suggest that the effect of CSISC shareholding on ESG performance is more significant in firms with lower institutional ownership, analyst coverage, and media following, and in those without political connections. This study emphasizes the critical role of CSISC shareholding in promoting minority shareholder activism as well as provides valuable policy insights for emerging economies aiming to strengthen minority shareholder protections.

title: Parameter Stability as a Diagnostic Tool for Production Function Specification
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Parameter Stability as a Diagnostic Tool for Production Function Specification
detail.abstract:
The control function approach remains the dominant method for estimating production functions.
In this framework, unobserved productivity is recovered by inverting a proxy function
that relates it to observed state variables and flexible inputs. A key specification test proposed
by Levinsohn and Petrin (2003) relies on the invariance of parameter estimates across different
nonparametric proxies for flexible inputs. Given the widespread use of Cobb-Douglas production
functions in empirical industrial organization, we propose a related test within the parametric inversion
framework of Doraszelski and Jaumandreu (2013) (hereafter DJ). Specifically, we demonstrate
that under the identification assumptions of DJ, the recovered productivity process—and
hence the structural parameter estimates—should be invariant to the choice of flexible input used
for inversion. Consequently, systematic discrepancies across inversion strategies can serve as a
diagnostic tool for detecting violations of the model’s underlying assumptions.

title: Lead, Own, Share: Sovereign Wealth Funds for Transformative AI
affiliations: University of Cambridge - Leverhulme Centre for the Future of Intelligence

detail.title: Lead, Own, Share: Sovereign Wealth Funds for Transformative AI
detail.abstract: This paper proposes sovereign wealth funds (SWFs) as a foundational policy instrument for states to navigate the economic and strategic challenges posed by transformative artificial intelligence (TAI). I explore the rationale for public investment in AI-related assets, drawing on analogies from resource governance and historical state-led development. I evaluate how different types of SWFs—strategic, stabilization, and savings funds—could be adapted to invest in compute infrastructure, upstream supply chains, and equity in frontier AI labs. My analysis identifies key pathways through which public ownership can shape TAI development, mitigate economic volatility, and distribute AI-derived wealth more equitably. I assess the design tradeoffs of ownership models, from minority stakes to majority control, and highlight political and institutional constraints on implementation. By comparing SWFs’ potential to that of laissez-faire or purely regulatory approaches, I argue that SWFs offer a flexible, scalable tool for democratic states to retain strategic influence over TAI while preserving fiscal legitimacy. I conclude by outlining scenarios under which SWFs may succeed or fail, providing a structured framework for policymakers to evaluate this institutional lever in managing the AI transition.

title: Matched or Mismatched? Unpacking Gender Mismatch Gaps with Machine Learning
affiliations: Heriot-Watt University and Heriot-Watt University

detail.title: Matched or Mismatched? Unpacking Gender Mismatch Gaps with Machine Learning
detail.abstract: This paper investigates gender differences in labour market mismatch, specifically, over-education and over-skilling, using rich microdata from the OECD’s Survey of Adult Skills (PIAAC) for the UK. We construct multiple education- and skill-based mismatch indicators and estimate both raw and adjusted gender mismatch gaps (GMGs). To estimate the average treatment effect on the treated (ATET) and flexibly account for a high-dimensional set of covariates, we apply the double-debiased machine learning (DDML) approach combined with stacked generalisation. Our findings confirm that women are more likely to be over-educated, while men are more likely to be over-skilled, in line with previous literature. However, once we control for observable characteristics, most of the gender mismatch gaps attenuate and lose statistical significance. These results highlight the importance of both how mismatch is defined and the methodological approach used, while suggesting that observed gender disparities in mismatch are largely driven by differences in labour market sorting rather than differential treatment

title: Price Discrimination Under Minimum Advertised Price Restriction
affiliations: University of Maryland - Department of Economics, Spotify Economics  and University of Maryland

detail.title: Price Discrimination Under Minimum Advertised Price Restriction
detail.abstract: A minimum advertised price (MAP) policy is a popular vertical restraint. We study retail pricing under MAP using price data of Seagate hard disk drives on US online retailers. The data suggest that MAP is not a form of minimum resale price maintenance (RPM). First, we find that retail prices can be significantly lower than MAP. Second, retail prices of products subject to MAP have greater dispersions between retailers. Lastly, retail prices sometimes increase after a MAP decrease. These observations are consistent with the predictions of a search model that interprets MAP as a form of information restraint.

title: Making Room for Vacationers? The Effect of Airbnb Entry on Eviction Filings in the United States
affiliations: Middlebury College

detail.title: Making Room for Vacationers? The Effect of Airbnb Entry on Eviction Filings in the United States
detail.abstract: I construct novel census-tract-by-year panel data measuring Airbnb listings and eviction filings to estimate the effect of the initial entry of Airbnb into neighborhoods on local eviction filings. Using difference-in-differences and event study methodologies, I find no evidence that Airbnb entry leads to a substantial increase in eviction filings in the ensuing three years. However, this average effect may mask dynamic and heterogeneous effects across neighborhoods, as I find suggestive evidence that, after two years, Airbnb entry causes a modest increase in eviction filings in neighborhoods with a high poverty rate and/or a high concentration of renter households. In neighborhoods where poverty rates are below the national median, Airbnb entry is associated with an increase of 4.5 to 10.9 eviction filings per 1,000 renter households after two years, or a 5.6% to 11.6% increase relative to the average eviction filing rate. In neighborhoods where owner-occupancy is below the national median, the increase ranges from 6.1 to 10.6, or from 7.6% to 10.5%.

title: Applying Information Theory to Increase the Efficiency of Life-History Sampling in Fisheries Data
affiliations: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration - Northwest Fisheries Science Center, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration - Northwest Fisheries Science Center, University of Kiel - Institute of Marine Research, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration - Northwest Fisheries Science Center and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration - Northwest Fisheries Science Center

detail.title: Applying Information Theory to Increase the Efficiency of Life-History Sampling in Fisheries Data
detail.abstract: Effective monitoring of fish populations is critical for understanding life-history traits such as maturation or growth, which directly impact population dynamics and fisheries management. Long-term monitoring efforts around the world are faced with rising survey costs and a more uncertain future, as environmental variability is projected to increase. Together, these pressures necessitate more efficient sampling designs. In this study, we use information theory (Fisher Information) to evaluate and optimize life-history sampling, focusing on how variation in fish growth or maturation can guide more informed sampling decisions. Fisher Information is closely related to variance, in that samples with higher information result in greater precision. Using life-history parameters from eight commercially important groundfish species assessed on the U.S. West Coast, we develop three case studies illustrating how sampling strategies can be improved using Fisher Information. The first example focuses on estimating maturity ogives in the absence of spatial and temporal variability; our second case study incorporates spatial and temporal variation, and the third adds a second life-history trait (growth) to jointly optimize sampling for maturity. Our results indicate that for informing maturity ogives, Fisher Information is maximized at lengths near the inflection point, and that the range of most informative lengths can shift across space and time due to habitat or environmental variation. When both growth and maturation are considered, optimal sampling windows broaden for some species but remain narrow for others. Our simulation results also show that sampling fish in proportion to Fisher Information, rather than random sampling, can reduce sampling effort by more than 50% while maintaining or improving the precision of parameter estimates. While the benefits of using Fisher Information are species specific, these findings suggest that adaptive sampling based on Fisher Information can substantially increase the efficiency and effectiveness of monitoring programs, especially under budgetary or logistical constraints.

title: How Resilient is Public Support for Carbon Pricing? Longitudinal Evidence from Germany
affiliations: Bochum University of Applied Sciences, Wageningen University and University of Malaga

detail.title: How Resilient is Public Support for Carbon Pricing? Longitudinal Evidence from Germany
detail.abstract: The success of climate policies depends crucially on the dynamics of public support. Using unique longitudinal data from three surveys conducted between 2019 and 2022, we study the variations of public support for carbon pricing and revenue use in Germany. Using panel methods, we show that support is very persistent over time. However, people who incur high energy cost decrease their support. Regarding revenue use, we find that social cushioning has become more popular over time, while support for green spending has decreased. Our findings suggest that it is crucial to adapt climate policies in response to increased energy costs.

title: From Absolut-Ists to Anthropo- and Ecocentr-Ists: People's Awareness of Bees’ Decline
affiliations: Università di Bologna - Alma Mater Studiorum Università di Bologna, University of Bologna and Università di Bologna - Alma Mater Studiorum Università di Bologna

detail.title: From Absolut-Ists to Anthropo- and Ecocentr-Ists: People's Awareness of Bees’ Decline
detail.abstract: The understanding of individuals’ awareness of pollinator declines and their consequences remains underexplored. This study aims to identify different profiles of people based on their awareness of the decline in bee populations and the importance of these pollinators. A non-probabilistic sampling design was used through an online survey conducted in Italy with 380 participants aged 21–75. The survey adapted the General Awareness of Consequences (GAC) scale and included measures of the relevance of bees for Ecosystem Services (ES). The segmentation process identified three distinct groups, with no significant differences in sociodemographic profiles. The “Absolutists” segment emerged as the most deeply engaged with the issue of pollinator decline. The “Anthropocentrists”, for whom perceived benefits for human life primarily drive their concern for bee conservation. Finally, the “Ecocentrists” are characterised by a worldview based on a moral responsibility extended to all living beings rather than solely to humans. The findings provide valuable insights to enhance communication, increase awareness, and promote conservation actions. The results provide practical recommendations for public institutions and policymakers to develop targeted strategies that address knowledge gaps and encourage conservation efforts.

title: Comprehensive Analysis of Co2 Capture from Reformer Stack in Methanol Production Via Steam Reforming: Evaluation of Technical, Economic, and Environmental Impacts
affiliations: Sharif University of Technology, Sharif University of Technology and Sharif University of Technology

detail.title: Comprehensive Analysis of Co2 Capture from Reformer Stack in Methanol Production Via Steam Reforming: Evaluation of Technical, Economic, and Environmental Impacts
detail.abstract: This study assesses the techno-economic and environmental feasibility of establishing a CO2 recovery (CDR) unit from the flue gas of a methanol plant. The results demonstrate that adding piperazine (PZ) to monoethanolamine (MEA) significantly enhances CO2 absorption efficiency, with optimal performance achieved at a 10:20 wt.% PZ:MEA ratio. The effects of recovering varying amounts of CO2 from the reformer stack (i.e., 5–25 ton/h) and injecting it under two scenarios (to the reformer feed gas vs. synthesis feed gas) on methanol yield, utility consumption, and emissions were investigated. The optimal capacity of 15 t/h was chosen for maximizing methanol production. The economic assessment included capital and operating costs, while the environmental assessment comprehensively evaluated net CO2 emissions. However, the total required excess energy for solvent regeneration and compression was 2,708 kW of electricity, 45 tons of low-pressure steam, and 3,270 tons of cooling water, corresponding to a 15 t/h CO2 recovery. Moreover, an environmental analysis reveals a paradox: while CO2 recovery reduces direct stack emissions, the indirect emissions from utility services result in a net increase in CO2 output. The CO2 intensity per ton of methanol rises by 20–26% compared to the base case design.

title: Riding the Waves of Frequent Floods: How Regular Updates Shape Flood Risk Perceptions and Insurance Uptake
affiliations: Nanjing Audit University and University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Department of Agricultural and Consumer Economics

detail.title: Riding the Waves of Frequent Floods: How Regular Updates Shape Flood Risk Perceptions and Insurance Uptake
detail.abstract: Do flood risk perceptions evolve with access to diverse and frequently updated risk information? By analyzing monthly county-level flood insurance uptake data, we evaluate how adaptive behaviors are shaped by three key information sources, media coverage of climate change, direct disaster experiences, and indirect disaster exposure. While updated risk information generally increases insurance adoption, the relative importance of information sources varies. Local and indirect disaster experiences exhibit stronger importance for behavioral adaptation, whereas unexpected climate change media coverage shows context-dependent importance modulated by its intensity, topic focus, and tone of coverage. Media influence further varies across political ideology, educational attainment, employment status, and baseline flood risk. These findings challenge one-size-fits-all risk communication paradigms, instead highlighting the need for demographically tailored strategies that accommodate audience-specific informational processing to optimize climate resilience and preparedness.

title: Global Public Opinion on Tradeoffs between Environmental Protection and Economic Growth
affiliations: University of Vermont and University of Vermont

detail.title: Global Public Opinion on Tradeoffs between Environmental Protection and Economic Growth
detail.abstract: Studies have found that most people don’t think of environmental protection and economic growth as mutually exclusive. As ecological economists have challenged this assumption, exploring public opinion on possible tradeoffs between the environment and the economy is critical. Until now, most research investigating these tradeoffs has been primarily conducted in Global North countries, mainly in Europe. We elevate this to a global level by analyzing data for 92 countries from the World Values Survey, particularly how people's prioritization relates to demographic and socio-economic factors. The results show that a majority of the global population prioritizes environmental protection over economic growth (60.07%), especially in high-income countries in the Americas, Western Europe, and Oceania, but also in Southeast Asia. Surprisingly, we can show significant differences in the influence of demographic and socio-economic factors on people's level of environmental support. In the global average and a majority of countries, stronger environmental support is held by more educated people, those leaning politically to the left, females, and younger people. Income is shown not to have a significant effect on the global scale. However, our results indicate a broad diversity across countries in how all these variables influence the prioritization between the environment and the economy. Especially in non-Western countries, the often-assumed factors do not play out as expected. Overall, these results suggest that there should be a general openness for an economic system that places greater value on the environment and less on economic growth, such as degrowth.

title: Bridging Dimensions of Governance: Lessons from Perspectives on Participation Ladders and Natural Resources Management Principles
affiliations: Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences (SLU) - Department of Forest Economics, University of Milan and Department of Forest Economics, SLU

detail.title: Bridging Dimensions of Governance: Lessons from Perspectives on Participation Ladders and Natural Resources Management Principles
detail.abstract: Citizen and stakeholder participation is increasingly promoted as key to make institutions more effective in their governance of natural resources. Clearly, if participation implies a meaningful redistribution of power, its implications become especially relevant for understanding how decisions are made, by whom, and in whose interests. However, existing governance principles for natural resource management (NRM) have overlooked the influence of varying degrees of participation in their achievement. This paper explores the relationship between rungs of participation and the realization of NRM governance principles. Drawing on peer-reviewed literature case studies from diverse NRM contexts, it uses a structured framework of ascending participation rungs to compare how varying shapes of participation – from passive information sharing to full decision-making authority – influence governance outcomes. The analysis shows that lower rungs of participation generally offer limited support for effective governance. Mid-range rungs, where stakeholders influence agenda-setting and implementation, emerge as a threshold where participation begins to meaningfully affect governance outcomes. At the highest rungs, participation can enhance governance for NRM but may also generate trade-offs if institutional capacity is weak and coordination challenges arise. This analysis opens room for discussion on the shift from environmental governance to governance for sustainability, where citizen’s inputs are increasingly asked and the social and economic dimensions are considered besides the environmental one. Rather than treating participation as inherently beneficial, it highlights the conditions under which it can strengthen or undermine effective governance, inviting further reflection on the design and support of participatory process in complex environmental settings.

title: Awareness of Environmental and Climate Changes and Migration Decisions: The Case of Middle East and North Africa Countries
affiliations: University of Pavia

detail.title: Awareness of Environmental and Climate Changes and Migration Decisions: The Case of Middle East and North Africa Countries

keywords: Climate change and anthropocentric climate change awareness
Reported experience with extreme weather events

detail.abstract: This paper provides a novel perspective to examine whether and how individual awareness of environmental and climate changes is influenced by extreme weather, and, in turn, whether and how such awareness affects intentions to migrate internationally from Middle East and North Africa countries.Specifically, five proxies of awareness are considered, reflecting environmental awareness and the negative externalities associated with issues such as natural resource scarcity and climate change.These data are then combined with official measures of various climate hazards, accounting for the specific characteristics of the events (number of affected locations, duration, and incidence), as well as individual geographical proximity to areas affected by extreme weather conditions.Given that past climatic conditions may be key in the climate–migration nexus, two distinct time horizons, corresponding to the short and medium term, are considered.The results show that the five proxies of awareness positively influence migration intentions in the short and medium term. In addition, the reported experience with climate hazards shapes awareness of environmental and climate changes, while the factors influencing this experience evolve over time.Lastly, empirical analysis demonstrates that male migrants appear more aware of environmental and climate changes than women in the short term, while the opposite occurs in the medium term.

title: Market Clearing Formulation with High-Voltage Direct Current (Hvdc) Optimization and Transmission Losses Under Increasing Renewable Shares
affiliations: National Renewable Energy Laboratory, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Market Clearing Formulation with High-Voltage Direct Current (Hvdc) Optimization and Transmission Losses Under Increasing Renewable Shares
detail.abstract: With the increasing shares of renewable energy and the integration of flow-controllable high-voltage direct current (HVDC) lines, the market clearing mathematic models warrant further investigation. This paper identifies several potential issues, including a) sizeable circular power flows between alternating current (AC) and HVDC lines that may occur due to factors such as inaccuracies in the linearized AC loss model or negative prices; b) counter intuitive transmission flow outcomes and potential incentive misalignment when negative offers driven by policies or contracts outside of the electricity markets are setting market clearing prices; The paper also studied production sized market clearing model under high renewable penetration scenario and proposed potential methods to mitigate the observed circular flow.

title: Co-Producing Gender Knowledge in Energy Transitions: A Grey Literature Perspective

detail.title: Co-Producing Gender Knowledge in Energy Transitions: A Grey Literature Perspective
detail.abstract: This paper explores how the issue of gender is co-produced within the context of energy transitions, and how gendered framings in grey literature actively shape both policy and research directions in the energy field. Drawing on Sheila Jasanoff’s concept of co-production, we analyze how gender is not simply added onto existing energy systems, but is entangled with the epistemic, institutional, and technological configurations that underpin those systems. Based on a purposive sample of 138 grey literature documents published between 2018 and 2023, we examine how gender is framed across energy subsystems (political, economic, socio-ecological, and technological) and across multiple levels of analysis—from household to global. Our findings show that while economic and socio-ecological concerns are commonly addressed, technological domains remain largely gender-blind. Gender is often reduced to “women,” with limited intersectional analysis. Nevertheless, grey literature plays a key role in stabilizing certain visions of gender equality, contributing to the co-production of policy logics, intervention strategies, and research] agendas that define the contemporary energy transition.

title: Navigating Two Worlds: Indigenous Worldviews and the Impact of Tourism in the Colombian Amazon
affiliations: Universidad del Valle and Universidad del Valle

detail.title: Navigating Two Worlds: Indigenous Worldviews and the Impact of Tourism in the Colombian Amazon
detail.abstract: This study explores the influence of tourism on the valuation of nature among Indigenous communities in the Colombian Amazon, specifically in Leticia and Puerto Nariño. Using a mixed-methods approach, it analyzes tourism trends. It engages with Indigenous voices to examine how tourism shapes environmental values through the lens of the Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES) valuation framework and Aníbal Quijano’s theory of coloniality of power. The findings reveal a dynamic interplay between intrinsic, relational, and instrumental values of nature, with tourism fostering both opportunities for cultural revitalization and risks of cultural commodification. Indigenous communities articulate deep relational connections with nature, particularly the Amazon River, which tourism often reconfigures through capitalist and Western lenses. While community-based tourism can act as a vehicle for decolonial praxis and environmental stewardship, the predominance of corporate tourism models and weak governance structures perpetuates extractive legacies and marginalizes Indigenous worldviews. The paper argues for tourism policies grounded in Indigenous epistemologies to support sustainability and self-determination in Amazonian territories.

title: Exploring Public Contributions Using Taxes and Donations for Sustainable Financing in Wetland Conservation in Malaysia

detail.title: Exploring Public Contributions Using Taxes and Donations for Sustainable Financing in Wetland Conservation in Malaysia
detail.abstract: Nature resource conservation in Malaysia faces significant challenges due to limited public funding and increasing environmental degradation. Identifying sustainable financing mechanisms that align with public preferences is critical for long-term conservation efforts. This study evaluates public preferences for wetland conservation in Malaysia using choice experiments with tax and donation as monetary attributes. Data was collected using a quantitative research approach through face-to-face interviews with the public within the wetland areas. Economic analyses and modeling were conducted using BIOGEME software to estimate willingness to pay (WTP) and assess the influence of payment mechanisms. The results of Mixed Logit Model reveal that the price coefficient as a measure of sensitivity to conservation costs is remarkably similar across the two mechanisms. While the marginal WTP from the donation is slightly higher (RM42.80/ month) than the payment using tax (RM35.30/month). This finding suggests that the monetary valuation of wetlands is consistent regardless of the payment method, underscoring the universal recognition of their intrinsic value. These quantitative responses and contextual factors highlight the importance of public trust, perceived fairness, and ease of implementation in determining the viability of each funding mechanism. The study concludes that a hybrid or alternative approach leveraging both voluntary (donation) and mandatory (tax) contributions could enhance funding resilience while addressing diverse stakeholder preferences. These insights contribute to the discourse on sustainable financing for biodiversity conservation in developing countries.

detail.title: Development of a Probabilistic Framework for Realistic Vehicle Collision Scenario Generation

keywords: Vehicle Collision Non linear Finite Simulation

detail.abstract: This study proposes a probabilistic modeling approach to generate realistic virtual collision scenarios based on real-world vehicle crash data. Conventional crashworthiness assessments rely on standardized test conditions stipulated in regulations, which fail to fully reflect the complexity and diversity of actual road environments. Utilizing over 60,000 real crash cases provided by the U.S. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), we quantitatively analyzed key variables such as collision speed, impact location, vehicle type, and road surface condition to derive corresponding probability distributions. Through the application of Kernel Density Estimation (KDE) and Smoothed Probabilities, we established a reliable probabilistic framework. Subsequently, we employed the Latin Hypercube Sampling (LHS) technique to generate 30 virtual crash scenarios that ensure both representativeness and diversity. The proposed methodology enables scenario-based analyses that effectively capture the uncertainty and variability of real-world collisions. It offers substantial utility in diverse domains such as vehicle structural analysis, design optimization, and traffic safety policy development.

title: Community Engagement in Conservation of Biodiversity in Protected Areas: Assessing the Willingness to Pay of Local Community to the Restoration of Kafta-Sheraro National Park, Tigray, Northern Ethiopia

detail.title: Community Engagement in Conservation of Biodiversity in Protected Areas: Assessing the Willingness to Pay of Local Community to the Restoration of Kafta-Sheraro National Park, Tigray, Northern Ethiopia
detail.abstract: Protected areas are crucial for conserving biodiversity and providing ecosystem services, yet they face major threats like habitat fragmentation, human encroachment, and inadequate funding. This study evaluates local community willingness in conserving Kafta-Sheraro National Park, focusing on their willingness to contribute through financial support or labor to help mitigate these challenges. Using data from 384 local residents, the study gathered insights on perceived threats and conservation trends. Most respondents reported severe habitat degradation caused by agricultural expansion, illegal logging, and grazing. Majority (88.8%) the participants supported for the proposed conservation plan, with 72.43% preferring labor contributions and 27.57% opting for monetary support. Probit and biprobit models were used to analyze the determinants of respondents’ preferences and willingness to accept the offered bids. Ethnicity, residence conditions, livestock ownership, and income from forest products significantly influenced their decisions. Those with previous conflicts regarding conservation were less likely to support for the proposed plan. Households willing to contribute financially showed an average annual willingness to pay (WTPM) of 1,362.24 birr (approximately US$40.40), while those favoring labor contributions were willing to offer an average of 30 labor days per year. When aggregated across kebeles adjacent to the park, total contributions were estimated at 5,632,519 birr (US$166,988.41) and 325,929 labor days annually. These results emphasize the need to integrate community participation into conservation planning. By recognizing local willingness and addressing socio-economic factors, park management can build sustainable, inclusive strategies that benefit both the ecosystem and surrounding communities.

title: The Risk-Adjusted Discount Rate and Outflows a Solution to an Error
affiliations: Graduate Business School -- Fin/Eco

detail.title: The Risk-Adjusted Discount Rate and Outflows a Solution to an Error
detail.abstract: The Risk-Adjusted Discount Rate (RADR) method uses k to discount and compound risky flows. It is incorrect for outflows. We create the M-DCF which reformulates discounting and compounding. The M-DCF complies with risk aversion, is internally consistent, solves existing errors, complies with market prices, and it offers new insights using a single k. We prove that the RADR underestimates the PV of risky outflows and overestimates the FV of current risky outflows. We prove that the PV of an outflow may have a larger absolute value than the future cashflow. We prove that the RADR is a corner solution.

title: System-Level Analysis of Dry-Sorbent Co2 Capture Process Integrated with Natural Gas Combined Cycle

detail.title: System-Level Analysis of Dry-Sorbent Co2 Capture Process Integrated with Natural Gas Combined Cycle
detail.abstract: Compared to conventional fossil fuel power plants, natural gas combined cycle (NGCC) systems produce less CO2 and offer higher efficiency, making them a promising transitional technology for power generation. Nevertheless, CO2 emissions from NGCC still contribute to environmental degradation, necessitating the integration of CO2 capture technologies. Dry-sorbent CO2 capture, in particular, offers advantages such as compact plant design, reduced corrosion, and lower energy consumption. However, its economic and environmental performance has not been extensively investigated. In this study, two dry-sorbent CO2 capture processes were developed, employing vacuum swing adsorption (VSA) and temperature swing adsorption (TSA), respectively. The levelized costs of CO2 capture were determined to be 76.4 USD per ton and 73.3 USD per ton for VSA and TSA, respectively. Furthermore, global warming potential was reduced by 45% and 49% for VSA and TSA, respectively, corresponding to annual reductions of 827 × 103 and 908 × 103 tons of CO2 eq. These results indicate that TSA is the more economically and environmentally advantageous option. The electricity consumption of blowers, driven by pressure drop, was identified as a major factor influencing both economic and sustainability outcomes. The insights from this study may serve as guidelines for the commercialization and optimization of the dry-sorbent CO2 capture process.

title: Who Benefits Most from Fare-Free Public Transport? Socioeconomic Heterogeneity of Effects – Evidence from Clermont-Ferrand, France

detail.title: Who Benefits Most from Fare-Free Public Transport? Socioeconomic Heterogeneity of Effects – Evidence from Clermont-Ferrand, France
detail.abstract: This paper estimates the impact on household mobility of the fare-free public transport measure implemented on weekends in Clermont-Ferrand, France. More precisely, we are interested in the influence of socioeconomic determinants on the likelihood of using public transport more often following the introduction of a free travel measure. We investigate changes in travel behavior at the individual level, using data from the household travel survey (Cerema Certified Mobility Survey EMC²) conducted in the metropolitan area of Clermont-Ferrand in 2023. We built a weighted binary logistic regression to estimate the probability that users increase their public transport use due to the fare-free policy, depending on their socioeconomic characteristics. Results highlight an increase in public transport use for over 50% of users, mainly for shopping, leisure, and family and friends visiting. In addition, our analysis indicates that the impacts of free travel vary according to individual characteristics. In Clermont-Ferrand, low-income households, residents of priority urban districts, and families with children benefit more from the fare-free policy. Fare-free public transport eliminates tariff and non-tariff barriers to the public transport network on weekends, which may deter modest households from traveling or participating in solidarity pricing schemes. We also demonstrate that residing in an urban priority district (QPV) has a specific impact. Therefore, there could be a socioeconomic neighborhood effect beyond the composition effect. This study intends to contribute to the literature on free public transport policy evaluation, with a focus on the socioeconomic heterogeneity of effects.

detail.title: Adopting Digital Technologies Under Monetary Policy Uncertainty
detail.abstract: We examine the impact of monetary policy uncertainty on firms’ digital transformation. Using panel data on Chinese A-share listed manufacturing firms from 2010 to 2022, we find that a one standard deviation increase in monetary policy uncertainty (0.397) reduces the likelihood of digital transformation by at least 15%. Relative to the sample mean of digital transformation (1.269), this effect corresponds to an 11.8% decline. We identify four mechanisms driving this effect: reduced corporate risk appetite, lower cash holdings, curtailed R&D investment, and heightened financing costs. The results withstand alternative specifications, instrumental variable analysis, and extensive tests for endogeneity and heterogeneity. Importantly, the observed effects are not confounded by political, regulatory, and institutional uncertainties. Our findings underscore the importance of stabilising monetary policy to foster firm-level digital innovation.

title: Scaling Law Evolution between Urban Freight Transportation and Economic Development in China

detail.title: Scaling Law Evolution between Urban Freight Transportation and Economic Development in China
detail.abstract: Amid rapid urbanization and industrial change, understanding freight–economy dynamics is vital to shaping a sustainable transport system. This study utilizes statistical data from 288 prefecture-level cities in China from 2000 to 2023 to systematically investigate the causality, nonlinear coupling relationships, and their spatiotemporal evolution by applying the multispatial convergent cross mapping approach and scaling law. The results show that: (1) There exists a significant bidirectional causality between freight volume and most economic indicators, reflecting strong endogenous interactions; (2) a general sublinear scaling relationship is observed between economic variables and freight transportation, with declining coupling strength over time, suggesting an emerging trend of decoupling; and (3) spatially, the coupling relationship has progressively extended from eastern China to the central and western regions, with regional disparities showing signs of convergence. This study uncovers the spatiotemporal coupling between freight transportation and economic development, offering insights for regional transport planning and industrial layout.

detail.title: Factors that Lead to Better Implementation of Potato Variety (Nech Abeba) and Degree of Involvement: A Case Study of Janamoura District in the North Gondar Region of Ethiopia
detail.abstract: The study examined whether improved potato varieties have been introduced in Janamora woreda. Using primary data from smallholder potato growers, the study was carried out in order to meet the main and specific objectives. The introduction of improved potato varieties in the study area has not been the subject of any empirical research. This study used a quantitative survey approach with cross-sectional survey data gathered from 371 randomly chosen sample households in order to reduce the gap and accomplish the goals. The three study areas were selected purposively considering highly concentrated potato growing areas. The data obtained for this data were analyzed using both descriptive and econometric techniques. The findings demonstrated the importance of the independent factors included in the logistic and Tobit regression models, including household education level, fertilizer use, land size, experience of the household head, credit axcess and counseling services played a big role in hiring choices. Consequently, policies as well as strategies related to adoption and level of adoption of improved potato varities can influence these different factors in order to boost growers' acceptance.

detail.title: Coupled Anns-Adm Solution for Mhd Ternary Hybrid Nanofluid ( [[Equation]] ) Flow Over a Wedge: Biomedical Application
detail.abstract: This work identifies heat and fluid flow in a Ti6Al4V–ZnO–Fe2O3/blood mixture around a wedge model, used in biomedical engineering. The goal is to develop better heating and fluid movement in medicine, especially in hyperthermia and drug delivery, where exact control over how heat moves is important. By applying Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) and the Adomian Decomposition Method (ADM) to the governing equations for mass, momentum and energy conservation, we get solutions that are both semi-analytical and highly accurate. It is seen from key results that boosting the magnetic parameter (M = 0.5–2.0) leads to a 30% decrease in the average flow, while facilitating much better temperature spread. Compared to Ti_{6}Al_{4}V (φ1 = 0.05–0.2), ZnO (φ2 = 0.05–0.2) is found to have better thermal performance, since ZnO has slightly lower conductivity. If both thermal radiation (Rd is 0.1–0.5) and viscous dissipation (Ec is 0.01–0.1) are considered, they raise temperatures and boost heat transfer efficiency. Results for four curves are found to be within 1% of the existing numerical data (Table 4). The results suggest that ternary hybrid nanofluids, enhanced with Ti6Al4V, exhibit useful advantages in biomedicine due to their balance of heat transfer and fluid motion. Studies should concentrate on testing and reviewing how well these resins can be used in actual medical settings.

title: Trade Policy-Driven Efficiency Evaluation and Multi-Scenario Forecasting of the Photovoltaic Industry in Yangtze River Delta, China

detail.title: Trade Policy-Driven Efficiency Evaluation and Multi-Scenario Forecasting of the Photovoltaic Industry in Yangtze River Delta, China
detail.abstract: This study evaluates the operational efficiency and systemic resilience of China’s Yangtze River Delta (YRD) photovoltaic (PV) industry in response to escalating global trade barriers and domestic policy transitions. By using a Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) and a three-stage Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA) with carbon social cost, the results demonstrate significant inter-provincial heterogeneity: Jiangsu excels in carbon mitigation performance, yet displays heightened sensitivity to subsidy cuts; the eco-efficiency paradox observed in Anhui where ecological benefits coexist with systemic inefficiencies unveils a resource misallocation trap; Zhejiang’s innovation intensity contrasts with intra-regional imbalances; and Shanghai leverages managerial strengths despite spatial and land-use constraints. Scenario analyses show that a 50% tariff imposition reduces export-oriented efficiency by 4.9%; carbon border measures disrupt scale optimization, and subsidy phase-outs expose structural weaknesses of the PV industry. These findings underscore the adaptive resilience of YRD’s PV industry while exposing persistent structural inefficiencies, necessitating region-specific policies, R&D alignment, and cross-regional synergies to sustain China’s PV leadership in a shifting global trade landscape.

detail.abstract: This paper uses longitudinal data to study the benefits of participation in scholastic athletics starting with high school participation and continuing with college athletics, including the benefits of intramural athletics. We study the impact of participation on a number of important life outcomes, including graduation from high school and college and wages after schooling is completed. Controlling for rich measures of cognitive and personality skills and social background, we find substantial benefits at all levels. Participation in athletics promotes social mobility for disadvantaged and minority students.

title: Speaking of Inflation: The Influence of Fed Speeches on Expectations
affiliations: Norges Bank, BI Norwegian Business School, Department of Data Science and Analytics, University of Auckland and University of Warwick

detail.title: Speaking of Inflation: The Influence of Fed Speeches on Expectations
detail.abstract: We examine how speeches by Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) members, including regional Fed presidents, shape private sector expectations. Speeches that signal rising inflationary pressures prompt both households and professional forecasters to raise their inflation expectations, consistent with Delphic effects. Only professional forecasters respond to Odyssean communications—statements about the Fed’s intended policy response—leaving Delphic effects as the dominant channel for households. These household responses are driven by speeches from regional presidents, likely due to greater visibility in regional media coverage. A general equilibrium model, featuring agents who differ in their ability to interpret Odyssean signals, explains this heterogeneity.

title: Fertility in Sub-Saharan Africa: The Interplay between Policy, Culture, and Intra-Household Bargaining
affiliations: University of Galway, University of Bristol - Department of Economics and CESifo (Center for Economic Studies and Ifo Institute) - Ifo Institute

detail.title: Fertility in Sub-Saharan Africa: The Interplay between Policy, Culture, and Intra-Household Bargaining
detail.abstract: This paper investigates the causal impact of free primary education (FPE) on fertility decisions among parents in sub-Saharan Africa, focusing on the interplay between the policy, intra-household bargaining, and cultural norms. Using Demographic and Health Survey data and exploiting the staggered rollout of FPE across 17 countries, we find that FPE reduces fertility by 0.1 children per woman and improves child survival and school enrollment. Linking these data with ethnic-level cultural norms of male dominance, we find that these effects are concentrated among ethnic groups with low male dominance, while high male-dominance groups experience minimal or opposing effects. We further show that FPE strengthens women’s bargaining power in low male-dominance settings, as evidenced by increased contraceptive use, greater influence over reproductive decisions, and higher participation in household decision-making. These changes are accompanied by higher labor force participation, increased media engagement, a higher probability of divorce, and reduced tolerance for intimate partner violence. Such shifts are largely absent in high-male dominance cultures. These findings are consistent with a simple theoretical framework that integrates the canonical quantity–quality trade-off into a household bargaining model with limited commitment, where cultural norms are captured by the extent of women’s veto power over fertility decisions. Our results highlight the critical role of cultural norms in shaping the effects of policy interventions on fertility behavior and broader development outcomes.

title: Government Scale as a Stabilizer: Effects on Output Volatility and Losses
affiliations: ISEG Lisbon School of Economics and Management,Universidade de Lisboa, University of Lisbon and University Institute of Lisbon (IUL) - Lisbon Accounting and Business School (ISCAL)

detail.title: Government Scale as a Stabilizer: Effects on Output Volatility and Losses
detail.abstract: We examine the impact of government size on economic fluctuations and the role of fiscal policy in promoting macroeconomic stability in the period 1980-2024. The results indicate that indirect taxes, capital taxes, and social security contributions (as a percentage of GDP) are associated with lower output volatility, whereas direct taxes tend to amplify it, particularly over longer horizons. On the expenditure side, current spending – especially public wages and interest payments – also exerts a stabilising influence. We further provide new estimates of output losses from the two most severe recent recessions in the EU27 – the Great Recession and the COVID-19 pandemic – and find evidence that the severity of these losses may be linked to the scale of the government, both before and after the crises.
